column2: Anthropologists love to tell the story of the "cargo tribes" of New Guinea, who have built huge models of airports in the jungle in the hope that a passing airplane will come down and land on them.
"WHEREVER America's cities are going, Newark will get there first."--Motto of the administration of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark.

ATHENS--According to Greek legend, a man named Palamides practiced medicine in the region at Nafplion during prehistoric times. Last year, while archeologists were exploring a fortress in that area, they accidentally discovered a tomb from Mycenaean times, the Greek bronze age. Inside, they found a set of medical instruments.

A Florida woman has been convicted by a Federal jury in Manhattan of defrauding a West Virginia bank and a Canadian businessman of $260,000 with the aid of false letters of recommendation written by a former United Nations official with whom she was having a love affair.

WASHINGTON--Late one afternoon last summer, Thomas P. O'Neil Jr. was musing about the responsibilities of the House majority leader. He had been out campaigning for a Democratic colleague the night before, and he had spent all day holding audiences with other Democrats on the House floor or in his office down the hall. That evening he was flying to California for a weekend of campaigning for Democratic candidates on the West Coast.

Back home in Quitman, Tex., population 1,500, Sissy Spacek was a cheerleader, a majorette, a 4-H club member, the football quarterback's girlfriend, and in her senior year, homecoming queen. She was, in her own words, "an All-American girl."

CAMP KADUM, Israeli--Occupied West Bank, Dec. 8--A year ago today the Israeli Government told a zealous group of Israeli squatters that they could remain in their illegal settlement here for only three months while the Cabinet decided on the future of its West Bank settlement policy.

Segovia wrote his own, Merrill did his "with" Robert Saffron, and the Peerce memoirs are unblushingly "by" Alan Levy. Segovia explains: "I would not think of using a borrowed pen. I choose to use my own and speak in my own words. Thus, in lieu of scholarship and writing craft, the reader will find greater authenticity in this story."

OSAKA, He's the self-styled "mayor of the night" of a seedy neighborhood near the city's gaudiest nightclub district. His youthful followers are under strict orders not to drink in the bars near the highwalled confines of his spacious headquarters complex or otherwise harass the ordinary citizenry.

THE United States Government has been listening, but so far New Jersey residents have not been doing much talking. The subject is Sandy Hook, the 6.5-milelong peninsula that juts north from Atlantic Highlands into the Lower Bay, and the theme is the development of the 4,600-acre site as part of the Gateway National Recreation Area.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 11--A ceasefire has been worked out between rival Moslem and Christian factions in the district of Bint Jbail in southern Lebanon near the border with Israel.

Walter Benedick, president and founder of Investor Planning Corporation of America, one of the largest mutual-fund sales organizations in the 1960's, died yesterday at his home in New York City after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

The plan to turn Manhattan Plaza, a $951 million development west of Times Square into subsidized housing for performing artists is now in the final states of consideration by the City Planning Commission, with a decision expected early next month.

WASHINGTON--The hardest part, of course, was losing the election. But the second-hardest thing for the lame-duck Ford Administration is giving up the grand plans and pet projects with which it intended to save the Republic over the next four years.

Last August I paid a visit to AM Travel Service--also known as Amicus--at 50 East 42d Street. I told a woman in the cramped office suite that I wanted to leave for Europe on Sept. 5 and return about a month later. She said there was a flight to Brussels and back for $319--$306 plus $3 airport tax plus $10 "membership and administrative fee" (I never did find out what that meant.)

GARDEN CITY, L.I. Dec. 11--A hearing board at Adelphi University here ruled this week that the campus newspaper was under no legal obligation to print material that the student government considered important, but the verdict left both sides dissatisfied.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP)--President Ford discussed possible large pay increases for top-ranked Federal employees, members of Congress and other Government officials as he continued work today nn the budget for the 1978 fiscal year.

DESPITE the birth-control pill --the panacea that was once expected to make unwanted pregnancies a thing of the past --and perhaps because of the legalization of abortion and a more liberal attitude toward sex, pregnancies among unmarried Long Island teen-agers have reached distressing proportions.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 11--Mary Schneider's Sign of the Times, one of the more consistent fox chasers in the metropolitan area, scored 13 points and won the local working hunter championship today at the Boulder Brook indoor horse show.

CHICAGO--At 7:30 A.M. on most weekdays, a slight, short, gray-haired man with a gray moustache steps out of his chauffeured Cadillac limousine on South Michigan Avenue and walks into the harbor shop of the Conrad Hilton Hotel.

LINES are peculiar things. Nobody plans them. Usually selfgenerating and almost always consisting of people who say they wouldn't dream of being part of them, they form where it might naturally be expected they would--at the Lincoln and Holland Tunnel toll booths in the rush hours, at do-it-yourself hardware counters in Wayne and for standing-room-only at the latest fad restaurants in Fort Lee.

TO preserve jobs in New York State and keep the state even marginally attractive to business and industry, the Legisla ture must often resort to Faustian bargains. While other branches of state government, of course, are not immune to this affliction, this argument is well illustrated in the Legislature by past actions and future predictions surrounding one bill--a measure banning nonreturnable bottles and containers.
What on earth is one to say about Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo, a dance company of strange reputation, which was to be seen at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday night.

KEANSBURG EACH day at low tide, Richard H. Lentze watches his dreams of enlarging his marina sink to the muddy bottom of Thorn's Creek, a couple of hundred yards from Raritan Bay. Silt has choked the boating channels and the marina over the last three years until, at low water, the boats still using the docks on Thorn's and Waycake Creeks rest on the bottom in ankle-deep water.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 11-- The Islanders' "youth 'n' age" duo of Bryan Trottier and Ed Westfall ran rampant tonight as the New Yorkers routed the Pittsburgh Penguins, 6-3, at Nassau Coliseum. The 20-year-old Trottier, the youngest player on the ice, tallied two goals and an assist. Westfall, at 36 the oldest, had one goal and three assists.

Dr. Herbert L. Kleinfield, professor of American studies at C.W. Post College for the last 15 years and general editor of "The Collective works of Washington Irving," died Friday at Meadowbrook Hospital, East Meadow, L.I., after a long illness. He was 55 years old and lived at 90-A Dosoris Lane; Glen Cove, L.I.
Mr. and Mrs. Morris J. Solomon of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Randy Esther Solomon, to Gerry Evan Feinberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Feinberg of Woodbury, L.I.

A 21-year-old former mental patient convicted of killing a man gild wounding a policeman inside St. Vincent's Hospital in New York City in January 1975 was sentenced Friday to two consecutive terms of life in prison. He will be eligible for parole after 25 years.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 11--When the chief prosecutor in the aborted political corruption trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel was losing his argument in court earlier this week against defense demands for a mistrial, he characterized the Government's case as besieged by sinister forces.

The next time your buddy pulls you aside after a night of league bowling and tells you to be a bit more straightforward in your game, the odds are that he is not impugning your integrity but has detected a flaw in your delivery.
Dan Dierdorf won't be wearing pompoms today.

WASHINGTON-Crawling out of the rubble of the 1976 electoral blitz, the Republican Party has reckoned the number of its surviving office-holders at a deeply disturbing few. But, given the lack of a rallying leader like Winston Churchill, G.O.P. morale six weeks after the onslaught seems remarkably, almost unreasonably high.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Dec. 11--Haverford College announced today a compromise decision designed to end a long occasionally bitter debate with nearby Bryn Mawr College. At issue was a proposal to convert Haverford, a small college for men here on Philadelphia's Main Line, into a coeducational institution.

THERE comes a time in the tide of governmental affairs when an overdue idea suddenly pops up and seemingly is unstop pable. The proposed "sunset" law is one of these ideas and the time is now. But it may not be unstoppable. There is considerable opposition to it.
THE voice crackled over the radio: "Breaker one-nine. Smokey report. Wall-to-wall bears east at five-oh on four nine-five but clean and green up to the twister at five-one."

There's an old show-business adage that warns actors to avoid, at all costs, playing opposite either children or animals. As an actor currently employed doing children's theater, which always booms at this time of year, trust me when I say that acting with children is duck soup compared to acting for children. (I have never acted for animals, although one particularly rowdy audience in Chicago came awfully close.)

Montana State won the Division II football championship of the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday, and Texas A. and I. won a third consecutive Division I crown in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Schmeelk of Katonah, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Luellen Marie Schmeelk, to J. Gary Henderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Henderson of Bedford, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

WASHINGTON--When President-elect Jimmy Carter got a briefing from members of his transition staff on Thursday about the problems he will soon face in the Treasury Department's area of economic policy, four of the six economists who briefed him were women. It seemed to be a sign of real progress for the women's movement.
HUNTINGTON FIFTEEN persons gathered in the gymnasium of the Y.M.C..A. here the other night and for one hour did little mere than the on their backs and bend their knees every now and then.
Three years ago the average age of a New York City public school teacher was 28 years. Today it is 41.

Susan Irene Teshcr, a member of the University College public relations staff at Adelphi University, was married last evening to Harvey Jay Heinovitz, an instructor at Adelphi's School of Business. Rabbi Charles Agin performed the ceremony at the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club.

When the holiday season rolls around, nothing seems quite so festive as red. Even designers who generally favor neutrals and pale colors will acknowledge the tonic effect of color by adding a flash of red to their holiday collections, as have the four designers represented here-- two well established and two trying to break into the big time.
What cards to buy and what gifts to select all pale beside the apartment dweller's really serious Christmas decision: what to tip the building staff.
SAN ANTONIO, Dec. 11--A former high-ranking executive of the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company has testified that the company frequently wiretapped its employees and customers.

WINDOW ROCK, Ariz., Dec. 11--A Navajo radio network is to begin broadcasting daily news and information programs in the Navajo language Monday to the tribe's 150,000 members on the 25,000 square mile reservation in Arizona, New Mexico and Utah.
LIHUE, Hawaii, Dec. 11 (UPI)--Dr. Renee Richards advanced to the final of a $20,000 women's tennis tournament today when Karen Krantzcke of Australia had to default.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--At least six of the 18 members at the New York City Congressional delegation and several representatives of nearby districts have accepted the blandishments of the Korean lobby, whose alleged efforts to influence United States Congressmen are the subject of multiple investigations here.

Tony Dorsett of Pittsburgh was, by far, the most spectacular individual college football player in the nation this season and deservedly won the Heisman Trophy as the "outstanding college player in the nation." But the Pitt Panthers went through the season undefeated, untied and ranked No. 1 because Dorsett had considerable help.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Dec. 11 (AP) --Lou Holtz was hired today as head football coach at the University of Arkansas, two days after he had resigned the head-coach position with the New York Jets of the National Football League.
PARIS, Dec. 11--More than half of the Soviet Jewish emigrants, all of whom ostensibly leave the Soviet Union bound for Israel, are going elsewhere, mainly to the United States.
In accordance with a newly developing practice, members of the House of Representatives held party caucuses last week, a full month in advance of next month's formal opening of Congress.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 11 (AP)--Linda Jefferson scored all Toledo's points, leading the Troopers to a 13-12 victory over the Oklahoma City Dolls for the championship of the National Women's Professional Football League.

Acting of any kind is difficult enough to judge rationally but film acting is the most illusive, being so dependent on things that have nothing to do with the talent or the craft or the intelligent options exercised by the actor. A good performance on the stage or screen can be shaped as much by what God gave the actor for a nose, ...
To judge from reports on the crowd response to the previous two bands, the headliner at Friday evening's white rhythm-and-blues bill at the Palladium was something of an anticlimax.
JOHANNESBURG--The moderates, black and white, who are trying to dismantle South Africa's system of racial separation through peaceful means arc losing ground to extremisis on both sides.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Dec. 11 (AP)--A border patrol in southern Thailand killed four Communist guerrillas and wounded several more yesterday in a clash 25 miles from the Malaysian border with a group belonging to the banned Communist Party of Malaya, Thai security officials said here today.
OPEN-HOUSING advocates in Bergen County have won what they describe as a major legal victory that affirms their right to challenge in court alleged racially segregated housing patterns in the county.

The good news in the corporate bond department is that prices have climbed to their highest levels in three years. The bad news is that some of the most valuable of that "paper"--namely, the high-yielding debentures of Bell System companies--is being called.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Dec. 11 (AP)-- Billy Kilmer, the Washington Redskins' quarterback, was arrested early today and charged with driving under the influence of alcohol, Virginia State Police reported.

MISSION, Kan., Dec. 11 (AP)--Attendance at the nation's major football playing colleges increased by 446,515 this year to a record high of 23,837,408, according National Collegiate Athletic Association findings.

We have before us two books on Russian history, both concerned with dramatic episodes of the Revolution: the Bolshevik seizure of power in October 1917, and the murder nine months later of the Imperial family. They are so different in approach and quality that it is almost embarrassing to have to review them under the same heading.

St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Bettina Clara Bryan, who graduated in January from Marymount Manhattan College, to Michael Sheldon Snyder, a second-year student at the Cornell Medical College. The Rev. James G. Munroe performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the Piping Rock Club.

LONDON, Dec. 11--Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and Foreign Secretary Anthony Crosland of Britain today concluded two rounds of strategy sessions aimed at breaking the deadlock in talks in Geneva on how to set up a black majority government in Rhodesia to replace the white-led regime of Ian D. Smith.
Jimmy Carter's victory in the 1976 Presidential contest was based in part on domestic economic concerns over inflation, unemployment and the "pause" in the economic recovery.

BERLIN, Dec. 11 (UPI)--Vera Krasnova of the Soviet Union today won the womens' 500-meter race at an invitation sprint skating meet in West Berlin. The Russian was clocked in 42.88 seconds to the 44.19, Haitske Pijlman of the Netherlands was second at 44:l9. Yevgeni Kulikov of the Soviet Union, a l976 gold medalist in the mens' 500 meters, took first place with a time of 34.04 seconds.

HOUSTON, Dec. 11--Capping the sport's busiest and richest year ever, Manuel Orantes of Spain will play Wojtek Fibak of Poland tomorrow afternoon for the $40,000 top prize in the Grand Prix Masters tennis tournament.

The conference rooms are hushed. The lines of chairs around the tables are as straight as toy soldiers. The corridors where adversaries huddled and caucused in whispers are no longer cluttered with people and cigarette butts. Outside the gates, where pickets marched when strikes broke out, the ping of time clock is heard.

MADRID, Dec. 11--Gunmen believed to be Basque militants today kidnapped Antonio Maria de Oriol y Urquijo, the staunchly conservative president of the advisory Council of State, taking him from his downtown Madrid office to an unknown location.

The English language contains over 600,000 words; a well-educated person knows about 20,000 of them in the course of reading and writing. But in the spoken language, fewer than 2,000 words account for 99 percent of what we say, and only 10 words make up 25 percent of all we have to say. (First comes I, then comes you.) And many oral communications are not credited with being "words" at all.
MICHAEL BLANEY drives a cab. Alison Corr is a secretary. Ric French sells lime. Arlene Garguilo is a dental assistant, Salvatore Davi makes ballet slippers. Jennifer Herring teaches music.

Mrs. Lytle Hull, the philanthropic grande dame of classical music who helped establish and support some of New York City's leading cultural institutions, died yesterday in Vassar Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., from postoperative complications following an accident. She was 83 years old.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 10 (AP)--Policemen used clubs and tear has today to disperse Arab youths demonstrating in the occupied West Bank town of Nablus against a new Israeli tax similar to a sales tax.
ROME, Dec. 11 (AP)--Tullio Abelli, a 55-year-old member of the Chamber of Deputies from the Neo-Fascist Italian Social Movement, jumped or fell to his death yesterday, the police said.

SEATTLE--A half-carat diamond ring priced at $312 sparkles in jeweler Ray Cox's hand. "I put out a small counter sign saying these rings were on sale for $229 recently. Within hours I sold my entire stock of eight rings to Canadians and could have sold more. They cost S550 in Canada," he said.
ODESSA, Tex., Dec. 11 (UPI)--Two former Fort Sill, Okla., soldiers were sentenced yesterday to death in the electric chair for the murder of a Texas highway patrolman.
MANILA, Dec. 11 (AP)--Unidentified gunmen opened fire on a bus taking three United States servicemen to work 60 miles north of Manila, wounding a seaman,authorities said today.

John Kinsella, a silver medalist in the 1968 Olympics and a gold medal victor in 1972, has been named the top professional marathon swimmer for 1976 by the World Professional Marathon Swimming Federation.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 11--Married women will be able to list their own first names alongside their husbands' names at no additional cost in telephone books in Wisconsin, the State Public Service Commission has ruled.

Andrei A. Amalrik, a dissident Soviet writer who caused a stir in the West in 1970 with a volume under the title "Will the Soviet Union Survive Until 1984?", has reluctantly reached the conclusion that the answer is "yes."

Rod Gilbert, who is as much a part of New York as Broadway, will be playing his 1,000th game as a New York Ranger tonight when the team meets the Montreal Canadiens at Madison Square Garden. No special observance is planned tonight, but the Rangers plan a Rod Gilbert "Night on Wednesday, March 9, when they play the Minnesota North Stars.

On the familiar theory that half a loaf is better than none, the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects is showing bits and pieces of buildings. "New York's Stepchildren" is a small exhibition of photographs of architectural ornament on about two dozen city owned structures--some of which are abandoned, and some of which are headed for sale or demolition.

Arthur Penn, director of "Bonnie and Clyde," that bloody film landmark of the 1960's, sat sipping a scotch and water on a New York-bound Metroliner, talking about why he was re turning to Broadway after ten years away.

Nothing has yet appeared this year to equal the monster volume of some Christmases ago that opened up to a spread of 3 feet. But this season's coffee-table literature covers as wide a range of subjects as ever, which can help to fill the blanks in the annual gift list-- provided you're ready to put out the money.
For Kenneth and Sally Wheeler of Warrenton, Va., a new day will dawn in three weeks.

Mr. and Mrs. Elmer L. Schemanski of Mikado, Mich., have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Lucy Ellen Schemanski, to Jonathan richards Durfee, son of Lieut. Comdr. Harold S. Durfee, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Durfee, of North Massapequa, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--The Department of Justice is tstudying the legality of Central Intelligence Agency electronic surveillance conducted during the last four years in Micronesia, a group of Pacific islands governed by the United States under a United Nations trusteeship, a department spokesman said today.

NEW JERSEY Democratic hopefuls have a unique love-hate relationship with Hudson County. They want the Demo cratic plurality that the area represents, but they fear the county's reputation for raising public corruption to the level of high art.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11--As the last lengths of pipe went into place this week for the Trans Alaska Pipeline, battle formations assembled for the most important pipeline tariff dispute since the Interstate Commerce Commission took jurisdiction in that field 40 years ago.

THIS is the time of year when all that you've read and heard about concerning the family and how it has changed all seems to come true. The holiday season. The kids, those who are away in college, are coming home and the tempo in the house has speeded up.
WEST TISBURY, Mass.--Through a rift in the dark clouds low in the west, shafts of light streamed, waned and disappeared, and even though sunset was more than an hour away, the day was suddenly dark.

CHIEF JUSTICE HUGHES, in addressing a Judicial Seminar on Sept. 10, announced his feeling that juveniles should, in some cases, be stripped of their protective mantle of anonymity. The Chief Justice singled out violent crimes and cases of "extensive vandalism" as examples of situations where public reporting of the juvenile offender's name should be allowed.

On what basis should the public lodge your performance? I guess the most important thing is in terms of the amount of money we've returned. The essential difference in this investigation and any other one I can think of is that ...

Susan Read and Edward W. Cronin Jr., Williams College graduates, will be married Dec. 20 in Katmandu, Nepal. The future bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Alexander D. Read of Peru, Vt. Her father is an artist and a former member of the New York Stock Exchange.

The first 1977 issue of the United States looks back to 200 years ago when the cause of the Revolution seemed desperate. It commemorates the gam ble Washington took that brought a decisive victory at the battle of Princeton. With this issue the U.S. Postal Service initiates an important modification in the procedure for acquiring first-day covers--do-it-yourself covers.

Historically, the northward thrust of commercial and industrial expansion in Manhattan has swept aside many of the residential areas in the "valley" that now lies between the skyscrapers of the downtown and midtown business districts.

In a highly uncharacteristic move, the State Commission on Correction has asked prison officials to justify the need for nearly one-fifth of a planned expenditure of $107 million for prison renovations.

The Spanish Socialist Workers Party last week held its first legal congress in Spain since 1932, and the event, an historic one in modern Europe, evoked the past and said much about the nation's present careful approach toward democracy.

The Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women held a conference last week that sought to involve college presidents in an effort to solve the educational, civil rights and financial problems facing women's sports ...

LONG BEACH is today at the crossroads of its future. As City Manager, I perceive that Long Beach can go in one of two di rections: either continue its current existence as a bedroom community, or seek to reachieve its former status as one of the foremost resort areas on the Northeast Coast.

If employees of the Forest Oil Carporation are working a bit harder these days, it may be because more than 150 of them, about 37 percent of Forest's work force, are being given an incentive seldom, if ever, offered by a publicly owned company.

MOSCOW, Dec. 11 (Reuters)--The Soviet Union's leading expert on the United States said today that a major priority for President-elect Jimmy Carter should be movement in the long-stalled strategic arms limitation talks, known as SALT.
On the night of Sept. 28, 1973, Peter Reilly, a young man--an 18-year-old boy, really--was arrested and charged with the murder of his mother, 51year-old Barbara Gibbons.

At a moment in our cultural life when the imperatives of formalism seem to be on the wane in the discussion, if not in the actual practice, of painting and sculpture, a vigorous restatement of the formalist position has come from a surprising quarter--from the world of photog raphy.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 (AP)--Rich Branning, a freshman, scored 4 points in the last 45 seconds to lead Notre Dame to a 66-63 basketball upset of the University of California, Los Angeles, at Pauley Pavilion today. U.C.L.A.'s Bruins led by 63-60 with six minutes to play but did not score again.

Last month in Rochester, the New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers approved a resolution at its 79th annual convention calling for the decriminalization of marijuana. The vote underscored the tact that changes are due in the traditional image of the P.T.A. as a social group whose activities used to be limited to gathering at monthly school meetings for coffee or tea.

Margaret Mary Cumming, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Cumming of Elizabeth, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Donald Evans Casciato of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominick Casciato of Somers Point, N.J.

A young lawyer became "totally frustrated in doing by the book" in efforts to get legal protection for battered wives and then conceived the idea of filing suit against the New York City Police Department and the administrative arm of the city's Family Court.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 11 (Reuters)-- Thirteen persons were killed today when a train slammed into the rear of a truck at a crossing near here. The police said that all the victims were aboard the truck, which was bringing back guests from a wedding party. Apparently the truck slipped around the barrier in an attempt to beat the train through the crossing.

A NYONE of an age to bring to mind, without too much prompting of the memory, the squeak of corduroy knickers can doubtlessly also recall easily how Gary Cooper, playing a Tennessee backwoodsman in a classic film of the 30's, sharpened his shooting skill by practicing on turkeys.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 11 (AP) --Thousands of cans of beef chunks destined for drought victims ended up on store shelves in Port-au-Prince earlier this year. But it wasn't because the poor didn't get the food.

TRENTON THE national Electoral College, which convenes once every four years to elect a President of the United States, has been labeled an anachronism by many political experts. But 17 New Jerseyans are looking forward to attending a session of the Electoral College tomorrow afternoon, even if it is anachronistic and despite the fact that they will be casting ballots for an also-ran-Gerald Ford.

Detroit is about to reconfirm its love affair with the Mercedes-Benz. Another cars in the growing family of American cars unabashedly patterned after the luxurious German automobile is being readied for a spring debut.
COLOMBO, SRI LANKA, Dec. 11 (Reuters)--Sri Lanka announced today it would give a year-old orphaned elephant called Shanti (Peace) to the United States to mark the Bicentennial.
ALBANY--A new regional economic development agency has been proposed for the 13 counties in and around the Adirondack Mountains, one of the most depressed areas of the state.

Andre Malraux died on November 23 shortly after completing his 75th year. He was still actively writing: the final volume of his vast "The Metamorphoses of the Gods" had come out, a short book on the same theme in literature was planned, the "Anti-Memoirs" were being extended, and "Picasso's Mask" had just been published in this country.

LAUREL, Md., Dec. 11 (AP)--What A Summer, the favorite, took the lead after the first sixteenth of a mile and won the $27,600 Anne Arundel Handicap by 3 lengths from Turn the Guns today at Laurel Race Course.

FOR the more than 11,000 doctors in the state, the decision by the Medical Society of New Jersey to form the first physi cian-owned medical malpractice insurance company in the state was the first step in an attempt to slow the ever-increasing costs of providing medical care.

THOMAS B. LANCE, President-elect Carter's choice to head the Office of Management and Budget, said he favors a $15 billion stimulatory package for the economy, consisting of tax cuts and Federal spending. Earlier, he said he believed a one-year tax rebate would be preferable to a permanent tax cut.

The Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity in Midland Park, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Marion Muriel Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David E. Jones of Ridgewood, N.J., to Lennart Gosta Petersson, son of Sonja Petersson of Vasteras, Sweden, and Gosta Petersson of Danderyd, Sweden.

Homeowners can cut down drmatically on the amount of water used for flushing toilets by installing a small gadget that fits into any standard flush tank. Called the Dual Flush, and manufactured by the Savway Company, 930 Clarkson Drive, Brooklyn N.Y. 11203, the device can be installed on the top edge of the tank with a screwdriver. What it does is create a two-part or dual-flushing system in a standard ...

Labor relations in professional sports moved into the big league of academe last week. The New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations at Cornell University devoted a special seminar to instructing its undergraduates, alumni and faculty in the intricacies of the Rozelle rule and other feudal hiring practices that have created full employment in recent years for a stadiumful of arbitrators, mediators and other experts in industrial jurisprudence.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 11 (UPI)--A federal judge has overturned former President Luis Echeverria Alvarez's expropriation of 250,000 acres of farmlands for peasants in the state of Sonora and has ordered the land returned to its former owners, it was announced today.

LIVINGSTON A VERY pleasant looking woman with a friendly smile approached me with a pencil in hand and said, "Would you like to taste-test some shrimp newburgh? Free." At that moment, 12:45 P.M. or so, I was prepared to pay the better part of $5 for some shrimp newburgh, so it was with great alacrity that I followed her.

More than 20,000 persons, many of them political dissidents, have disappeared or have been illegally executed in the last 10 years in Guatemala, according to Amnesty International, a humanrights organization.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 Waves of fear are washing over many portions of this city. Once-secure citizens say they are terrorized by the recent intrusion of violence into their formerly safe neighborhoods.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Some say Washington is a one-game town-politics. But it is really a two-game town. The other game is football, and it is much easier to understand.

DETROIT, Dec. 12 Eva M. McKellar's spacious home in this city's exclusive Palmer Woods area is not what most people would consider uninhabitable. But when she recently agreed to sell it for more than $62,000, the city sent an inspector who declared that her home did not meet local standards for livability.

Thousands of affluent shoppers and not-so-affluent window-shoppers thronged Fifth Avenue and the Upper East Side in a holiday mood yesterday, turning the thoroughfare into a festive mall as four major stores opened for the first time on a Sunday.

Greg Terhune scored two goals and added an assist and Greg Cassim had a goal and two assists as the New York Police Department's hockey team defeated the New York Fire Department's team, 4-2, before 7,528 fans yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

At a time of general cost inflation, New York City's spending on day-care programs has been reduced from an average of $74 a week a child last June 30 to $63 currently, according to the Agency for Child Development.

EAST ORANGE, Dec. 12 Rain did not dampen enthusiasm at the dedication of the Educational Improvement Center for northeast New Jersey here today. Neither did it halt a protest by 50 demonstrators against the state income tax outside the center.

The Beame administration, faced with a three-week deadline to show how it will balance the city's budget next year, has now identified some potential new savings that may soften the need for the drastic cuts in services that have been feared for the last several months.

WASHINGTON According to some of our best doctors, Mustafa Barzani, 73, leader of the Kurdish people, should have died of cancer about six months ago. On the assumption that his illness was terminal, and with the tacit understanding that he would not try to enlist public support for the Kurds in his waning days, General Barzani was permitted to undergo treatment here at the Mayo Clinic.

Rohr Industries, which experienced such heavy losses producing cars for San Francisco and Washington, D.C.'s rapid transit systems that it pulled out of the rail car business, suddenly blossomed in last week's stock market.

Union musicians went on strike against the New York City Ballet this morning for more money and work changes in a walkout that could cause a shutdown of the company for the holiday season.

HOLTON, Kan., Dec. 12 (AP) An early morning hotel fire, believed to have started in a divan, claimed five lives here today.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 12 (UPI) Officials concerned with agrarian reform said today that they were ready to enforce a court ruling ordering 8,000 peasants off land that they had occupied in the state of Sonora.

Kenneth R. Smith, a retired stockbroker who had been a naval aviator in both World Wars died yesterday in Community Hospital, Glen Cove, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived a 67 Wolver Hollow Road in Upper Brookville, L.I.

IBIZA, Dec. 12 (Reuters) Elmyr de Hory, reputed to be the world's best art forger, committed suicide yesterday here at his villa on this island in the Balearics because he faced almost certain extradition to France, the police said today. They reported that the Hungarian-born painter had died of an overdose of sleeping pills.

Contract negotiations between taxi fleet owners and union cab drivers continued early this morning, with the owners still threatening to charge each driver 5 cents for each gallon of gasoline used during his shift, beginning today, unless a settlement of the dispute was reached, or seemed to be near.
SOMERVILLE, Dec. 12 (AP) Potential tree thieves beware: There's going to be a real stink if you chop down a tree in Somerset County to decorate your home at Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Direct personal contact with ordinary voters was a deliberate hallmark of President-elect Jimmy. Carter's election campaign and even of his tenure as Governor of Georgia. But some of his own entourage fear that he is getting out of touch.

Melanie Beth Gordon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Gordon of Baldwin Harbor, L.I., was married at noon yesterday to Michael Bennett Garfinkle, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart Garfinkle of Rockville, Md. Rabbi A. David Arzt performed the ceremony at the Sands, Lido Beach, L.I.
Dozens of voters will go to the polls tomorrow in New York State's 920 independent fire districts to elect fire commissioners who will spend more than $50 million in tax monies next year.

Twenty books by living American authors published this year have been nominated for prizes in the second annual National Book Critics Circle Awards. Five books were seelcted in each of the four categories: fiction, nonfiction, poetry and criticism.

MADRID, Dec. 12 The identity of the kidnappers of the right-wing president of Spain's advisory Council of State, who was bundled out of his Madrid office by gunmen yesterday morning, remained in doubt today.

WASHINGTON Last spring an unusual combination of liberals and conservatives in Congress joined the Attorney General, Edward H. Levi, in a new approach to an Intractable old problem. WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) President-elect Jimmy Carter plans to name W. Michael Blumenthal, chairman of the Bendix Corporation, to be Secretary of the Treasury, according to sources close to Mr. Carter.

Under fire from students who charged that their education was "irrelevant," many college faculties and administrations in the turbulent 1960's beat a hasty retreat and abandoned most course requirements. The New York State Legislature will return to Albany next month to find an agenda filled with the same problems it confronted or, in some significant cases, failed to confront during the 1976 session, which ended five months ago.

Large cuts in city taxes on manufacturers to stop the economic erosion that has cost New York 500,000 factory jobs since 1950 were recommended yesterday by a commission appointed by Mayor Beame.

David Gilbert, assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic, led the orchestra in a subscription concert for the first time Saturday night. He did not make things easy for himself. The program he chose was Schumann's Second Symphony, which has built-in problems, and two rarely played pieces, Richard Strauss's "Macbeth" and Prokofiev's "Scythian Suite." "Macbeth" had never been performed by the Philharmonic.
PHILADELPHIA, Miss., Dec. 12 (AP) About 100 people stood through light rain today to dedicate a monument to three civil rights workers who were killed in June 1964.

Opera singers are traditionally presumed to make poor recitalists, but Martina Arroyo disproved if not actually reversed that theory yesterday afternoon at her Avery Fisher Hall concert by finding the recital stage even more suitable to her talents. Not that Miss Arroyo is ineffective on the opera stage her large, bright, excellently schooled soprano is a natural instrument for the dramatic Italian roles.

UTICA, Dec. 12 When the Chief of Police had the Mayor of Utica arrested last week, the Mayor suspended the Chief, threatened to shut the Police Department entirely and call in the National Guard. A New York Rangers victory over the Montreal Canadiens is about as plausible as a New York City budget surplus, but the Rangers brought off that miracle last night as they outhustled and routed the Canadiens, 5-2, before a frenzied capacity house of 17,500 in Madison Square Garden.
SINES, Portugal A few years back, honeymooners came to this isolated fishing village to sun on the deserted white sands, climb the dark rocky cliffs and see the house where Vasco da Gama was born.

PARIS, Dec. 12 The blight of jobless youth has fallen over Western Europe. As in the United States, it is school dropouts often from the least favored social strata, often with inadequate vocational training or an education mismatched with the needs of employers who are the hardest hit.

In what is considered a coup in network program competition, CBS-TV has won the rights to next September's telecast of "The Miss America Pageant," one of television's consistently high-rating winners. The band's recent burst of popularity top billing in stadium concerts, gold albums is the result of almost five years of incessant touring. Foghat has yet to become a New York favorite, but in the heartland the group's following is enormous.

Jerry Pate, winner of the United States Open, was honored yesterday as rookie of the year in golf and Billy Martin as rookie of the year in tennis. The designations were announced by two sister publications, Golf Digest and Tennis, at a luncheon at the 21 Club.

Melba Moore's concert at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sunday was a lavishly stylish affair, with animationlike visual effects on a screen and resourceful lighting changes complementing the music's moods. The Classic Stage Company, now in its 10th year, came up with something very special at its home, the Abbey Theater, on East 13th Street, on Sunday night. It was the first professional production of Jean Genet's "The Balcony" in New York for more than a decade. It was last performed in New York by the Circle-in-the-Square.

Among the victims of the littleknown young experts competing in the grand nationals at the New York Hilton Hotel Saturday were Marcel Friedmann, Alan Rich, Sudhakar Bhatt, Jay Mechutan and Jack Saltz. TRENTON, Dec. 13 The chief counsel to the State Legislature and the State Attorney General agreed today that the Senate President, Matthew Feldman, Democrat of Teaneck, was innocent of any "fraudulent, dishonest or corrupt conduct" when he paid money to a restaurant chain executive in 1974 and 1975 to win an exclusive liquor contract for his family's business.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 13 (AP) Authorities acknowledged today that at least three persons were killed near the end of a 1-1 soccer tie between Cuba and Haiti here two days ago.

DOHA, Qatar, Dec. 13 As oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries began arriving today for the crucial price-setting conference to open here Wednesday, Mohammed Sadli, OPEC's president, said that one "possible scenario" for OPEC would be to declare a small price increase at the conference and a larger one later.

HIS NIGHT Daniel Phillips, the 22-year-old American violinist, is tonight's performer at 8 o'clock in the Young Concert Artists series, playing a program ranging from Bach to a chaconne composed this year by Eugene Phillips. The place is the 92d Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. at Lexington Avenue. Tickets are $1.50 to $3.50.
LISBON, Dec. 13 Portugal's voters gave the minority Socialist Party Government a qualified vote of confidence in the local elections held yesterday, averting a crisis for this young democracy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 President- elect Jimmy Carter will name W. Michael Blumenthal, 50-year-old chairman and chief executive officer of the Bendix Corporation, to be the next Secretary of the Treasury, according to sources in the Carter camp.

Amid rumors that Ghana purchased more cocoa beans last week than anticipated from its farmers, cocoa futures dropped sharply yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. OF ALL THE AUTHORS, the biographer in-depth is the most optimistic, and the most surely doomed to failure. Who can ever know another human being? The biographer's self-imposed duty, however, is to do the impossible, to dive deep beneath the surface of appearances and return with another person in tow. It is enough to give one the bends just to think about the presumptuousness of such a mission.

Changes were made yesterday in chairmanships of major New York City Council standing committees, including the appointment of Edward L. Sadowsky, Democrat of Queens, as chairman of the powerful Finance Committee. The vote by the full Council was 35 to 3.

There was a surprise at the Theater of the Riverside Church last night. A surprise from Montreal. It was a small French-Canadian classic dance company called Entre-Six, and it was making its American debut.

A Federal judge ruled yesterday that New York City school authorities could not prevent a student editor at Stuyvesant High School from distributing a questionnaire about sex to junior and senior students at the school.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15?President-elect Jimmy Carter is prepared to announce three major appointments tomorrow?Charles L. Schultze as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Zbigniew Brzezinski as Special Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs, and Representative Andrew Young as the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, according to well-placed Carter sources.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 15 John Artis took the witness stand today in his second trial for triple murder and told the jury, as he had in his first trial in 1967, that he was innocent of the Lafayette Grill shootings.

DETROIT, Dec. 15 The American auto industry is scheduled to build a yearly high of 212,779 cars this week, up 2.7 percent from 207,133 last week, and 20.9 percent ahead of the 175,998 units built in the comparable year-ago week.

NEWARK, Dec. 15 Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson disclosed today an affirmative action plan aimed at ending municipal hiring discrimination and upgrading minority employees working in "dead end" city jobs.

PROVO, Utah, Dec. 15 Gary Mark Gilmore was sentenced today to be executed by a Utah firing squad on Jan. 17. Putting the execution date 33 days away displeased Mr. Gilmore, who, after vainly trying to persuade Judge J. Robert Bullock to set next Monday for the execution, called the judge a "moral coward." The convicted murderer said Judge Bullock lacked "the guts to carry out the law."

Prison officials in New York State are giving early parole consideration to 3,000 inmates in an effort to reduce overcrowding and make room for the many new prisoners coming into the prison system each month.

MADRID, Dec. 18--The kidnappers of the rightist president of the advisory Council of State disclosed tonight that they had "canceled" their decision to kill him in light of the Government's "vague" promise of an amnesty for political prisoners.

SENATOR JAMES P. DUGAN of Hudson County, the state Democratic chairman, recently envisioned a three-way primary contest for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination next year and said he could support any of the three he felt might run--State Senator Frank J. Dodd of Essex County, Mayor Paul Jordan of Jersey City or Joseph A. Hoffman, the former State Commissioner of Labor and Industry.

THEME restaurants can be off-putting, as anyone who has ever dined in a so-called Poly nesian place offering a simulated hurricane every hour can readily confirm. Fortunately, the 50 Yard Line confines its macho orientation to the murals of famous stadiums, a display of assorted gridiron trophies and some silly titles on the menu.

An acting State Supreme Court justice and the city's special narcotics prosecutor have been accused of conspiring to supply false information to a grand jury to obtain an indictment that would make a government informer appear to be a criminal and thereby insure his safety.

HONG KONG, Dec. 18--China today confirmed reports from unofficial Chinese sources that a major charge against Chiang Ching and three other disgraced members of the Communist Party Politburo is that they reworded a critical quotation by Mao Tse-tung to make it appear they alone were to be left in control after his death.

It was a foregone conclusion that Spanish voters would endorse overwhelmingly the Government's plan to hold free elections for a new democratic Parliament next spring. There was, nonetheless, something exhilarating about the 75 percent turnout in Wednesday's referendum and the 94 percent approval for the program advanced by King Juan Carlos and Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez for dismantling the authoritarian system of Francisco Franco.

ORADELL A GIFT of music for Christmas has been presented by the choirs of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in this Bergen County community in the form of a stereophonic recording containing 13 religious songs performed by the choirs during the year.
ALBANY, Dec. 18 (UPI)--Loss of binding arbitration as a negotiating tool could "adversely affect the cause of labor peace" between policemen and municipalities, a state policemen's group said today.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Day of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., of the engagement of their daughter, Shirley Susan Day, to Robert W. Harrell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Harrell of Portsmouth, Va.

HONG KONG--When the Communists ruling North Vietnam held their last party congress 16 years ago, they approved plans to fight for control of the South while at the same time building socialism in the North. With the divided nation now one after a protracted and devastating war, the Vietnam Workers Party met again in Hanoi last week to make final a new socialist course for North and South.

If it is true that house plants react to the mood of their environment, as some far-out experiments have suggested, the next philodendron you buy may need comforting. It will be uneasy if it has acquired a sense of its business future.

THE recent explosion at a chicle factory in New York City turned out to be a successful baptism of fire for an innovative burn-treatment network devised by a former electronics company executive. The network, which was established just five months earlier by the National Burn Victim Foundation in Orange, was able to quickly place 27 of the 52 New York blast victims in hospitals in New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

Forty-four percent of the American public would like the Government to reimpose wage and price controls, according to the latest Gallup poll. Forty-one percent of those questioned said they opposed such controls and 15 percent had no opinion.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 18--In an old house in New Orleans that is laden with vines lives a rich, eccentric inventor 99 years old, who once had in his possession a fortune. But one evening the fortune mysteriously disappeared.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 18--The editorial offices and printing facilities of another Lebanese newspaper were occupied last night by Syrian troops in the Arab League's peacekeeping force.

ROME, Dec. 18--Giovanni Agnelli, who is one of Italy's best-known personalities and runs its most famous company, is once again dominating the headlines, the covers of the weekly picture magazines and the conversation here.

IRVING, Tex., Dec. 18--Are the Los Angeles Rams ready for the playoffs? And are the Dallas Cowboys? Both teams presented questions here today as they got set for tomorrow's fourth and last National Football League division playoff game in Texas Stadium. This one will have a late start and CBS anticipates a national television audience of perhaps 30 million. The game will be televised in New York on Channel 2 beginning at 5:30 P.M., E.S.T.

Mary Elizabeth McDade, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Hardinge McDade Jr. of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married last evening in Scarsdale, N.Y., to George Leonard Anderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Anderson of Chicago. The Rev. Francis T. O'Malley performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church.

The heritage of the Middle Ages, when every form of artistic endeavor was devoted to the celebration and veneration of Christi anity, has been evoked as the dominant theme of many 1976 Christmas stamps from around the world.
When the Colts meet the hottest team in the National Football League today, the Pittsburgh Steelers, will they be seeing dark images of last year's game?

In this era of retrenchment in Wall Street, a thriving investment house is exceptional, and one that earns a steady 25 percent or more on its capital is as scarce as a stockbroker without a buy recommendation.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 18--Gen. Va Nguyen Giap, Vietnam's Defense Minister and the nation's senior military tactician, said in Hanoi today that its leaders still intended to emphasize human needs despite the vast plans for the overall economic and political development of the country already presented by the leadership.

LONDON--More than nine years ago, on a visit to Montevideo, I wrote: "Contemporary England ... might well take a long southwesterly look at Uruguay while murmuring; 'There but for the grace of God go I.' For Uruguay is the welfare state gone wild ... the system maximizes rights of the citizen and minimizes his obligations ... pragmatic socialism knows that charity costs money--and now the bill has been presented."
Ann Ferrell, Bloomingdale's advertising copy chief, was married yesterday afternoon to Jonathan Rinehart, founder and head of the Jonathan Rinehart Group Inc., public-relations-counseling concern.

SPRINGFIELD SUCCESS hasn't spoiled Sidney Frank. It has merely bemused him slightly. "I know I'm good at what I do, but whenever I make a couple of dollars, it's always a surprise," says the one-time businessman turned playwright, historian, author, humorist, songwriter and New Jersey trivia specialist.
CAIRO, Dec. 18--The sixth annual Nile International Rowing Festival will get under way tomorrow with the arrival of the University of Paris, the French entry.

Between the paintings that an artist produces in his lifetime and the way they come to be characterized and "seen" by posterity there are often--perhaps more often than not-- some remarkable discrepancies, Take the case of Ernest Lawson (1873-1939), whose paintings are currently the subject of a comprehensive exhibition at the A.C.A. Galleries, 25 East 73d Street.

PARIS--When Romain de Tirtoft arrived in Paris at age 18, despite his family's outraged objections, he managed to get a designer's job at what he now calls a "thoroughly second-rate fashion house" named Caroline.

EVERGREEN boughs have long been associated with the winter festivals of man. Their evergreen leaves represented a continuing thread of life during the dreary, dead days of winter and gave assurance that nature would again come alive in the spring.

WASHINGTON--While the nation is making good progress is reducing pollution, the Carter administration faces a formidable array of environmental problems, according to the man who has had chief responsibility, for grappling with them.

St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, Woodsville, N.H., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Regina Marie Boudreault, daughter of Mrs. H. Edward Moses of North Haverhill, N.H., and the late Patrick Boudreault, to John David Pitcher, son of Mr. and Mrs. David E. Pitcher Jr. of East Norwich, N.Y. The Rev. Roger P. Bilodeau performed the ceremony.

A 12-year-old boy died last night in a two-alarm fire in his family's one family house in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. The dead boy was identified by the police as Richard Guzowski of 1325 Albany Avenue, near Avenue D.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 18--Justice Department investigators concluded at a meeting this week that their inquiry into alleged influence-buying by the South Korean Government had reached the point where they should end their "vacuum cleaner-type" gathering of information and begin focusing on possible prosecutions, according to sources close to the case.
BOBIGNY, France, Dec. 16--For 40 hours a week Ren Santraine sells windows and doors, hustling around the Paris suburbs and earning $175 a week.

ROBERT GEMSON, an English teacher at East Meadow High School, took one last look around the lobby at his stu dents, who were dressed like Chubby Checker, the Andrews sisters, Groucho Marx and Fanny Brice.

Anne Lane Ferguson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Troy Ferguson Jr., was married yesterday to Harry Randall Leach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph F. Leach. Both families are of Bronxville, N.Y., where the Rev. Charles L. Copenhaver performed the ceremony in the Reformed Church.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Barr Deans Jr. of Mill Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Lucy Colson Deans, to David Robinson Lamb, son of Carol Lamb of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Stephen B. Lamb of Port Villa, New Hebrides.

This evening at 9, the terribly urbane, witty and brilliant amateur detective Lord Peter Wimsey leaves his expensively decorated London flat for a holiday in the hills of Scotland. Of course, no holiday for Lord Peter and his right-hand man, ...

The F-16 has been described as the first jet fighter to incorporate space-age technology. It is lightweight--22,000 pounds--and highly maneuverable, and has a combat radius of 500 miles. The plane's Pratt Whitney turbofan engine produces 25 percent more thrust per pound of engine than previous fighter engines.

PEKING, Dec. 17--One of the most active organizations in China these days is the international liaison department of the Chinese Communist Party. It is telling Maoist parties around the world that China did not forsake leftist purity when it threw Mao Tse-tung's widow and her associates into jail in October.

The Gray Line of San Francisco offers a tour of the Napa Valley Wine Country, but Gray Line was on strike. So we rented a car and, armed with a free guidebook to "California's Wine Wonderland" from the Wine Institute, we did it ourselves: seven wineries in nine hours, with tastings at five of them, all of which took some doing, some driving and some drinking.

At the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Westbury, L.I., yesterday, Diane McCarthy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William McCarthy 2d of Westbury, was married to John Tobey Devlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Devlin of Ramsey, N.J. The Rev. Herbert H. Beardsley performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. John Mallone, a Roman Catholic priest.
The Henry Hudson Parkway between 72d and 81st Streets will be reopened to six lanes of traffic next Tuesday, after a 15-month, $10.67 million reconstruction.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 19 Tony Trabert, captain of the United States team, has official Davis Cup uniforms for Jimmy Connors and Harold Solomon, complete with blazers and warmup suits that have their names on the back.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 19 (AP) Zambia announced today that it had suspended relations with the wing of Rhodesia's African National Council led by Bishop Abel Muzorewa.

What's the difference between $1,000 and $10,000? Just an extra 0. Less than one might suppose, If the money is to be spent on decorating an apartment, according to some of Manhattan's foremost practitioners of the art.
LONDON, Dec. 19 (Reuters) World wheat and rice production has kept well ahead of the population explosion since World War II, according to figures released by the International Wheat Council.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 19 Many of the 60,020 spectators had departed long before the Pittsburgh Steelers completed their 40-14 victory.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 Presidentelect Carter has decided to nominate a fellow Georgian, Griffin B. Bell, a former Federal appellate judge, to be Attorney General, sources close to Mr. Carter said today.

MADONNA Di CAMPIGLIO, Italy, Dec. 19 (AP) Fausto Radici, blind in one eye, competed in a heavy snowfall today and won the men's World Cup ski special slalom, leading the Italian team to a 1, 2, 3 sweep.
SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain At the soccer match with Bilbao, a San Sebastian player suddenly unfolded the ikurrunia the outlawed red, white and green Basque flag and the stands erupted in jubilation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 The former vice chairman of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, A. Carl Kotchian, who was a central figure in the Lockheed scandal in Japan, has asserted that the bribes his company paid in that country were all requested by Japanese, not offered by Lockheed.

Alice Chase Edmunds, a freelance writer, was married yesterday at her home in Greenwich Village to Henry Richard Kaufman, legal counsel to the Association of American Publishers. Rabbi Dennis Math performed the ceremony.

MANILA, Dec. 19(AP) An F-14 Tomcat the most advanced type of American fighter plane plunged into the South China Sea today after missing a landing aboard the carrier Enterprise, a Navy spokesman here reported.

The New York Cocoa Exchange is planning to join the trend toward offering trading in options based on futures contracts, it announced last week. However, the Cocoa Exchange's proposed options would be traded along side futures on the trading floor through open auction and not by bid-and-ask quotations, as is the case with the new silver and copper options.

THERE WAS NOTHING very subtle about the Metropolitan Opera's "Tosca" Saturday night, the first performance of the season. It was sung to the hilt by the three principals, who took a broad, sock-it-to-'em approach to the opera that left the fans cheering.

The new teachers' contract will cut first-year costs to the New York City Board of Education from an originally negotiated $43 million to $20 million, Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, said yesterday.

Some instrumentalists shape their interpretations to conform to their technical abilities and others just plow ahead, leaving the audience to glimpse a fully realized conception through a veil of digital betrayals.

BACK in the early days of World War II, when G.I.'s were being paid $21 a day (but only once a month), F. N. Clapper somehow managed to scrape together $1,800. Just before being shipped overseas, he tucked the money into an account at the North River Savings Bank in Manhattan.

Lina Prokofiev sat in front of the picture window overlooking Chicago's wintry lakefront and fingered through more than half a century of memories, selecting one now and then to share with her visitor. Now 79 years old, she spoke about the first time she, a young Spanish singer living in New York, saw Serge Prokofiev, a virtually unknown young composer from the Ukraine. "It was at Carnegie Hall in December 1919.

WASHINGTON AMERICAN BALLET THEATER, in the midst of a completely sold-out month's season at the Kennedy Center, is featuring, in addition to Mikhail Baryshnikov's new version of "The Nutcracker," to have its premiere tomorrow, a slightly revised version of its production of "The Sleeping Beauty."
