In its weeklong engagement at Alice Tully Hall, the Salzburg Marionettes have been concentrating on the presentation of fairy tales, ideal holiday fare for children. On Tuesday night, they gave the first of the three opera performances that were scheduled and ended up with another fairy tale. This was "The Magic Flute," raised by Mozart's music to the realm of high art, but still filled with the fantasy and illusion that appeal to the young.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 29 (AP)-- Rudolph George Perpich became Governor of Minnesota today when Gov. Wendell R. Anderson stepped down to take the Senate seat being vacated by Vice President-elect Walter F. Mondale.

LAWRENCEVILLE, Dec. 29--Two hundred high school students have spent the last three days analyzing the United States Constitution at a Youth Constitutional Convention here, and the teen-age delegates seem agreed that the document needs no drastic changes.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 29 (AP)--Darryl Sittler rammed in two goals and a defenseman, Borje Salming, got a goal and three assists as the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Cleveland Barons, 6-2, in an N.H.L. game tonight.

Nicholas Scoppetta, the city's new Deputy Mayor for Criminal Justice, proposed yesterday a system of evaluating individual police officers that would include such data as how many of their arrests ultimately resulted in convictions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--A bitter dispute has broken out among the leaders of American Jewish organizations over whether American Jews should have any contact with representatives of the Palestine Liberation Organization, given the Israeli Government's refusal to deal with that group.

Prince Alexander Ratibor lives in a 746-year-old, 35-room castle in Stuttgart, West Germany. His dual professional career as a veterinarian and agricultural engineer blends with his avocation for breeding Leonbergers, and showing French bull- dogs on the continent. Whether he's participating as a judge or exhibitor or spectator, the prince is at home in any country as long as he's at a dog show.
The Brooklyn Democratic organization has endorsed former City Councilman Howard Golden for Brooklyn Borbugh President to succeed Sebastian Leone, who resigned to become a State Supreme Court Justice.

HAYSVILLE, Kan., Dec. 29 (AP)-- Police marksmen shot and killed a former mental patient tonight, ending an eighthour ordeal that began when he took a woman and four children hostage at gunpoint in their home in this suburb of Wichita.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--Cyrus R. Vance, the Secretary of State-designate, has virtually assembled his high-level staff, combining some new faces, former and present Foreign Service officers and at least four key aides to Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 29--Unranked Providence College scored a stunning, double-overtime upset over top-ranked Michigan tonight in the final of the first Industrial National Classic.

VOYAGE. By Sterling Hayden. 700 pages. Putnam. $12.95. Sterling Hayden's "Voyage" is the sort of book some critic is certain to call a "blockbuster," but I believe that this particular block has already been busted beyond repair. "Epic" novels of the sea are generally foul weather in fiction, and "Voyage" is not responsive to the helm. I always liked Mr. Hayden as an understated actor, but as a writer he is a terrible ham.

GLOUCESTER CITY, N.J., Dec. 29--A three-state bird rescue operation was set up today by Federal wildlife officials to save hundreds of ducks and geese covered with oil from a tanker spill in the Delaware River two days ago.

Arthur G. Reichert of 32 Harriet Lane, Huntington, L.I., who retired in 1974 as a partner in Quigley Reichert, a real estate and general insurance firm in Northport, died yesterday morning in Huntington Hospital after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

WASHINGTON--The coming to power of an elected President with a Congress controlled by his own political party offers an unparalleled opportunity to bring an end to lawbreaking by the intelligence and police agencies of the Federal Government.

The 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund passed the $600,000 mark yesterday with the receipt of $l1,698.14 from 200 donors. The overall figure for the campaign, which is in its fourth week and will continue through February, now stands at $609,613.32.

Byron Dyce, home on vacation from his doctoral studies at the University of Florida, ran his first competitive race of the indoor season last night and won the half-mile event in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union's development meet.

In a stinging four-page letter, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday accused the deputy schools chancellor, Bernard R. Gifford, of dishonesty, demagoguery and bad faith for his questioning of the accuracy of the Comptroller's figures for layoffs at the Board of Education.

NEWARK, Dec. 29--Although no garbage was collected in residential neighborhoods for the fourth straight day today, some of the striking public works employees began going back to their jobs in response to calls from their union leaders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2--The Congressional Budget Office suggested today that the Army was buying the wrong type of helicopter and planning to form the wrong kind of division if it is expected to fight a short, intense war in Europe.

Credit markets continued to show a firm tone in quiet trading yesterday. The Government securities sector was buoyed during the afternoon after the Federal Reserve injected permanent reserves into the banking system by purchasing Treas ury coupons.

About 150 young women are likely to dance the Sugarplum Fairy in various productions of "The Nutcracker" this season, but one must count Mar- tine van Hamel's as a special treat. She appeared with Adam Luders as her cavalier in the Eglevsky Ballet's production Tuesday evening at the Nassau Coliseum. The arena is scarcely the ideal setting for the ballet, but judicious curtains and lighting framed the production warmly, and the company did the rest.

BUCHAREST, Rumania--Just a few hours before he greeted Leonid I. Brezhnev at Bucharest's airport, President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania made time to see another visitor, Secretary of Commerce Elliot L. Richardson.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29 (AP)--Ron Schock's sixth goal of the season, scored from the edge of the crease early in the final period, gave the Pittsburgh Penguins a 3-3 tie with the Montreal Canadiens in a National Hockey League game tonight.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 29--Topseeded Carlos DiBrito of Brazil led the way into the semifinals of the New York State men's indoor tennis championship today at the Cove Racquet Club.

SAN FRANCISCO--Joseph Malandra stood on the corner of Vallejo Street and pointed up Grant Street to the big neon signs dominating the busy avenue of small shops. "That's what I object to, neon signs with block lettering that are completely out of character with the OldWorld feeling of this neighborhood, said Mr. Malandra, a young law- yer with offices above a nearby saloon.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 28--The breakup of marriage is often depicted as a traumatic experience for the wife and as a release for the husband, who supposedly longs for the freedom of his bachelor days.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--The Civil Aeronautics Board said today it was proceeding to consider applications by two corporations to offer low-cost service to and from Chicago's Midway Airport in a case the board says is "unique" and could have far-reaching consequences for both domestic air transportation and the problem of service at Midway.
Walter Young, a painter and art teacher, died Saturday at his Lake Katonah home in Golden's Bridge, N.Y., after suffering a stroke. He was 70 years old.

ALBANY Dec. 29--Governor Carey warned today that the City University's "Mobilization," the public relations effort designed to forestall budget cuts, "shouldn't develop into a resistance movement to jar the city out of a balanced budget."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--The Administation of President Lyndon B. Johnson prepared briefly to intervene in Brazil with naval and airborne units in 1964 to prevent leftist forces from seizing power in the wake of an expected miliary coup, according to recently released documents and to the former United States Ambassador, Lincoln Gordon.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 (AP)--The Argo Merchant carried an "unusual" complement of three port-based repairmen when she ran aground two weeks ago off Nantucket, attorneys for Cape Cod fisher- men said yesterday.

TRENTON, DEC. 29--The state today settled out of court a $61.7 million antitrust suit it had brought against 15 individuals, including Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel, and 12 companies accused of conspiring to rig highway bids in New Jersey from 1957 to 1970.

MIAMI, Dec. 29--Having said earlier this week that he could live with Jimmy Carter and without girlie magazines, Woody Hayes found another target for his verbal punches today--athletic scholarships based on need.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--The Federal energy research agency said today that "solar heating can now compete economically" with electricity in the heating of newly built, well-insulated, one-family houses in New York and at least 12 other cities.

Nicholas Scoppetta, the city's new Deputy Mayor for Criminal Justice, proposed yesterday a system of evaluating individual police officers, that would include such data as how many of their arrests ultimately resulted in convictions.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Dec. 29 (AP)--The burial of Senator Philip A. Hart took place at noon today in a snowy, wooded cemetery on this tiny island, which he called home.

WASHINGTON--Will Frank G. Zarb punt? With only two weeks and three days to the Jan. 15 effective date of his resignation, Mr. Zarb has the oil industry and his own staff wondering whether he will follow through on a major regulatory idea he floated or whether he will play it safe and turn the ball over to the Carter administration.

Dr. Eugene F. Russell, who retired in l942 as a vice president of Mutual Life Insurance Company in New York City, died yesterday in Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 91 years old.

Alexander Schneider and his New York String Orchestra paid homage last night to Pablo Casals, who was born Dec. 29 a century ago, and whose postWorld War II career in Prades and Puerto Rico was intimately linked with that of Mr. Schneider.

KONYA, Turkey--The pilgrims shuffle slowly into the green-domed mausoleum, the mud of their fields still clinging to their plastic shoes. When they reach the sarcophagus, they raise their hands chest high, palms up, and begin to murmur the old prayers. Some try to kneel on the brightly patterned prayer rugs, but the guard usually stops them. Officially, the building is now a museum, and devotion cannot be too obvious.

Mollie Silverstein, a former high school teacher of business courses, died yesterday at Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park, L.I. She was 69 years old and lived at 226-14 137th Avenue, Quens.

ATLANTA, Dec. 29--A group of expert advisers to the Federal Government today recommended continuing the present moratorium on influenza vaccinations because of the possible risk of a rare form of paralysis called Guillain-Barre Syndrome.

Picketing and demonstrations, political pressure and the raising of money from West 86th Street landlords to press lawsuits will be required to reverse the move by Bridge Inc. into the Brewster Hotel, but "what is done can be undone," nearly 200 residents of the street were told at a meeting last night.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 29 (UPI)-- Three Americans, including Hank Pfister of California, reached the quarterfinals of the $100,000 New South Wales grass tennis championships today.
PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Dec. 29--New York State will soon acquire a 1,300-acre area of beaches, dunes and rare wetlands on Long Island's South Fork.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--The Government's composite indexes of leading indicators and coincident indicators of the economy both rose in November, the Commerce Department reported today, giving a further signal that the summer and early autumn pause in the economy has given way to renewed expansion.
Belly dancing would be one name for most of what was on view Tuesday night in an offbeat program at the Hudson Guild Theater, 441 west 26th Street.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 29--The publication of documents relating to the role of the United States Government before the 1964 right-wing military coup in Brazil has led to a flurry of protests by Brazilian politicians who were unfavorably protrayed.
CANNES, France, Dec. 29 (UPI)-- Princess Andree, a former wife of the late Aga Khan, died today in Cannes, family sources said. She was 70 years old.

Marion Rombauer Becker, co-author of the best-selling "The Joy of Cooking," died Tuesday night of cancer at Holmes Hospital in Cincinnati, where she lived. She would have been 74 years old next Sunday.

I. W. Abel, the retiring president of the United Steelworkers of America, pledged yesterday to campaign in "the plants, the mines, the mills, the factories and the shops" for Lloyd McBride as his successor against the insurgent challenger Ed Sadlowski, who, he said, was "the cocktail party candidate for president of our union."

The discovery of a major urban civilization that rose in northern Syria 4,400 years ago and rivaled its only contemporaries, Mesopotamia and Egypt, is being acclaimed as one of the most significant archeological advances of the century.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--The Federal energy research agency said today that "solar heating can now compete economically" with electricity in the heating of newly built, well-insulated, one-family houses in New York and at least 12 other cities.

Working under a Congressional deadline, the Financial Accounting Standards Board yesterday set next March 20 for public hearings to begin on accounting standards for oil and gas producers and other extractive industries.
Some astute individuals are earning extra income by paying large bills with checks written against their interestbearing money-market fund investments.

Solomon Zeitlin, a scholar who found himself uncomfortable in majorities and immovable as a party of one, died in Philadelphia Tuesday of heart failure. He was 84 by his count, 88 or 91 by the count of Dropsie University, where he taught.

TRENTON, (UPI)--Dec. 29--The State Department of Community Af fairs is attempting to find buyers for abandoned railroad properties. Federal law gives governmental agencies preference on the properties.

Jenny Charnay Maybruck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles N. Maybruck of New York, was married in Stamford, Conn., yesterday to Andrew Francis Besch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Besch of Bedford Hills, N. Y. Rabbi Philip Schecter performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ochs Sulzberger. Their daughter, Cathy Sulzberger, was matron of honor, Jeff Lieberman was best man.

ST. SIMONS ISLAND, Ga., Dec. 29-- President-elect Carter concluded a series of meetings with his future Cabinet and other major advisers today, announced more meetings for next week to fashion the outlines of an economic recovery program and, in effect, confirmed that it was uncertain that his administration would seek a reduction in defense spending.

TRENTON, Dec. 29--The State Supreme Court indicated today by an unusual request that it might be nearing a ruling on whether State Senator Stephen B. Wiley of Morris Township might take his place on the court.

On opening night at "Fiddler on the Roof" Tuesday, there was no mistaking the billing: It was Zero Mostel above and beyond the title. The evening was, first of all, a celebration for the actor. And when the curtain fell, it was Mostel, solo, who received a standing ovation.

PIONEER, Ohio--Roger Herrett, a state forest service officer in the northwestern part of Ohio for some 17 years, is not one who gets easily excited over a new tree story. He thought he had heard them all.
BARCELONA, Spain, Dec. 29--Three years after his death in self-imposed exile in Puerto Rico, the memory of Pablo Casals was honored today in his beloved Catalonia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--A bitter dispute has broken out among the leaders of American Jewish organizations over whether American Jews should have any contact with representatives of the Palestine Liberation Organization, given the Israeli Government's refusal to deal with that group.

Coast Guard pollution-control officers said yesterday that no capability existed in the technology for control of oil spill that could cope with a calamitous spill in a storm. They cited the discharge of 7.5 million gallons of oil from the Argo Merchant, which broke up last week off Nantucket, Mass.
PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 29--Motions for a third trial for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis were filed today at the Passaic County Courthouse here.

SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 29--The South Korean Court of Appeals ruled today that a former opposition presidential candidate had properly been convicted of anti-Government activities for demanding the resignation of President Park Chung Hee, but it reduced the defendant's sentence from eight years to five.

GLOUCESTER CITY, N.J., Dec. 29--A three-state bird rescue operation was set up today by Federal wildlife officials to save hundreds of ducks and geese covered with oil from a tanker spill in the Delaware River two days ago.

Spokesmen for the Unification Church yesterday described as "hysterical" and "malicious" criticisms made Tuesday by Christian and Jewish leaders of the movement, which is led by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29, (AP)--The Federal Bureau of Investigation found hundreds of secret Central Intelligence Agency documents in the home of a retired C.I.A. employee charged with trying to sell documents to the Soviet Union, according to an inventory the bureau filed with a Federal magistrate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)--The State Department said today that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger had stored the transcripts of his telephone conversations while in office at the private New York estate of Vice President Rockefeller.
A 50-cent service charge on creditcard users, imposed earlier this year by Citibank has come under attack by Leonard Lapidus, acting New York State Superintendent of Banks.

RIO DE JANEIRO--In Brazil--and throughout the developing world--a growing discontent and sense of crisis have emerged over the sharp oil price increases decreed by the Organization of Oil Exporting Countries.

HARTFORD, Dec. 29--Dominick J. DeLucco, who rose from newspaper boy and dump-cart driver to election as the first Italian-American Mayor of Hartford, died yesterday at the State Veterans' Home and Hospital in Rocky Hill, where he had lived for eight months. He was 81 years old.

BOSTON, Dec. 29--In 1966 the Georgia House of Representatives refused to seat Julian Bond, a newly elected black member. The reason was his endorsement of a statement by the Student Non-violent Coordinating Committee criticizing the war in Vietnam and sympathizing with men who resisted the draft for service there.

An 82-year-old woman was shoved into her lower East Side apartment as she turned her key in the lock early yesterday afternoon, punched in the face, threatened with a knife and robbed of more than $350 by a man the police believe had also attacked two women in their 80's early last week.
For 364 days a year, the employees of Zabar's serve the customers of the West side delicatessen, but once a year they are the guests at a party in their honor.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP)--The pound gained more than a half cent to $1.7065 on the London foreign exchange market yesterday, reaching its highest level since late September.

ORANGE, France, Dec. 29 (AP)--Ivo Van Damme of Belgium, winner of two silver medals in track at the recent Olympics, was fatally injured today in a car crash while traveling from the Riviera to Paris.

A 32-year-old convicted felon was being held yesterday following his indictment on charges that he had abducted a 14year-old Long Island girl, raped and otherwise sexually abused her in a midtown hotel over a period of three days, and had then attemped to turn her into a prostitute.
MOSCOW, Dec. 29--Soviet dissident activity has risen in recent months, bringing a series of government countermeasures.

Darryl Eady, Dino Larry and 32 free throws put Manhattan College into the final round of the Holiday Festival basketball tournament last night before a disappointing Madison Square Garden crowd of 7,102.
New Yorkers were warned yesterday not to purchase or use "for any purpose" a silicone caulking sealant made by General Electric, because of possible hazards from the arsenic compound it contained.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)--Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today gave John N. Mitchell and H. R. Haldeman 29 extra days to appeal to the Supreme Court their convictions for conspiracy, obstruction of justice and perjury in the Watergate case.

Labor leaders and bankers said yesterday that they were pleased with President-elect Carter's new assurances about New York City, but that many additional questions had to be answered before they could agree to a plan to redeem nearly $1 billion in city short-term notes.
Early in 1977, Britain's Royal Navy will deploy five small warships as the first step toward military protection of the North Sea oil and gas fields.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--The Government's composite indexes of leading indicators and coincident indicators of the economy both rose in November, the Commerce Department reported today, giving a further signal that the summer and early autumn pause in the economy has given way to renewed expansion.

GINGER'S OWN Television viewers enjoying this week's festival of Fred Astaire-Ginger Rogers musical movies have a bonus in store in the form of a rare theatrical revival of "Kitty Foyle" (1940) coupled with "Roxie Hart" (1942) tomorrow through Sunday at the Theater 80 St. Marks (254-7400).
The New York City Council is expected to approve next Wednesday nine nominees for an independent, nonpartisan commission to draw new Council lines for the 1977 elections.

A group of American antiwar activists said yesterday that they had been rebuffed by Vietnamese authorities after months of efforts to persuade Hanoi to release political prisoners and to accept an impartial inquiry into charges of violations of human rights.

Capt. Georgios Papadopoulos testified yesterday that his oil tanker, the Argo Merchant, lacked an up-to-date chart for the currents near Nantucket Island when the ship ran aground and poured 7.5 million gallons of oil into the Atlantic.

Hazel Hardy, a publications executive with the American Broadcasting Compaanies Inc., died Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital at the age of 32. Mrs. Hardy whose home was in Ossining, N.Y., had been ill for several months with cancer.
The stock market ignored some favorable economic news yesterday as profit taking weakened the list and sent the Dow Jones industrial average below the 1,000 level at the close.

BOSTON--Tom Kelly has been a believer in Columbia-Savin Hill, a neighborhood in Boston's Dorchester section. But now he says his faith is shaky. After sinking $17,000 into improvements in his three-family house over the last two years, he is having second thoughts about his investment.

The 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund passed the $600,000 mark yesterday with the receipt of $11,698.14 from 200 donors. The overall figure for the campaign, which is in its fourth week and will continue through February, now stands at $609,613.32.

On opening night at "Fiddler on the Roof" Tuesday, there was no mistaking the billing: It was Zero Mostel above and beyond the title. The evening was, first of all, a celebration for the actor. And when the curtain fell, it was Mos- tel, solo, who received a standing ovation.

An independent study of the international supply situation in seven critical commodities, for which the United States depends heavily on foreign sources, finds optimistically that the likelihood of damage from supply interruptions in all but one--chromite--is small.

Anne van Munching Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo van Munching of Greenwich, Conn., and Bal Harbour, Fla., was married yesterday evening to James F. Ryan, a widower of Old Greenwich, Conn. He is the son of the late Dr. Joseph P. Ryan, a physician, of Hartford, and the late Mrs. Chester M. Curry of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the American Hospital Supply Corporation submitted to Saudi Arabian demands that it pay millions of dollars in questionable fees for contracts to equip the ultramodern King Faisal Specialist Hospital ih Riyadh, the Saudi capital.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29--George W. Dunne, long a member of Richard J. Daley's inner circle, was chosen today to succeed the late Mayor as chairman of the Cook County Democratic Central Committee, the organization through which the Daley machine functioned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--The Carter camp found itself in a minor to-do tonight over what various spokesmen sought to treat as a premature and possibly, though not necessarily, inaccurate disclosure of several major White House staff appointments by a senior transition aide.
WASHINGTON--The Fourth Annual Office Pool, pitting reader against pundit, is offered herewith.

As Alex Rose lay dying Monday night, his secretary of 25 years, Florence Erdel, visited his bedside not for a sad farewell, but to bring him up to date on who called that day and what they wanted. This was the essential Alex Rose; tracking his communicants to the end, studying the thoughts and people of politics that clustered to him each day as if the telephone itself were patronage.

GLEN HEAD, L.I--All last week, while many students at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn were planning trips to beach and ski resorts for their Christmas holiday, Nancy Manzione simply wanted to go home.
BARCELONA, Spain, Dec. 29--Three years after his death in self-imposed exile in Puerto Rico, the memory of Pablo Casals was honored today in his beloved Catalonia.

VOYAGE. By Sterling Hayden. 700 Pages. Putnam. $12.95. Sterling Hayden's "Voyage" is the sort of book some critic is certain to call a "blockbuster," but I believe that this particular block has already been busted beyond repair. "Epic" novels of the sea are generally foul weather in fiction, and "Voyage" is not responsive to the helm. I always liked Mr. Hayden as an understated actor, but as a writer he is a terrible ham.

PARIS, Dec. 29--The bizarre assassination on Friday of Prince Jean de Broglie, a prominent politician, took an even more curious turn today as officials said that the motive for the killing was not political retribution, as earlier believed, but money.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 29-- Bob Gibson, not the former St. Louis Cardinal pitcher but the former Youngstown University quarterback, was the only newcomer announced today by Coach John McVay to the Giants' reshuffled coaching staff.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--A lawyer for the Civil Aeronautics Board charged today that Flying Tiger Line Inc., a Los Angeles-based cargo carrier, gave money and corporate gifts to American politicians and foreign dignitaries and then improperly listed them as operating expenses.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29--Johnny Majors, who has three days to go as the University of Pittsburgh head football coach, returned to the scene of his best known mistake and found himself the center of a social-professional situation that he admitted was "a little bit bizarre."

A State Supreme Court justice has dismissed a two-year-old suit for breach of contract against Valery and Galina Panov by their first American manager, and also denied their countersuit for punitive damages.
ATLANTIC CITY--The adoption of the casino gambling referendum on Nov. 2 has stimulated the best two months of convention bookings in the history of the 68-year-old Atlantic City Convention Bureau.

CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Dec. 29 (AP)--The first of several black marines charged in a commando-style attack on white marines they allegedly thought were Ku Klux Klan members pleaded guilty today to rduced charges of assault.

The discovery of a major urban civilization that rose in northern Syria 4,400 years ago and rivaled its only contemporaries, Mesopotamia and Egypt, is being acclaimed as one one of the most significant archeological advances of the century.
A brisk trade in macapino, tujo, patis and bijon is going on these days along the Manila strip of Ninth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)--Final regulations were issued today by the Federal Reserve Board banning credit discrimination for reasons of race, color, religion and age, and including the right for people to know why they were denied credit.

A State Supreme Court justice has dismissed a two-year-old suit for breach of contract against Valery and Galina Panov by their first American manager, and also denied their countersuit for punitive damages.
They came to the party to see a gorilla grab at airplanes from his perch atop the 12-foot Christmas tree. Or was it the Empire State Building?
UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 29--Fred Brown, who looks sleepy, and Slick Watts, who looks innocent, stole a game for the Seattle SuperSonics against the Nets last night at the Nassau Coliseum.
Cocoa futures prices moved up yesterda on the New York Cocoa Exchange, with the March delivery closing at $1.39 65/100 up from $1.38 55/100.
VAIL, Colo. Dec. 29--President Ford said today it was "highly likely" that he would recommend the elimination of price controls on gasoline when he returns to Washington next week.

With November residential construction contracts running 50 percent ahead of the November 1975 level, the total of construction contracts last month at $7.69 billion showed an increase of 37 percent over the level of the corresponding month of 1975, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 29--A mystery involving the sale of fraudulent military equipment to Libya deepened today with evidence that the French Government, and apparently the Libyan Government as well, knew in advance that a fake deal was in the works.

High inventories indicative of the slackened demand for its products has prompted temporary closedown at a textile fiber plant, an iron ore mine and 11 plants of a major textile producer in Canada. All of them were announced yesterday.

Two United States Senators, Herman E. Talmadge of Georgia, and Lowell P. Weicker of Connecticut, are separating from their wives. Marie Louise Weicker yesterday asked Su perior Court in Stamford for a divorce, saying in her complaint, filed under the state's no-fault law, that her 23-year-old marriage to the Republican Senator was "irretrievably broken."

Ella Dutcher Romig of Washington, former president of the Women's Board of Foreign Missions of the Reformed Church in America, died Monday while visiting a son, the Rev. David W. Romig, pastor of the Downtown United Presbyterian Church in Rochester. She was 84 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--To make Mr. Ford's proposal more politically palatable to Congress, the Federal Energy Administration plans to write in three safeguard- type provisions, officials said.
PEKING, Dec. 29--Long-smoldering political unrest in a city about 100 miles south of here has reportedly erupted into armed conflict, forcing Peking to intervene to quell it.

Some investors who favor dark horses, or secondary issues, did very well in the stock market this year. Those who bought shares of Teledyne Inc., Bally Manufacturing or Brush Wellman Inc. should be especially happy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--The Carter camp found itself in a minor to-do tonight over what various spokesmen sought to treat as a premature and possibly, though not necessarily, inaccurate disclosure of several major White House staff appointments by a senior transition aide.

Labor leaders and bankers said yesterday that they were pleased with President-elect Carter's new assurances about New York City, but that many additional questions had to be answered before they could agree to a plan to redeem nearly $1 billion in city short-term notes.

YONKERS, Dec. 29--The City Council regained control of the Yonkers budget last night by removing from the City Manager the power to create and eliminate jobs and set salaries--a role that had been given to him in a 1970 law.

YONKERS, Dec. 29--The City Council regained control of the Yonkers budget last night by removing from the City Manager the power to create and eliminate jobs and set salaries--a role that had been given to him in a 1970 law.

Ten Harvard undergraduates, cooperating in a test of "psychic" powers to tell the future, did slightly better than 10 nationally prominent "psychics" whose predictions were published in The National Enquirer.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 Representative Jim Wright disclosed today that the House Democratic leadership hoped to create a special energy committee to draft a "long-range, comprehensive program."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 At the beginning of the New Year, maybe the most promising aspect of politics in Washington is the decline of dogmatism. It would be too much to say that everybody has suddenly acquired a chivalrous respect for the opinions of others, but almost everybody seems to be listening a little more and shouting less.

The nation's basic money supply rose a seasonally adjusted average of $700 million, to $311.8 billion, in the week ended Dec. 22, in contrast to a decline of $100 million the week before, according to figures furnished by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 30 (Reuters) In a section of "Jane's Weapon Systems" dealing with naval weapons, Captain G.R. Villar, a former director of British naval intelligence, says that "it is quite possible that missiles will be developed for firing from shore against ships hundreds or thousands of miles away which have been detected and identified by satellite."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 27 As Jimmy Carter prepares to take office, the Middle East, more than any other region of the world, clamors for his attention. From the start, he will be under tremendous pressure to begin a major initiative.

For the first time in nearly 20 years, church and synagogue attendance went up in 1976, according to the Gallup Poll. At the same time, the Gallup organization indicated that the proportion of persons who believed religion was increasing its influence on American life tripled since 1970.

Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher, and the Washington Post Company were reported yesterday to be making competing bids for a sizable block of stock that could mean control of New York magazine and The Village Voice.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 United States Attorney David W. Marston said today that he would seek the indictment next week of Capt. Vasilios Vlismas of the tanker Olympic Games on Federal charges of polluting the Delaware River. Mr. Marston said he would also sue the owner of the Liberian-flag vessel.

THE AUDIENCE follows the actors into the theater, the La Mama Annex, a large open space bare of scenery and edged with bleachers. Suddenly, "The Trojan Women" begins to happen. Scenes are enacted on swiftly rolling carts, high on platforms, even on a stage. Helen of Troy is stripped, besmirched and assaulted. A child is crated in a cage. Andromache plummets to her death. Women, as the booty of war, are led into exile.

Governor Carey moved yesterday to "firmly and finally close the book" on the 1971 prison uprising at Attica as he pardoned seven former Attica inmates and commuted the sentence of an eighth who participated in the riot.

THE EXCITEMENT in Wednesday night's performance of "Salome" at the Metropolitan... Opera was mainly in the orchestra pit. Patty Hearst is out of prison and Phil Shinnick is in, and thereby hangs a tale of American justice.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 31 (AP)--Palestinian gunners shelled three Christian towns in southern Lebanon today, a right-wing Christian radio station reported.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31--With public confidence in its rectitude undermined by disclosures of illegal activity, internal corruption and abuse of power, the Federal Bureau of Investigation that the Carter administration will inherit Jan. 20 is in the midst of its worst internal crisis ever.

A new law calling for faster property-tax foreclosures could result in as much as $200 million in accelerated revenue for New York City. Or it could cause a still greater drain on the city's finances and further erode its troubled tax base.
LISBON, Dec. 31 The United States has agreed to make a $300 million emergency loan to Portugal to save the fivemonth-old Socialist Government from a severe financial crisis.

PARIS--While, at present, French politics are being increasingly polarized between right and left, with the left-wing Socialist-Communist coalition attaining a lead in opinion polls, there is no doubt in the mind of President Giscard d'Estaing, symbol of centralism, that regardless of possible changes in the parliamentary majority, he will remain in office until 1981, the end of his designated term as chief of state.

Pianists in cocktail lounges tend to lean toward a repertory of pop and show tunes performed either with a bland, superficial tinkle or with as much jazz inflection as the room will allow. Neil Wolfe, who is playing piano in the lounge in front of Les Mareyeurs, a restaurant on Madison Avenue at 77th Street, draws on the standard cocktail pianist's repertory, but what he does with these tunes is far from typical.
MATTOON, Ill., Dec. 31 (UPI) Shoppers at stores in this part of eastern Illinois yesterday loaded up on popular soft drinks priced at only 49 cents for an eight pack of 16-ounce bottles.
TOKYO (AP) The Tokyo office of Warner Bros. said that it has annunced that it would terminate the showing of the movie "Victory at Entebbe" in major Japanese cities because of poor attendance.
LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) The pound closed unchanged today in year-end trading on the London foreign exchange market. Trading was at a virtual standstill in the pre-holiday lull.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 31 (AP) The Communist Party of India said today that some of its workers had been arrested on the eve of a planned New Year's Day national protest against Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government.

The projector flashed slides of record album covers on the small screen, and the reaction of the audience at a meeting held the other evening by an organization called Women Against Violence Against Women was shock and outrage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 An engineering team from the staff of the Rock Island Arsenal in Illinois was granted a patent this week for a new, lightweight machine gun intended for use by the United States armed forces.

TRENTON, Dec. 31 State health experts are in general agreement with a State Senate report that says New Jersey's high cancer death rate may be linked to harmful agents in the environment, particularly emissions from certain chemical factories.

Peregrine White Whittlesey was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Gerald Freund, professor and dean of humanities and arts at Hunter College. The bridegroom is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Freund of New York.

NEWARK, Dec, 31 A Hillside, N.J., man who charges that his wife lapsed into a "vegetative" coma as a result of an anesthetic administered during childbirth on Oct. 6 filed a negligence suit yesterday against Beth Israel Medical Center and an anesthesiologist at the hospital.
Commodity exchanges throughout the nation were closed yesterday as were some foreign stock exchanges.
The stock market ended 1976 with a flourish yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average finished ahead 5.56 points to 1,004.65, its second highest yearend closing level in history.

Wallis E. Howe Jr., editor and former advertising manager of The Garden City News, a Long Island weekly, died yesterday in Nassau Hospital after a long illness. He lived at 43 Hilton Avenue in Garden City and was 75 years old.

At the stroke of midnight, bells rang out from Riverside Church, fireworks thundered and sparkled over Central Park and a vast throng of revelers roared, shrieked and blared on horns in Times Square as a ball of light fell from 1976 to 1977.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 31 (UPI) Vietnam reopened the railroad between the north and south today, linking the two halves of the country after 22 years of separation, the official Vietnam News Agency reported.

PRAGUE, Dec. 31 (AP) A gas explosion trapped 45 miners in a coal mine at Chlebovice in northern Moravia, the Czechoslovak press agency CTK said today, and unofficial reports said there was little or no hope that they survived.
John Ferguson grabbed the pink scoresheet in his muscled hand, and, with one squeeze, tightened the paper into a small ball. Three more scoresheets met the same fate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) With a Marine Corps bugle fanfare, the Bicentennial Parade of American Music concluded a year-long salute to the nation's composers today and placed in a 100-year time capsule a sampling of two centuries of their music.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) Millions of Americans will pay as much as $70.20 more in Social Security taxes in the new year.
BOSTON, Dec. 31--The Coast Guard sank the battered hull of the wrecked tanker the Argo Merchant today with 12 shots fired from a 20-millimeter gun.
WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 31 "Duck cleaning here," say the hand-lettered signs outside the abandoned looking green-and-white concrete-block garage near the riverfront.

Coleman Jr., United States Secretary of Transportation, will find a coalition of opponents ready to resume their legal and political battles against the superhighway on Manhattan's West Side.
Interns and residents at Brooklyn's Methodist Hospital threatened to strike today because of the hospital's refusal to recognize the Committee of Interns and Residents as their bargaining agent.
VIENNA, Dec. 31--A hundred dressmakers are wielding scissors and needles, between glances at high-fashion sketches from Paris or Rome, to get gala gowns ready in time for the Opera Ball.

A fashionably and expensively dressed woman stood outside a toy store on Moscow's Kutuzovsky Prospekt this afternoon, watching aristocratically as two large rocking horses were loaded into her chauffeur-driven black sedan. Percy Selden, a Houston real estate investor, died Thursday in a balloon accident near that city. He was 70 years old.

MONTGOMERY, Ala. I got drunk last night. Not pleasantly high. Kneewalking. I was tipsy by three in the afternoon, kept the buzz on until after sundown, began with Beefeater-onthe-rocks at six, and ended with bourbon and branch water. I brought in the New Year with a holler, a taste of champagne, and a kiss from my sweet wife's lips.

PARIS, Dec. 31 The small orchestra played "Moulin Rouge" as sweetly and valiantly as it could, about 75 couples shuffled and bumped each other on the dance floor, the waiters collected $5 for each cup of tea or gin fizz, and by 7 P.M. yesterday it was all over: Another elegant, if coquettish aspect of life in Paris had moved into nostalgia.

GEOGRAPHY Puerto Rico is 50 miles east of Hispaniola (Haiti and the Dominican Republic) in the outer Caribbean, about 1,000 miles southeast of Florida. The island commonwealth consists of 3,423 square miles, less than one-third the size of New Hampshire. The climate is semi tropical with temperatures ranging from 63 degrees to 96 degrees Fahrenheit. There are 10 ports, with San Juan, the capital on the northern coast, Ponce and Mayaguez; the leading ones.
Two trophies are awarded annually by the Greater New York Bridge Association for overall performance, the Lipton Trophy for all events, and the Spero Trophy for team events.

A 16-year-old Queens youth was charged yesterday in the murder of Carlos King, a Transit Authority patrolman who was found shot to death on a quiet street in Queens Village, Queens, on Dec. 20 in the medallion cab he was driving while on vacation.

The commission ruled on a card by Steve Reece, a promoter who had proposed a Jan. 14 match between Baby Bear James and Joanne Lutz, both of Miami.

NEW ORLEANS Dec. 31 The undefeated Pittsburgh and once-beaten Georgia football teams are ready to play the 43d Sugar Bowl football game in the Superdome tomorrow morning as scheduled. The Peabody Institute, a major American music conservatory, will become affiliated with Johns Hopkins University next July. In the new relationship between the two Baltimore organizations, Peabody will keep its corporate identity, but supervision of its day-to-day management will be the university's responsibility. The conservatory will be known as the Peabody Institute of the Johns Hopkins University.
Newark's 450 sanitationmen will be working throughout the New Year's weekend to clean up the 2,400 tons of Christmas garbage and snow that have piled up since they went on strike Monday.

New Jersey's 607 public school districts start the new year still worried about the problem of adjusting their 1976-77 budgets so that they can take advantage of the $320 million in incometax revenue and $285 million in other state aid they have been told they can use to meet current needs. LONDON, Dec. 31 The Great British Christmas Break seems to have gotten out of hand. WASHINGTON, Dec 31 (UPI) The Federal Government spent $72 million to finance the 1976 Presidential election and has almost $24 million left as a base for building a new fund for the 1980 elections, federal records show.

Three youths were arrested last night and charged with the vandalism of a South Bronx branch of the New York Public Library over the Christmas weekend. Another suspect, who is reportedly a member of a gang known as the Bachelors, was still being sought by the police.

WEST BERLIN The German motorcycle industry, whose early demise was predicted in the nineteenfifties, is alive and well today, thanks to young people all over the world. The biggest German producer, the BMW motorcycle factory, reported growth of 20 percent in 1976 and expects a 10 percent increase in 1977. Peter Martini, the business manager, told a reporter that the company hoped to expand sales from 28,000 vehicles in 1976 to about 60,000 in 1980.

A word of advice for anyone who enrolls in the course in contemporary developments in criminal justice next semester at Adelphi University in Garden City: Don't mess around with the teacher. The one-semester course will be taught by Sanford Garelik, who started as a New York City policeman in 1940, became the department's Chief Inspector and now is head of the New York City Transit Police Department.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Jan. 1 Eleven fire companies, some from as far south as Tarrytown, joined in fighting a general alarm fire here today that destroyed a small branch of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Hospital, a furniture store and three homes. A garage was damaged.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 The University of Southern California had the quarterback, Vince Evans, who could do everything today, and Michigan did not. That was the difference in the 63d Rose Bowl game, won by the Trojans, 14-6, before the largest football crowd of the season, 106,182.

At the end of World War II, the Navy sent a young engineer named Samuel C. Florman to help rebuild a bombed Pacific atoll. He paved an airstrip with coral and erected Quonset huts. "It was quite an adventure," he says.

THIS reviewer could easily devote every week of the next 50 exclusively to northern Italian restaurants without exhausting the possibilities afforded by this immensely popular species. By local definition, "northern Italian" signifies restaurants of some elegance that go lightly on the marinara, serve fettuccine, tortellini and scampi and do not feature meatball or pizza. More of Italy must be "northern" than meets the eye.

BETHPAGE A VANT GARDE-do it yourself enthusiasts here are learning how to heat their home water system by polar energy. They're being taught to design, build and install box-like collectors that trap heat from the sun to save on fuel bills.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) Groups fighting for and against the equal rights amendment to the Constitution agree that 1977 is a pivotal year for state legislative action if the amendment is to be approved. The proposed amendment would prohibit discrimination based on sex.

The United States Fish and Wildlife Service has reported that a bald eagle was shot and killed by two men with a shotgun near Water Mill in Suffolk County on Dec. 13, for reasons only the men know. Bald eagles are increasingly rare in the nation that adopted them as the national symbol, and rewards of $3,000 are being offered for information leading to the conviction of the bird's killers.

Hoffman, Democrats, and Assemblyman Thomas H. Kean, a Republican. The engagement of Polly Connor Williams to Peter Thomas Zarella, a Boston lawyer has been announced by the future bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. John Avery Ingersoll Jr. of Old Saybrook, Conn. In case you haven't heard, Flo Kennedy is a 60-year-old female black activist, lawyer, feminist, radical. She has founded or joined up with some respectable organizations in her time (NOW, Women's Political Caucus, Women's National Abortion Action Coalition, The Feminist Party), but she is basically a street-fighter against racism and sexism and a great talker. Not for nothing is she known, most honorably, as "radicalism's rudest mouth."

TOKYO, Jan. 1 (UPI) Guty Espadas of Mexico battered Jiro Takada of Japan at will today and retained his Worl pan at will today and retained his World Boxing Association flyweight title with a seventh-round knockout in a scheduled 15-round fight. The 22year-old champion took control in the third round when he floored Takada with a left hook to the jaw for a mandatory 8 count.

SYDNEY, Jan. 1 (UPI) Rain postponed the men's final in the $100,000 New South Wales open tennis tournament today. Tony Roche won the first set, 6-3, from Dick Stockton, but was trailing, 2-5, in the second when an electrical storm broke.

PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 2 (AP)--Presidentelect Carter evoked memories of his childhood in a nearly all-black community today as he took the son and daughter of a black bishop to worship services at the Plains Baptist Church.

HONOLULU, Jan. 2--Hawaii's sugar industry, already suffering from depressed prices because of foreign competition, is facing crucial wage negotiations this month. A strike after Jan. 31 is a strong possibility.
KEENE, N.H., Jan. 2 (UPI)--"I'm Francis Albert Sinatra, known the world over as the voice of WKBK, 1220 on your dial in Keene, N.H., the garden spot of the universe."

First Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti last night raised the possibility of furloughing 10,000 more municipal workers next year to balance New York City's budget if various municipal unions and banks failed to agree to a five-year deferral of all payments of principal on Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds that they own.

Edward M. McDermott, who after retiring from the New York City Parks Department gained recognition as an Irish fiddler, died Saturday in the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived in the Atlantic Hotel, Asbury Park, N.J.

COLUMBUS, N.M.--An eagerness to exchange Mexican beef-on-the-hoof for solid United States dollars has created a cattle jam at the border crossing here. Behind the stampede is the second devaluation of the peso in three months.

A 40-year-old man described as a "jealous suitor" and a 17-year-old friend were arrested yesterday and charged with setting the fire last Oct. 24 that killed 25 persons in a Bronx social club and injured 24.

Marion Brown, an alto saxophonist from Atlanta who made a name for himself in New York during the 1960's, has been writing music inspired by the prose poetry of Jean Toomer for several years. Mr. Toomer, a black Georgian, celebrated the Southern landscape and recounted the trials of black Southerners.

BUFFALO, Jan. 2--The Islanders began their return trip from the doldrums tonight by tying the Buffalo Sabres, 3-3, on just 16 shots.

Mark Diesen, an 18-year-old master of Potomic, Md., and the United States representative in the World Junior Championship, won the second New York futurity tournament, held at the Manhattan Chess Club.

BILBAO, Spain, Jan. 2(Reuters)--About 12 persons were injured today when hundreds of stone-throwing Basque demonstrators fought a two-hour battle with the Civil Guard in the streets of Algorta near here.
The University of Pittsburgh's unbeaten football team was named to receive two national awards yesterday after its 27-3 victory over Georgia in Saturday's Sugar Bowl game at New Orleans.

HACKENSACK, Jan. 2--A.L. Winegar, president of the Business Arts Foundation, would like to see symphony orchestras perform in the Meadowlands Sports Complex--maybe not in the middle ef the big stadium, but possibly in some bright new facility devoted to the cultural arts within the highly successful complex.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2--Several months ago a 16-year-old Armenian walked from the gray streets of Baku into the gold and candlelight of a church. She crossed herself, lit a candle and bowed her head in a brief prayer.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 2--President Anwar el-Sadat's proposal that any Palestinian state should be linked with Jordan was cautiously assessed in the Israeli Cabinet today, with Foreign Minister Yigal Allon stating that the Egyptian leader's move was a "not insignificant step."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 2 (UPI) --Arthur Ashe ended a series of disappointing losses with a quick first-round victory in the $216,000 Australian open tennis championships at the Kooyong grass courts today. Ashe, who won the title six years ago, posted a 6-3, 6-0, 6-2 triumph over Peter McNamara of Australia.
Raw steel production in the United States rose 11.4 percent to 130 million tons in 1976, the strongest increase among all the world's major steel producers.
The New York Rangers survived a bewildering variety of obstacles last night and still registered a 5-3 victory over the Vancouver Canucks at Madison Square Garden.

Erroll Garner, the jazz pianist, died yesterday afternoon when he suffered a cardiac arrest in an ambulance going to Cedars Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. Mr. Garner had been receiving treatment for emphysema since March, 1975, when he collapsed while performing at Mr. Kelly's in Chigaco. He was 53 years old.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP)--The North stormed to a three-touchdown lead-in the first half today, then held off a late surge by the South for a 21-20 victory in the ninth annual American Bowl before a crowd of 14,207.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 (AP)--Philadelphia's Mummers were out in force today, braving subfreezing temperatures to parade up Broad Street in their extravagant regalia. The freezing cold and blustery winds forced postponement of the New Year's Day parade yesterday. The parade has been a Philadelphia institution since 1901.

The West End Funeral Chapel, formerly at 4511 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, is now at 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, Edward Weinstein, vice president, said yesterday that the chapel had been moved from the other building, where its place has been taken by the Shomrei Hadas Chapel, which held services Dec. 21 for three rabbis killed in an automobile accident.

Christianity and Communism in the Soviet Union have reached a state of uneasy coexistence. WASHINGTON, Jan. 2--The Government's program for assuring the safety of pesticides is in a "state of chaos" that raises doubts about the protection of the public from traces of dangerous chemicals, according to a Senate staff report made public today.

ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 2--Claudine Longet, the French-born entertainer, is scheduled to go on trial here tomorrow on manslaughter charges resulting from the shooting death last March 21 of Vladimir Sabich, the professional skier.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 2--They call it the Russian front of archeology. In the morning the ground is frozen solid, but before the day is over it has turned to ankle-deep mud. Tons of earth have to be screened with chilling water and often workers have to lie on the ground while painstakingly unearthing a skeleton or artifact.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 2--Two jockeys, Jesus Guaralupe of Whitestone, N.Y., and Paul Kallai of Cherry Hill, N.J., have had their one-year suspensions imposed by the State Racing Commission set aside pending a hearing in Superior Court here on Jan. 13.

Warren J. Freeman, who retired in 1968 as president of the General Bronze Corporation, maker of aluminum windows and building panels, died Saturday at his home in Hallandale, Fla. He was 76 years old.

New York City's first new Charter in 14 years tools effect over the weekend, promising a sharply increased role for local communities in the conduct of city government, including the gradual assumption of responsibility for the delivery of most services.

The corporate bond market, which has just completed what one trader calls "an absolutely fantastic year" for profits, will test the waters this week to see how much higher prices can go in early 1977.

STANFORD, Calif., Jan. 2--It rained on the Shriners parade today, but their 52d annual East-West college all-star game was undimmed by the weather. BURLINGTON, Vt., Jan. 2 (AP)--The Vermont Sunday News, owned by William Loeb, announced today that it would temporarily stop publication.

New Jersey motorists were given the chance for the first time yesterday to turn right at most red lights, but the opportunity apparently went unnoticed by many drivers unfamiliar with the new regulation. A spot road check by United Press International showed motorists frequently were unaware of the opportunity to turn right at red lights not specifically marked with "No Turn on Red" signs.

A new schedule for economic commentary takes effect today. The Economic Scene column will be written by Leonard Silk on Monday in addition to Thursday. Thomas E. Mullaney will continue to write the column on Tuesday and Friday, as well as Sunday. The Labor Scene column by A. H. Raskin, which previously appeared on Monday, will appear each Wednesday.

Not since the Goren "Championship Bridge" programs made in the early 60's have New York enthusiasts had a regular opportunity to watch their favorite game on television. The long drought has now ended. Monica M. Devine of Westport, Conn., and Paul Bancroft 3d of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. White in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Jan Walton performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP)--The spreading slick of oil spilled by the wrecked Argo Merchant could be drawn into the Gulf Stream within two days, the Coast Guard reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP)--Betty Ford indicated tonight that she does not favor blanket amnesty for Vietnam War draft evaders and deserters, but she said that she had not advised her husband about what to do on the issue.
