LONDON, Jan. 5 Britain's Department of Energy released today the agreement by which it plans to become a 51 percent owner of North Sea oil production now belonging to Shell U.K. Ltd. and the Esso Petroleum Company. The arrangement; expected to be complted within three months, is similar to settlements reached with other oil companies and is aimed at reserving supplies of North Sea oil to Britain.

A high-grade utility bond issue was offered to investors yesterday at a yield of 7,625 percent, the lowest rate of return on such securities since June 1973. The bonds marketed in the midst of a modest recovery throughout the credit markets, were reported to...

For weeks Carla Pinza, the actress, has been nursing new plays through their growing pains at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater on the Lower East Side. But they are plays with a difference. They are plays that have a lot riding on them because, if everything goes well, Miss Pinza says with her fingers crossed, "gifted Latino playwrights will have a chance to get their work before the public and, hopefully, produced."

A Federal grand jury has reported that intelligence agents of the Internal Revenue Service did not violate the civil rights of taxpayers during a highly publicized "sex and drinking" investigation in Miami known as Operation Leprechaun.

Dr. John Taylor Howell, for 56 years a leading pediatrician and teacher in New York City, died Tuesday in Huntington (L.I.) Hospital after a short illness. He was 85 years old and lived in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

HARTFORD, Jan. 5 Gov. Ella T. Grasso today asked for a consolidated, reorganized administration for public higher education in Connecticut, a single agency for budget planning, a single agency for revenue-producing activities, the means for more closely overseeing the state's various forms of legal gambling and better tools for controlling organized crime.

Dr. Irving M. Derby, pathologist at Brooklyn State Hospital from 1929 to 1942 when he did preliminary blood-bank research, died yesterday in Veterans Administration Hospital at Canandaigua, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

After about a year at Warren, Muller, Dolobowsky and some six months at Martin Landey/Arlow Advertising, Nathan's Famous restaurant chain has changed agencies once again. This time it is Shaper Rubin Associates and the client is saying that it will spend more than $1 million for advertising.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 Senate Democrats today, gave Hubert H. Humphrey a $7,450 raise, a chauffeured limousine, entree to White House leadership meetings and a new title: Deputy President pro tem of the Senate.

FAIRVIEW, Jan. 5 An explosion and fire caused by a leaking gas main destroyed a small embroidery shop in this commercial community of Bergen County today, killing the wife of the owner and critically injuring him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 State Department officials said today that Presidentelect Carter has informed President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France that he agreed in principle with his proposal for a summit meeting among leading Western economic powers but that no time or place has been set.

The Carter Administration will face two critical tasks on the international economic front: holding back a rising tide of protectionist barriers to trade, and building safeguards against international financial decay that could re- sult from continuing bal-...

Bill Martin, one of the top half-milers in the country last year while a freshman at Boston College, has switched his allegiance to Iona College and the New York A.C. this year. Last night he also switched distances at the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union junior indoor track and field championships and the result was a victory for him in the mile run.
Amy Lou, the youngest and newest of the New York Aquarium's four white whales, is believed to be about midway in a pregnancy that could produce a 50-or-so-pound calf next May to July.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 5 Harry G. Hoffmann, who recently retired as editor of The Charleston Gazette and who was one of this state's best known and most influential political writers, died at his typewriter yesterday of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

BOSTON, Jan. 5 If one looks around the world today with an eye for what could become areas of danger to the Carter Administration, the most likely trouble spot may well be southern Africa. The clashes of race and ideology there, already violent, have about them the feeling of inevitable escalation.
Rupert Murdoch used assets of The New York Post to pay for the major part of what he calls his controlling interest in the New York Magazine Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 A proposed new regulation that would have eliminated a major tax shelter enjoyed by builders was ordered withdrawn today by the Secretary of the Treasury only hours after it was published by the Internal Revenue Service.

NEWARK, Jan. 5 A. Avram Apter, a director of the Philip Apter and Sons Funeral Home in Maplewood, N.J., has been indicted on charges of attempting to defraud two insurance companies of more than $800,000 in a fake jewel-robbery scheme, the Essex County Prosecutor's office said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 The Justice Department today issued formal administrative guidelines designed to prevent future abusive and illegal acts on the part of undercover informers controlled by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and to balance the use of informers against the possibility that their presence might stifle free speech and association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 Members of Congress from coastal states, amid growing concern over a series of oil spills and accidents involving Liberian-flag tankers, are proposing new legislation aimed at curbing spills and are scheduling hearings on the Argo Merchant disaster.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 5 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, making a significant gesture, has written one of her leading political opponents expressing the hope that "it would not be impossible to find solutions to the problems between opposition and Government."

LONDON, Jan. 5 Britain's official reserves plunged 20 percent in December the Bank of England disclosed today. It was an extraordinary loss of vital funds that governments use in managing their economies and the consequences of the severe pressure on the pound through most of the year.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 5 County Executive Ralph G. Caso, who is fighting his party for political survival, won two small skirmishes today in his efforts to name an acting county attorney.

PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 5 A valued young assistant to President-elect Carter who had been expected to become the White House appointments secretary will not be given the post because a routine security check by the Federal Bureau of investigation disclosed that he might have been involved in financial irregulari- ties, a Carter spokesman said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 The chairman of the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Civil and Constitutional Rights has warned that some of the proposed investigative techniques of the House Select Committee on Assassinations would be...

The recent advance of several important economic indicators has convinced many private American economists that the so-called pause in the nation's economic recovery from the deepest recession since World War II is now ending and that growth this year may be somewhat stronger than they had expected earlier.
Frances Fox Field, a writer and painter died Tuesday in her home in Manhattan She was 64 years old.

PHILADEPHIA, Jan. 5 The chief and second engineers of the Liberian-registered Olympic Games testified today that a malfunctioning valve caused a loss of maneuvering power a few minutes before the tanker veered shoreward and went aground off Marcus Hook, Pa., last week, spilling 134,000 gallons of oil into the Delaware River.
JOHANNESBURG, Jan 5 (Reuters) Schools in the black African township of Soweto reopened today, six months after bloody rioting began in protest over teaching practices.
OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 5 Wendy Yoshimura testified in her defense today and was cited five times for contempt of court for refusing to answer questions about her life in the underground.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 When it snows it rains troubles on Washington, a Southern city in clime and temperament that has never learned to cope with such Northern caprices as today's two-inch snowfall.

A mathematical error resulted in a serious miscalculation about the position of the oil tanker Argo Merchant shortly before the ship ran aground, according to testimony yesterday by Capt. Georgios Papadopoulos, the ship's master.

BOSTON, Jan. 5 The prospects of finding the missing Panamanian tanker Grand Zenith diminished today as the United States and Canadian Coast Guards expanded the air and sea search to a 100,000-square-mile area in the Atlantic Ocean east of Cape Cod and south of Nova Scotia.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 5 (AP) Steve Grant hit a career high of 31 points and grabbed 17 rebounds tonight in leading Manhattan to an 81-68 basketball victory over Brown.
EAST BERLIN, Jan. 5 Mehmet Soglaclu, a Turkish migrant worker in West Berlin, got an unpleasant surprise this morning when he crossed the border into East Berlin to visit his friend and have lunch.

The National Iranian Oil Company reported yesterday that it expects sales in 1977 to run about 10 percent below expected levels equivalent to $6 million per day in lost revenue after the decision by Saudi Arabia to impose a more moderate price increase.
Chinese gangs, whose members range in age from the low teens to the upper 20's, are extorting money from owners of Chinese restaurants in Queens, District Attorney John J. Santucci said yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 Governor Carey today complemented his call for continued fiscal caution with a reaffirmation of his interest in aiding "persons legitimately in need of government assistance" and outlined new proposals for dealing with the mentally disabled juvenile delinquents and the aged.

DETROIT, Jan. 5 Over half a million new car and light-truck owners around the country are still without spare tires even though the fourmonth rubber industry strike ended list summer, an auto industry survey showed today.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 Governor Carey sur prised the Legislature today by asking for an immediate $200 million cut in the state's personal income tax and a $750 million bond issue to finance job-producing construction projects starting next year.
With sales of new cars domestic and imported up 17 percent in 1976 to 10.1 million, some of the credit, it appears, must be shared with the suppliers of credit.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 Stock and debenture owners who lost millions of dollars when Equity Funding, a Los Angeles-based financial services company, was destroyed by a securities fraud in 1973, are expected to receive a settlement totaling more than $57 million.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 The opening of a legislative session is very like the first day of school, and one of the freshest freshmen in Albany yesterday was Assemblyman Clifford E. Wilson, a 30year-old Democrat-Liberal of Queens. His mother cried, he buttoned up the vest of his new brown suit wrong and his wife got very nervous about meeting the Governor.
The price of lead rose yesterday to 26.5 cents a pound, an increase of cent a pound for most producers and of one cent a pound for Asarco Inc., which had been quoting lead at 25.5 cents a pound.

Mayor Beame is proposing to overcome a budget deficit of at least $585 million in the next fiscal year by raising the New York City real estate tax, pressing for increased Federal and state assistance and reducing the work force by 8,200 more employees including 1,500 police officers by attrition and without resorting to layoffs.
The Year of the Bicentennial has passed but its benefits are still being harvested. Among them are gifts from donors to the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Syracuse surged in the second half last night to defeat Fordham, 87-68, at the Rose Hill gymnasium in the Bronx. The Orangemen used a balanced attack to set back the Rams, with three players in double figures. Jim Williams led all scorers with 18 and Ross Kindel added 13 and Marty Byrnes 10 as Syracuse continued its usual deep-scoring attack.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 5 The incoming Carter Administration says that it will "review" the $1.16 billion Westway highway project for Manhattan, which was approved yesterday by President Ford's Secretary of Transportation, William T. Coleman Jr.

SONGKHLA, Thailand, Jan. 1 One day late this month, the captains of four small Vietnamese fishing boats plan to set out from this southern Thai port with 80 to 100 refugees for a 3,000-mile voyage across the South China Sea to Australia.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan.5(AP) Keith Herron scored 19 points and his brother Larry had 11 tonight as Villanova upset Notre Dame, 64-62. It was the third consecutive loss for the eighth-ranked Irish.

Onslow Stevens, whose stage and screen career spanned more than three decades, was found dead yesterday in a van Nuys, Calif., nursing home, where he had been a patient. He was 70 years old. The Los Angeles coroner's office said the cause of death was under investigation.

American representation in the world team championship, scheduled in Manila next October, will depend on the result of two matches being played in Houston. In the first match, which began last night, four reigning world champions may be fighting an uphill battle.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 A proposed new regulation that would have eliminated a major tax shelter enjoyed by builders was ordered withdrawn today by the Secretary of the Treasury only hours after it was published by the Internal Revenue Service.

District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn accused the Board of Education yesterday of having tried to cover up the payment of nearly $70,000 in fictitious overtime to a substitute teacher in Community School District 23, in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville area of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 Sea-Land Service Inc. agreed today in a settement with the Federal Maritime Commission to pay a $4 million penalty for making more than $19 million in rebates to customers. It was the largest civil penalty ever assessed by a transportation regulatory agency in the United States.

The recent advance of several important economic indicators has convinced many private American economists that the so-called pause in the nation's economic recovery from the deepest recession since World War II is now ending and that growth this year may be somewhat stronger than they had expected earlier.

DETROIT, Jan. 5 New-car sales in the United States rebounded to 10.1 million last year, up 17 percent from 8.6 million in 1975, reports from the domestic and imported auto makers showed today. Sales last year were the fourth best for the auto-makers and were 1.3 million behind the 1973 record of 11.4 million.

Mayor Beame is proposing to overcome a budget deficit of at least $585 million in the next fiscal year by raising the New York City real estate tax, pressing for increased Federal and state assistance and reducing the work force by 8,200 more employees including 1,500 police officers by attrition and without resorting to layoffs.
Stock prices dropped sharply across a broad front yesterday in stepped-up trading, with particularly sizable losses in many of the blue-chip and glamour issues.

EAST BRUNSWICK, Jan. 5 William J. Hamilton, a 44-year-old lawyer and the majority leader of the New Jersey Assembly, weathered a challenge by, three other Democrats tonight to win in all but a formal sense the post of Assembly Speaker.

DETROIT, Jan. 5 Despite a substantial increase in losses for the 1976 fiscal year, the two top executives of the financially shaky American Motors Corporation received pay raises for that year, according to the company's stockholder proxy statement, released today.

John J.P. Murphy, who retired five years ago as vice president, general manager and partner of Laird, Bissell Meeds, stock brokers in New York City, died of a heart attack Monday at his home at 1035 Park Avenue. He was 78 Years old.
Fans of the Yomiuri Giants can relax. Sadaharu Oh, Japanese baseball's home-run king, signed his 1977 contract yesterday with the Tokyo club.
Webb Wilson, a retired investment banker, died Tuesday at Southampton, L.I., Hospital. He was 77 years old and a resident of East Hampton, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 For Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. the turning point in his surprising election yesterday as Senate minority leader came at a breakfast meeting Monday with most of the eight freshmen Republican Senators a meeting to which he had not been officially invited.
Management of a Times Square bookstore by undercover policemen has resulted in the arrest of six men accused of selling obscene movies, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 5 (AP) Roscoe Tanner beat Tony Roche and Arthur Ashe eliminated the surprising Hank Pfister in the $216,000 Australian open tennis championship today. Both winners reached the quarterfinals.

Superior teachers may occasionally do more for children in ramshackle schools than incompetent teachers in educational palaces. And yet, the romantic or miserly notion that money makes no difference does not stand the test of reality. When, as currently in New York State, some school districts can barely afford $1,000 a year per pupil, while others spend more than $6,000, not even the best teachers can overcome the handicap.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 5 West Point cadets ousted in last year's cheating scandal will be permitted to return, but not until this summer, Army Secretary Martin R. Hoffmann said today, thereby rejecting the major recommendation of the Borman Commission that the cadets be readmitted "as soon as possible."
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 Lynn and David wanted an inexpensive divorce, so they decided to do the legal work themselves.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 5 When Ivor Richard of Britain sat down at the weekend to discuss a Rhodesian peace settlement with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith, it was not long before the two men became embroiled in what Mr. Rich-...

The Seagram Company Ltd., the world's largest distiller, is expected to announce today the election of Philip E. Beekman, president of the Colgate-Palmolive Company's international division, as president and chief operating officer of Seagram, the parent company, and of Joseph R. Seagram Son Inc., the American subsidiary.
ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 5 (UPI) Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto today announced a series of agrarian reforms expected to improve his party's chances in the March elections.

The winter wind courses through the Hall of Fame for Great Americans high above the Harlem River, whistling past 95 bare heads cast in bronze and one with a hat, William Penn. All the rest is silence in the open, 630-foot Greco-Roman colonnade on the old University Heights campus of New York University, now occupied by Bronx Community College.
HUNTER, N.Y., Jan. 5(AP) United States ski team members dominated the competition today as the CanadianAmerican Ski Trophy series got under way at Hunter Mountain with a giant slalom event.
After exhaustive study, two young chemists have retracted the highly controversial conclusion of an earlier investigation that disrupted a major new area of pest control research.

One hardly knew whether last night's audience at the City Center 55th Street Theater was welcoming back the American Ballet Theater or its always lively production of "Coppelia." What was certain was that, transcending anything else, it was relishing the return to New York of Cynthia Gregory, after her much publicized premature retirement a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 The Securities and Exchange Commission published today a preliminary report of its staff's inquiry into the securities activities of commercial banks. The report, which makes no legislative recommendations, consists of statistical analyses of four bank activities similar to services offered by brokers.

WASHINGTON A lengthy catand-mouse game between the country's largest banks and their Federal regulators is threatening to become a fierce fight over the banks' rights to what is, for them, relatively new and unguarded territory.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 5 Housing Minister Abraham Ofer, who committed suicide on Monday, was given a state funeral today, and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin said in a eulogy that he believed the minister to have been innocent of the embezzlement charges linked to him in newspaper reports.
MOSCOW, Jan. 5 The Soviet Union announced today that its 1976 grain harvest had totaled a record 223.8 million metric tons a dramatic rebound from the drought and crop failure of the previous year.

LONDON, Jan. 5 (UPI) Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union were banned from tournaments today by the international Lawn Tennis Federation because they had not paid all the fines levied against them for withdrawing from the Federation Cup in Philadelphia last September.

MOSCOW, Jan. 5 (Reuters) The leader of a dissident group set up to monitor Soviet observance of the Helsinki accords was seized on the street today and questioned for seven hours by justice officials.
A three hour mediation session failed yesterday to resolve the 23-day orchestra strike that has Shut down the New York City Ballet.

Saudi Arabia's multibillion dollar arms purchases from the United States have expanded to include some of the most advanced weapons such as ship-to-shore or ship-to-ship missiles, high speed laserguided bombs and antiradar missiles.
DETROIT, Jan, 6 American automobile plants are scheduled to build 181,089 cars this week, an increase of 17.1 percent over a year ago, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 6 The judge in the trial of Wendy Yoshimura instructed the jury today to disregard all testimony Miss Yoshimura gave when she took the stand yesterday.

The most accurate long-distance measurements ever made, by means of radio signals between the Viking spacecraft on Mars and antennas on Earth, have produced new confirmation of Einstein's theory of relativity, a Viking project scientist reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) A Federal Trade Commission study today called for a crackdown on "false, deceptive, and unfair" schemes used to promote vocational and home-study schools to which two million Americans pay more than $2.5 billion in tuition ,each year.

A centuries-old ritual the breaking of St. Basil's bread on Epiphany was celebrated yesterday by Archbishop Iakovos, Primate of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America, before youngsters attending Holy Trinity Cathedral School.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 President-elect Carter has selected former Senator Gale W. McGee, Democrat of Wyoming, to be the United States representative in the Organization of American States, high Latin American diplomats said today.

A special commission appointed by Governor Carey said yesterday that it was opposed to the merger of the City University of New York and the State University into a single statewide system with a central administration and one board of trustees.

MIAMI Jan. 6 (AP) Howard Kleinberg, editor of The Miami News, branded as ludicrous today the contents of a still secret Federal grand jury's report on the Internal Revenue Service's intelligence operations here, as described in The New York Times.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 6 Mel Patrick Lynch and Dominic P. Byrne, who were convicted last month of extorting $2.3 million from Edgar M. Bronfman but acquitted on charges of kidnapping Mr. Bronfman's son, Samuel 2d, were sentenced today to serve at least four and three years, respectively.

Spencer Haywood learned how to use a new protective shield for his left leg yesterday in the doctor's office and in a workout at the West Side Y.M.C.A. Tonight the Knick forward will find out how well it works in the battles under the backboards. The Knick forward flew to Chicago to join the team for the game against the Bulls after being examined by Dr. James Nicholas, the team doctor.

IT HAS BEEN a long time since a serious painter working in the Realist tradition has been invited to undertake a major mural project for a Government building, especially a mural on the theme of the American worker. But this unusual event long associated with the Work Projects Administration programs of the 1930's, and distant indeed from the recent interests of the art world has now occurred.

PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 6 President-elect Carter considered the final details of an economic stimulation program today after one major Carter adviser expressed hope that it would not cost more than $15 billion so as to avoid distressing public opinion as a result of massive additions to the budget deficit.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Jan. 4 Two weeks ago, 71-year-old Alex Nessen, a former owner of a nearby bungalow colony, strolled into Holiday Mountain's base lodge and told Vic Gordon, the area's manager, he wanted to learn to ski. "I didn't know what to think," said Gordon. "I've known the man for 25 years and he's never shown any interest in skiing.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 6 (AP) Rickey Green scored 20 points and John Robinson 18 as they led fifthranked Michigan to a 102-65 drubbing of Northwestern in their opening Big Ten Conference game.

BUFFALO, Jan. 6 (AP) Guy Lafleur scored his 32d and 33d goals of the season to pace the Montreal Canadiens to a 9-2 victory over the Buffalo Sabres in a National Hockey League game at the Memorial Auditorium tonight.
Judge Thomas P. Griesa interrogated the captain of the oil tanker Argo Merchant yesterday as the first round of testimony about the tanker ended in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

TRENTON, Jan. 6 Governor Byrne and State Education Commissioner Fred G. Burke urged today in a letter to all 607 school districts that all asbestos fibers be removed from the state's 2,500 public schools as a health measure.
"What I wanted was to eliminate this ghastly idea that the harp only plays glissandos with the orchestra, or only arpeggios," explains Aristid von Wurtzler. "I was looking for a new image."

Hubert Laws, a jazz flutist who has spent most of his career staying out of the spotlight, will be right in the middle of it tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall where he is giving concerts at 8 P.M. and at midnight with Earl Klugh the guitarist, and Lonnie Liston Smith and the Cosmic Echoes.

NOT LONG ago-10 years, or less technology was supposed to be going to put handmade art out of business. Even where paint and canvas were still in use, an impersonal execution was mandatory. Ideas came to the artist ready-made and complete, and their execution was best entrusted to others.
Rupert Murdoch said yesterday that the $30 million he used to buy The New York Post came from a combination of cash and borrowings in London, New York and his native Australia.
LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP) The pound fell almost a half cent on the London foreign exchange market today. Dealers described trading as relatively light.

THE CONTRIBUTIONS of Connecticut's citizenry in enriching the decorative arts heritage of the nation has become apparent in recent years as the state's museums, historical houses and societies have increasingly investigated the past. There are now, for instance, two exhibitions in Hartford that explore quite different areas and periods of American design.

Through sea changes in weaponry, in the balance of power and in the number and nature of potential adversaries, our Navy has designed itself for 50 years around 15 mighty capital ships, the ceiling that emerged from the Washington Naval Treaty of 1922. Capital once meant battleships, eventually attack carriers.

The prospect of an evening with the performer who, billed as "M. O'Haughey," plays Mary Sunshine, a transvestite reporter, in the musical "Chicago," might seem to be of limited appeal. But the actuality, as presented at Barbarann, 349 West 46th Street, through Sunday evening, is absolutely dazzling.

ALTHOUGH many restaurants lay claim to originality in the dishes they serve, all too often, the only original features of such specialties are their names. It is, therefore, a pleasant and encouraging surprise to come upon a restaurant with a cuisine that is truly original, inventive and delicious, and that is, as a bonus, moderately priced. That is exactly the combination one finds at the East-West Restaurant on East Ninth Street near Park Avenue South.

PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 6 President-elect Carter considered the final details of an economic stimulation program today after one major Carter adviser expressed hope that it would not cost more than $15 billion so as to avoid distressing public opinion as a result of massive additions to the budget deficit.
LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP) A plan to cut inflation from 15 to 5 percent a year by mid-1978 and to provide more than a half million new jobs was outlined today by the Confederation of British Industry.

The State Liquor Authority, declaring that it, had begun "a full-scale crackdown against unlicensed speakeasies," said yesterday that it was seeking its first court injunction to close an unlicensed bottle club in New York City.

CLEVELAND, Jan, 6 (AP) Austin Carr sparked a second-period spree tonight as the Cleveland Cavaliers ended Golden State's four-game winning string with a 129-100 National Basketball Association triumph over the Warriors.
The toll in a fire that destroyed a linen and giftware store in downtown Brooklyn on Dec. 22 rose to 10 yesterday as two additional bodies were found in the rubble.
Local harness-racing handicappers have been confronted this winter with this type of form frequently: a cheap horse coming back to the races only four days after his last start.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Jan. 6 (Reuters) President Samora Machel of Mozambique, whose country is the main springboard for nationalist guerrilla attacks on Rhodesia, was reported today to have expressed his readiness for a peaceful solution in the breakaway British colony.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 A block down Pennsylvania Avenue, a bank sign kept winking that it was 26 degrees this morning as construction workers stamped frigid feet outside the White House and prepared to install four solar heating units in the reviewing stand where President-elect Carter will watch his inaugural parade.

HONG KONG, Friday, Jan. 7 The Tibet radio said today that Chiang Ching and three other disgraced members of the Chinese Politburo should be put on public trial tomorrow on the first anniversary of the death of Prime Minister Chou En-lai for having persecuted him to death.

A police captain was fined a record $51,500 yesterday after he pleaded no contest to charges of taking bribes for overlooking gambling violations in Har- lem between 1967 and 1971. However, he was permitted to retire with a pension of $25,000 a year.

Jewelry valued at $110,000 was stolen from two different rooms on the fifth floor of the Plaza Hotel yesterday. More than $100,000 in jewelry was taken from the hotel suite of Ravi Tikkoo, a 44-year-old shipowner who heads and owns the Globtik Group of Companies based in London.

With the tempo of Christmas buying quickening as last month progressed, many of the nation's major chains turned in strong performances for December. Some retail executives said the pace of buying reflected a return of consumer confidence.

Often these nights, the wind comes down the stretch faster than the horses at Yonkers Raceway and the Meadowlands. It is the winter of discontent in local harness racing.

Long Island City's nickname is the Stars, but it is experience and not star power that has brought L.I.C, to the top of its Queens division in basketball this season. Coach Floyd Bank has three starters and the first substitute returning from last season's team, which reached the Public Schools Athletic League semifinals.

"Music Magic: A Musical Odyssey" is the newest presentation at the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation's Billie Holiday Theater, which is not only Off Off Broadway, but off all traditional theatrical tracks as well.

MADRID, Jan. 6 (Reuters) Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany met Prime Minister Adolfo Su rez for the first time tonight after being briefed by the Spanish opposition on demands for amnesty and recognition of all political parties.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 6 (AP) Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. said today that he would veto any death penalty bill sent to him by the California Legislature.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 6 The former Governor of Puerto Rico raised the possibility yesterday that President Ford's proposal to grant statehood to the island may have been instigated by the Department of the Interior in an effort to gain control of oil deposits that may be off the island's north coast.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 President Ford was uncharacteristically snappish when somebody asked him recently why he had not left the delicate issue of Puerto Rican statehood for the incoming President, Jimmy Carter, to handle.

PRAGUE, Jan. 6 The recent arrest of a former Czechoslovak official on espionage charges is being linked in official accounts with renewed allegations of United States intelligence activity against Czeschoslovakia and the Soviet Union.

ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 6 Aspen is not talking as much about Claudine Longet as it is about snow. The other night, when diners at the Ute City Banque Restaurant saw the first tentative flakes in weeks begin to fall, they broke into spontaneous cheers.

THE NO SMOKING Playhouse, an intimate and unpretentious Off Off Broadway theater, specializes in new plays and new old plays, such as its current production, Dion Boucicault's "Forbidden Fruit," a relic that has been dusted off and adapted by George Wolf Reily, (who also plays a minor role).
MOSCOW, Jan. 6 (Reuters) The Communist-bloc economic association, Comecon, has announced plans to build a nuclear power station in Cuba, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

The New York City Board of Estimate voted by a narrow margin last night to retain an 8 percent ceiling on the mortgage interest paid by residents of the Cadman Towers cooperative complex in Brooklyn Heights.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Jan. 6 The Suffolk County Legislature's leadership today formed a committee to investigate the effects of oil drilling off the county's South Shore, but backed off from its earlier proposal that such a committee sever negotiations with oil companies that want to drill there.
Bruce Jenner, who set a world record of 8,618 points in winning the decathlon at the Olympic Games in Montreal last summer, was named yesterday as male athlete of 1976 by The Associated Press.
Any weekend in New York is a potential jazz festival, but this weekend offers an abundance of riches for the jazz lover, with every stylistic persuasion well represented.
Figures released by the New York Federal Reserve Bank yesterday showed that the Federal Reserve Board had achieved or exceeded its targets for the growth of the nation's money supply during 1976.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 6 (Reuters) Australia took just half an hour today to wrap up the second cricket test against Pakistan in the three-match series.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration proposed today a crackdown on an alleged impurity in saccharin, the last artificial sweetener still allowed in food.
NORFOLK, Conn. Is a Jew less a Jew if, on a warm summer sabbath in the hills of northwestern Connecticut, he happens to go for a swim?

NEWARK, Jan. 6 (AP) Lawyers representing Rockland Electric Company's 49,000 customers in northern New Jersey told the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners yesterday that the company's request for a $7.9 million rate increase was too high.
Soybean futures prices ended sharply higher yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade after a slow start.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 6 (UPI) The City Council has voted to extend a ban on genetic research for another month.

PARACUELLOS DEL JARAMA, Spain, Jan. 5 Tucked away near the airport in the anonymous, half-rural eastern fringes of Madrid, the deserted cemetery and its withered memorial wreaths seem irretrievably locked in the past.
The stock market, aided by strength in some of the recently depressed bluechip and glamour issues, posted its first gain of the year yesterday in slower trading.
LISBON, Jan. 6 An angry crowd of workers and intellectuals protested today against the indulgence shown by the military courts toward the political police of the former Portuguese dictatorship.
LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP) The International Coffee Organization announced today that it was starting a worldwide campaign to sell coffee at a time of spiraling prices and an organized boycott.

HANOVER, West Germany, Jan. 6 (AP) Bishop Hanns Lilje, former president of the Lutheran Church's world movement and a noted German theologian, died in a hospital today after a heart attack. He was 77 years old and had retired in 1969.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 6 (AP) Two of the largest vessels in the United States tuna boat fleet are switching to foreign flags in the face of a Government ban on killing porpoise while fishing for yellowfintuna.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) President Ford today nominated four new ambassadors, including Malcolm Toon, for the Soviet Union, Jack B. Olson, the Bahamas, Lowell Bruce Lanigen, Malta, and Donald R. Norland, Lesotho, Botswana and Swaziland.
The New York City Police Department is planning to begin using one-man radio car patrols this spring, Commissioner Michael J. Codd disclosed yesterday.
The next time a professional tennis player hits a ball at a linesman, throws a racquet or arrives late for a match at Forest Hills, he may receive more than a casual warning.

HARTSDALE, N. Y. Outside Maryanne Fishberg's appartment at the Wildwood housing complex in Hartsdale, the tricycles are lined up three deep. In the parking lot below, a husband unloads groceries from the back of a station wagon while his wife walks a few feet ahead, pushing a stroller. This is station wagon country, nursery school country and, most of all, wedding ring country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 An investigative panel has found that the Teton Dam in Idaho burst last June 5 because of deficiencies in design and instrumentation that were rooted in a failure to anticipate the many possibilities for trouble "inherent in the situation."

KARIBA, Rhodesia, Jan. 6(AP) Barely 60 miles from this lakeside resort town where vacationers laze beneath the sun alongside swimming pools, scores of black nationalist guerrillas have been crossing into northern Rhodesia from Zambia to press their fight for racial majority rule.

Staff members of Co-ed Magazine, a church choir in Port Jervis, N.Y., and the Aloha Study Club of Manhattan were among the donors yesterday to the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
The New York Stock Exchange made its first move yesterday in the direction of establishing an option market.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 6 Mel Patrick Lynch and Dominic P. Byrne, who were convicted last month of extorting $2.3 million from Edgar M. Bronfman but acquitted on charges of kidnapping Mr. Bronfman's son, Samuel 2d, were sentenced today to serve at least four and three years, respectively.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 At least one shake-up in a major committee chairmanship was reported today as Stanley Steingut, the Speaker of the Assembly, chose Stanley Fink to be majority leader, as had been expected, and began the process of reorganizing the Assembly's expanded Democratic majority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6, (AP) House leaders said today that they doubted the committee investigating the assassinations of President Kennedy and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. would get the $6.5 million first-year budget it requested.

At 2:30 this Sunday afternoon an undetermined number of assorted New Yorkers, some of them old friends but some unknown to the others, will assemble near the change booth at the BMT subway exit at Seventh Avenue and 55th Street.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 6 A Federal laboratory reported today that blood samples from three victims of an unknown illness that struck an American Legion convention in Philadelphia last summer showed signs of recent infection by chlamydia, the group of infectious agents that includes psittacosis, popularly known as parrot fever.

"My name is Otis Simmons and my two legs got to stay on I won't have the operation, I got to cure my own self," a 58-year-old Alabama-born derelict said at a bedside hearing called by Justice Hilda G. Schwartz of State Supreme Court, at Roosevelt Hospital yesterday.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 6 For Bob Gilder, this is where it all began a year ago one of the most successful rookie seasons on the professional golf tour.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Despite heavy support from Democrats and special interest groups, Dr. Theodore Cooper has been told that he cannot keep his job as Assistant Secretary for Health in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare when the Carter administration takes over on Jan. 20.

TEGUCIGALPA, Hondouras Jan. 6 (AP) A pro-Govenment newspaper said today that several high military officers had bee assigned to new positions this week to avoid a coup planned by young leftist officers and civilians.

In a statement aimed at Venezuela's Mines Minister, the Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it was trying to use more lower-cost Saudi Arabian oil to reduce reliance on higher-priced oil from Venezuela and 10 other oil-producing countries.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 6 Puerto Rico's children received their Christmas presents today as a controversy went on over the steady encroachment being made by Santa Claus into the role of the Three Kings.

GLOUCESTER, N.J., Jan. 6 Governor Byrne went to the site of last week's Delaware River oil spill today to sign the most comprehensive state legislation in the country on cleanup of spills and compensation for damages.

MOSCOW, Jan. 6 In a sparsely furnished room of a drab Moscow communal apartment, Irina Astakhova McClellan waits, as she has for 28 months. She is waiting to join her husband, an American professor in Virginia, and her prospects in 1977 look as bleak as in 1976.

NEW YORK AND LOS ANGELES have become firmly established as the world capitals of pop music, headquarters of the major record companies, recording studios and music publications and homes of many of the artists. Nashville continues to hold its own as the center of the country music industry. But Memphis, which was the prime source for soul music 10 years ago and the birthplace of rock-and-roll during the 1950's, has been ominously quiet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The United States International Trade Commission voted today to recommend to the President a new form of import restraint on foreign shoes, but the commission chose the mildest remedy, with the lowest estimated cost to the consumer, of the several proposals before it.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 6 The Soviet Union has sent Secretary General Kurt Waldheim a note that United Nations officials interpret as a warning to the incoming Carter administration against continuing to discourage Soviet diplomatic participation in Middle East peacemaking efforts.

HONG KONG, Jan. 6 China's oil production increased 13 percent last year, the Chinese press agency, Hsinhua, said today, a claim that analysts here calculate, gave China a total output of 625.8 million barrels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 President Ford's ski-slope invitation to Puerto Rico to become the 5lst state was the most sudden and surprising notion he has had since he liberated Eastern Europe from the Soviet Union, but it has certain possible advantages.

PABLO NERUDA's "Memoirs," published today, encompasses the world of Latin American politics, the Spanish Civil War, the bonds of International poetry, the evolving nature of Marxism, Communism and Fascism and the role of the engaged artist balancing literature and diplomacy.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 6 (Reuters) Top-seeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina moved into the semifinal round of the $200,000 Australian open tennis tournament today by eliminating Ross Case, 6-4, 7-5, 1-6, 6-3. His powerful display dispelled any doubts about his ability to handle grass courts.

Staff members of Co-ed Magazine, a church choir in Port Jervis, N.Y., and the Aloha Study Club of Manhattan were among the donors yesterday to the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Uganda has begun excavation work in Manhattan for a 15-story headquarters for its United Nations delegation that would be three floors higher than its next-door neighbor, the building of the United States Mission.

Ellis Wilson, a widely known artist who was a Guggenheim. Fellow in 1944 and 1945, died Sunday in French Hospital after an illness of two weeks. He was 76 years old and lived at Cornish Arms Home for Adults, 315 West 23d Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) The Government said today that it had picked Barstow, Calif., as the site for the country's first solar "power tower" electric generating plant.

JEAN ANOUILH's comedy "The Waltz of the Toreadors" seems to b emerging, as it were, as one of the most substantially insubstantial of his plays. It new production by the Hartford Stage Company, in Hartford, confirmed all its scatterbrained charms and philosophical simplicities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency proposed today a lowering of the amount of radiation the general public can receive from intentional discharge of radioactive material by nuclear power production.

Mayor Beame formally presented yes terday his program to close New York City's remaining budget deficit, saying it would not "sap" the city's ability to deliver vital services, despite a projected reduction of an additional 7,500 employees through attrition rather than through layoffs.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 6 (AP) The Venezuelan Cabinet resigned today to allow President Carlos Andr s P rez to reorganize his administration.
ROME, Jan. 6 The Italian Government failed today to persuade union leaders to agree to curb wages, now rising here faster than in any other European nation.

Uganda has begun excavation work in Manhattan for a 15-story headquarters for its United Nations delegation that would be three floors higher than its next-door neighbor, the building of the United States Mission.

The Internal Revenue Service was going about its business tightening up the tests for whether a business entity is truly a partnership rather than a corporation. Then the housing people heard what was going on and in the last few days "telephone wires started burning across the country," as one outsider put it.

TRENTON, Jan. 6 The Assembly minority leader, Thomas H. Kean of Elizabeth, filed the necessary forms with the State Election Law. Enforcement Commission today to establish the campaign organization for his com- ing bid for the Republican gubernatorial nomination. Mr. Kean, 40 years old, who was chairman of Mr. Ford's successful New Jersey campaign, will become the sec- ond major Republican contender for the gubernatorial nomination when he formally announces his candidacy, possibly next week.

Edita Gruberova, a Czech soprano, made her Metropolitan Opera debut on Wednesday night as the Queen of the Night in Mozart's "Die Zauberfl te." She proved her competence by negotlating the coloratura of the arias securely and with clear articulation. Her top notes were in place and in tune.

For a company that was recently criticized for its heavy reliance on guest stars, American Ballet Theater is offering a highly democratic season at the City Center 55th Street Theater this month. During this weekend alone there will be six debuts in leading roles by the company's regular members.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (AP) Derek Sanderson, the flamboyant center, was placed on N.H.L. waivers today by the St. Louis Blues, apparently a result of a personality clash with the Blues' coach and general manager, Emile Francis.

For Rembrandts, the Metropolitan. For Picassos, the Museum of Modern Art. For fire engines, the Museum of the City of New York. For arrowheads, the Museum of the American Indian. But for tugboats? The South Street Seaport Museum, naturally.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Andrei A. Amalrik, the Russian dissident, told a United States commission today that President-elect Jimmy Carter should use the Soviet desire for American technology, credits and grain to force the Kremlin to comply with the human rights provisions of the 1975 Helsinki accord on EastWest relations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 A block down Pennsylvania Avenue, a bank sign kept winking that it was 26 degrees this morning as construction workers stamped frigid feet outside the White House and prepared to install four solar heating units in the reviewing stand where President-elect Carter will watch his inaugural parade.
One investment approach recommended for individuals is the purchase of shares of small, well-managed companies that are strategically situated in areas of rapid growth.
The nation's two largest steel companies appeared yesterday to be at least cautiously optimistic about this year's steel production.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 6 (UPI) Mike Miley, a utility infielder for the California Angels, was killed today in a one-car accident near the Louisiana State University campus. Investigators said Miley, 23 years old, was thrown from his car and run over by the vehicle. He was alone in the car at the time and the police are investigating the accident.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 6 Two Syrians and a Palestinian were put to death by hanging at dawn today a few hours after Syria announced that the three had been convicted in a series of bomb attacks carried out with the complicity of Iraq.

NEWARK, Jan. 6 Letters from the late Bishop John Neumann, who was approved for sainthood last month, and the 19th century diaries of Archbishop James Roosevelt Bayley, first Bishop of New Jersey, were among the items from the archives of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark formally turned over today to Seton Hall University for their "care and maintenance."

HAMBURG, West Germany, Jan. 6 (AP) A Soviet fighter pilot who defected to the West told American interrogators that Soviet combat pilots were under orders to make suicide attacks rather than bail out in wartime emergencies, according to the illustrated magazine Stern.

One line from an old song keeps popping into mind when the chatter at cocktail parties or bridge games gets around to the current topic of the day, the recent stratospheric rise in the price of coffee.
Helped by record production of heating oil last week, the sharp decline in inventories of heating oil known as distillates abated somewhat, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

HARTSDALE, N.Y. Outside Maryanne Fishberg's appartment at the Wildwood housing complex in Hartsdale, the tricycles are lined up three deep. In the parking lot below, a husband unloads, groceries from the back of a station wagon while his wife walks a few feet ahead, pushing a stroller. This is station wagon country, nursery school country and, most of all, wedding ring country.

Mayor Beame formally presented yesterday his program to close New York City's remaining budget deficit, saying it would not "sap" the city's ability to deliver vital services, despite a projected reduction of an additional 7,500 employees through attrition rather than through layoffs.

Meeting for the first time since the death of Alex Rose, Liberal Party officials last night scrapped his last legacy, a special committee to look into the party's role in the mayoral race, for fear that such a committee would be too divisive at this time.
The appointment of 50 jurors for the Pulitzer Prize awards in journalism for work published in 1976 was announced yesterday by Dr. William J. McGill, the president of Columbia University.
WASHINGTON Defenders of current aviation regulation warn of a "naive and dangerous" idea: reforming the 1938 Federal regulatory laws to make air transportation more competitive.
The New York City Police Department is planning to begin using one-man radio car patrols this spring, Commissioner Michael J. Codd disclosed yesterday.
The McLain Family Band has played in 40 foreign countries, not counting Greenwich Village, where it will play tomorrow night.
NORFOLK, Conn. Is a Jew less a Jew if, on a warm summer sabbath in the hills of northwestern Connecticut, he happens to go for a swim?

The great wave of enthusiasm stirred by Prince Alexis Obolensky and the other high rollers seems to have passed, but the rattle of dice cups is still loud in the land. The people who claim to keep track of such things say that 20 million Americans are now regular backgammon players, which, if true, means the game is at least on a par with chess if not quite to the level of popularity of bridge.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The Republican Party still riven by factionalism, has made little or no progress toward choosing new leaders in the two months since the 1976 election.

BECAUSE IT SEEMS to be losing a long tax battle with the Federal Government, the Frick Collection, that elegant man- sion of masterpieces on upper Fifth Avenue, is charging admission for the first time in its 58-year history. Last Tuesday, adults began paying $1; students and senior citizens 50 cents, for the privilege of gazing on the peerless works by Rembrandt, El Greco, Vermeer, Van Dyck Co. that they had long admired for free.

DETROIT, Jan. 6 (UPI) A Federal grand jury has resumed its investigation of the disappearance in July 1975 of James R, Hoffa, former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, amid reports that investigators are aiming for a "public resolution" of the case by next summer.
LAKE CARMEL, N.Y., Jan. 6 More than 800 disgruntled taxpayers squeezed into a roadside restaurant in northern Putnam County tonight to find out how to become tax-exempt ministers.

The outstanding books published in 1976 in four categories fiction, poetry nonfiction and criticism were selected yesterday in a meeting at the Algonquin Hotel by the National Book Critics Circle, a 250-member professional organization of full-time book critics and editors.

A memorial service will be held Jan. 19 for Dr. Hans-Lukas Teuber, head of the department of psychology at Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a leading authority on the relationship between the brain and behavior, who disappeared Tuesday while swimming in the waters off Virgin Gorda in the British Virgin Islands.

A judge of Civil Court in Brooklyn was indicted yesterday on charges that he lied to a special grand jury about his participation in a series of illegal loans before and during his tenure on the bench.

The mounting interest in who will now head the Federal Bureau of Investigation obscures a prior question: What should rule the F.B.I.? Just how committed is the new Administration to impressing the framework of law on an institution that has for years been placed beyond the reach of the law by Presidents, by Congress and by the founding director, J. Edgar Hoover.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 6 Bloomingdale's has decided to close its 30-yearold store on Main Street here its largest suburban branch largely because of competition from one of its newest and largest branches, several miles away in White Plains.

IMAGINE in the middle of winter strolling through a lush garden, the air scented with jasmine, camellias in bloom and goldfish swimming in a pond flecked with lily pads. Bermuda? Cuernavaca? A dream? No New Jersey. Only 36 miles from New York City, the Duke Gardens in Somerville, N.J., offer winter-weary metropolitan area residents a remembrance of springs past without the accompanying cost that getting away from it all usually requires.

Elizabeth Swados is a rare bird. Only 25 years old, she has composed scores for such avant-garde theatrical directors as Andrei Serban and Peter Brook. She is now writing the music for Mr. Serban's first two Lincoln Center ventures with Joseph Papp, "The Cherry Orchard" and "Agamemnon." And she has conceived, composed and directed "Nightclub Cantata," a new musical revue that opens Off Broadway Sunday night at the Village Gate.

NEWARK, Jan. 6 The State Board Public Utility Commissioners today ordered the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, the state's largest power company to implement, for the first time in New Jersey, a reduced electric rate for major users in an attempt to attract new industry.

The new Soviet chief delegate to the United Nations presented his credentials yesterday, then called a news conference and answered questions in American English. Which was understandable, for the diplomat, Oleg Troyanovsky, spent his teen-age years in the United States, when his father was the first Soviet Ambassador here, and attended a Quaker school in Washington.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (UPI) William Leonard, Chicago Tribune nightlife columnist, died today in Augustana Hospital where he was admitted Dec. 28 suffering from a suspected stoke. He was 64 years old.

Dr. Theodore Cooper, the Assistant Secretary for Health of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, said yesterday that he would recommend easing new restrictions on the immigration of foreign medical school graduates to prevent a threatened disruption of hospital care in this country.

Mayor Beame's new package of budget cuts to take effect during the coming fis cal year will have the sharpest impact on the city's Police Department, Human Resources Administration and the Board of Education, according to projections released yesterday.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 6 (AP) Four gunmen kicked in the door of Lady Spencer-Churchill's resort home today, threatened the niece of the late Sir Winston Churchill with a knife and shot a guest, the police had reported.

PARIS, Jan. 6 The Socialist leader, Fran ois Mitterrand, attacked the administration of President Val ry Giscard d'Estaing today for its handling of the case of the murder on Christmas Eve of Prince Jean de Broglie, a once-prominent political figure and supporter of Mr. Giscard d'Estaing's public career.

If you're the kind of a woman who'd like to receive a surprise package occasionally containing $14 worth of supermarket products for $5.98 (plus $1.75 for shipping and handling) then the G.R.I. Corporation has a deal for you membership in S.A.V.E.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked the Supreme Court today to rule quickly that the courts have no jurisdiction in the Justice Department's antitrust suit against the Bell System.

Tonight is opening night at the opera in the Bronx. The 10-year-old Bronx Opera, which has developed quite a respectable reputation for itself, will perform "La Traviata" at 8 P.M. at the Bronx High School of Science, 75 West 205th Street. It will be in typical Bronx Opera style a full production, in English, with orchestra and chorus.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 The New York State Public Service Commission has approved the New York Telephone Company's proposal to publish joint husband-and-wife entries in its directories, but the Commission stipulated that there be no charge for such listings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Two former members of the Federal Power Commission Lawrence J. O'Connor Jr. and John A. Carver Jr. have been denied permission to testify as witnesses for natural gas producers in a case before the commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 President-elect Carter has selected former Senator Gale W. McGee, Democrat of Wyoming, to be the United States representative in the Organization of American States, high Latin American diplomats said today.

Now comes ageismthe degrading of old people through stereotypes.
A sextet of California and Texas stars held a substantial advantage in the second quarter of play in the international team semifinal playoff in Houston yesterday.

Perhaps no gardening task is easier or potentially more hazardous to the pocketbook than spending a winter's evening in front of a fire reading the tea leaves of seed and nursery catalogues to see what the future garden might hold.

The staff of New York magazine marched off the job yesterday in a show of support for Clay S. Felker, editor of the magazine, and his attempts to prevent a takeover by Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The World Bank has sent its first mission to Vietnam since the reunified country was accepted as a bank member in September, a spokesman said today.

TRENTON, Jan. 7 State Senate President Matthew Feldman, who faces a challenge on Tuesday from Senate Republicans who want to oust him from his leadership post, received more bad news today when the State Division of Alcoholic Beverage Control filed a complaint against his family-owned liquor company.

WASHINGTON Jan. 7 President Ford sent Congress today a lengthy message on the nation's energy situation, asking for quick action to assure "an adequate and secure supply of energy at reasonable prices."

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 7 Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Executive, today named the five members of his newly created Industrial Development Agency, which was established to promote business and industrial development in the county.

MIAMI BEACH Jan. 7 (UPI) William D. Pawley, world financier, philanthropist, ambassador and special envoy for several Presidents, shot himself to death at his exclusive Sunset Island home today, the police said.
Dr. Nancy Acton, a research associate in chemistry at Columbia University, was married yesterday morning to Ronald Roth, a professor of chemistry at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 7 (AP) A rescue team struggled through a rugged canyon today in search of a missing private jet carrying the 82-year-old mother of Frank Sinatra.

Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher who acquired The New York Post last week, gained control of the New York Magazine Company yesterday after reaching an out-of-court settlement with Clay S. Felker, the founder of the magazine.

In the NBC "special" an violence the other night several network wizards argued that their nocturnal production of mayhem is a simple case of giving people what they want. The trouble with this argument is that it assumes that people know what they want.
SEA CLIFF, L.I., Jan. 7 Amid snow and song, ancient rites and sumptuous food, Christmas came last night to the Russian Orthodox community here.

In an unusual display of cooperation over an ordinarily divisive issue, labor and industry jointly awarded half a millon dollars yesterday to Mount Sinai Medical Center here to finance an attempt to find a cure to an occupationally caused cancer.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 7 (AP) Attorneys for Patricia Hearst asked a Federal appeals court today to overturn her bank robbery conviction on grounds that the trial judge had made errors "which all but dictated the verdict of guilty."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 The Senate will hold at least three sets of hearings on Soviet military ability and strategic objectives this winter, Congressional aides said today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 7 The closure of Bloomingdale's oldest branch store, in downtown New Rochelle, appeared today to have prompted new support for a redevelopment plan linked, in part, to the department store.

PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 7 President-elect Carter and Democratic Congressional leaders said today that they were in general agreement on an array of programs to stimulate the economy by increased spending to create jobs, changes in the income tax system to lower payments by persons of low and moderate income and for businesses and by a "oneshot" tax rebate for all taxpayers in 1977.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 7 (AP) Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan announced today in the National Assembly that general elections would take place March 7. Mr. Bhutto said the Assembly would be dissolved Monday to pave the way for election of a 216-member house for the next five-year term.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP) The dollar rallied today to recoup all its losses against major European currencies earlier this week. The price of gold rose slightly after sharp drops over the previous two days.

Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, advised top city and state officials yesterday to reject, at least for the time being, the latest demands laid down by the banks as a condition for their helping New York City to balance its budget and pay off its short-term notes.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 Bob McAdoo was in the starting lineup and Spencer Haywood was able to play 30 minutes with a protective leg shield covering the trouble spot on his left leg. All the other Knicks were comparatively healthy, so things should have been dandy.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 7 The New York Nets recovered some of their home-court intensity but none of their winning ways tonight at the Nassau Coliseum. They dropped their seventh straight game, this one by 85-82 to the Los Angeles Lakers.

HONG KONG, Jan. 7 Since his death last Jan. 8, Chou En-lai has emerged as the real folk hero of China, and has triumphed over his longtime antagonists and tormentors, the "leftist" group around Chian Ching, the widow of Mao Tse-tung.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 Governor Carey's effort to compel full financial disclosure from all top-level state employees received a setback today when Justice Harold J. Hughes of State Supreme Court declared unconstitutional the Governor's conflict-of-interest regulations.

PLAINS, Ga., Jan. 7 President-elect Carter and Democratic Congressional leaders said today that they were in general agreement on an array of programs to stimulate the economy by increased spending to create jobs, changes in the income tax system to lower payments by persons of low and moderate income and for businesses and by a "oneshot" tax rebate for all taxpayers in 1977.

CBS Inc. yesterday announced the company's acquisition of Fawcett Publica tions, one of the last family-run publishing giants, for $50 million in cash. A CBS spokesman called the sale one of the largest cash transactions in publishing history.
Natalia Roslavleva, a leading Soviet dance historian and critic whose writings are well known in dance circles in the West, died of cancer Monday in Moscow. She was 69 years old.

MANILA, Jan. 7 (AP) President Ferdinand E. Marcos today branded as a "provocation" a State Department report that human rights had been violated by his martial-law regime in the Philippines. President Marcos also said treaties with the United States could be terminated if they were no longer in his country's best interests.

HONG KONG, Jan. 7 Since his death last Jan. 8, Chou En-lai has emerged as the real folk hero of China, and has triumphed over his longtime antagonists and tormentors, the "leftist" group around Chiang Ching, the widow of Mao Tse-tung.
Dr. Harry Goldblatt, a widely acclaimed pioneer in blood pressure research, died Thursday in a Rochester hospital of pulmonary edema. He was 86 years old and lived in Rochester.

BONN, Jan. 7 Chancellor Helmut Schmidt is showing an uncharacteristic anxiety about the economic future and his fears are shared by some of his top advisers and West German industrialists. With increasing urgency, a number of them say they are counting on the Carter administration to take immediate steps to keep the Western world from sliding into a new recession.

VIENNA, Jan. 7 In Eastern Europe, it's not unusual to find a major American corporation doing business out of a hotel room. The scarcity of office space for foreign business is a major handicap to East-West trade.

"Puerto Rican Country Music," the title of a concert held at Town Hall Wednesday evening, sounds at first like an improbable mishmash. On second thought, one decides that the "country" part refers to the Puerto Rican countryside, and not to Nashville and bluegrass, but this is not entirely true. The fact is, the "Musica Jibara," or mountain music of Puerto Rico, has much in common with bluegrass, especially in its instrumental manifestations.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 Los Angeles, which prides itself on having developed a world-class symphony orchestra in the last decade, is now enjoying a first-class old-fashioned war between critic and musical entrepreneur.
A personal contribution for $250 has been received from Terence Cardinal Cooke for the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Rose DePalma, dialing directly from New York, talked again yesterday with another retired telephone operator, Isabel Ivy Baker, in London. Fifty years before, they had been among the first operators to establish commercial telephone connections across the Atlantic.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 7 Imprisoned political dissidents, some of whom began jail life last spring with 10 days of nonstop interrogation, are being subjected to a spartan life of solitary confinement in small cells with meager, monotonous meals and no furniture. Their wooden-floored cells are said to be so cold during the bitter Korean winter that eggs and milk brought by relatives freeze solid.

Dick Hyman, the jazz pianist who has made a specialty of exploring the works of such early jazz keyboard men as Scott Joplin, James P. Johnson and Jelly Roll Morton, has now moved ahead chronologically to the music of the 1930's. A quintet he is leading at Michael's Pub is, according to the club's advertisements, featuring "the 1930 sounds and music of the little bands of Fats Waller, Louis Armstrong, John Kirby, etc."
EASTMAN, Ga., Jan. 7 (AP) William Stuckey, who built a chain of candy shops and restaurants from a $35 pecan business, died yesterday. He was 67 years old.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 He's always at the Super Bowl or World Series, and it's as if he were invisible. He blends into the scenery. He even moves past the ticket takers without them asking for a ticket or even asking questions.
BOSTON, Jan. 7 The Panamanian flag tanker Grand Zenith sank in the Atlantic Ocean off Cape Cod, the Coast Guard said today. Two life jackets from the vessel were found.

ST.-TROPEZ, France, Jan. 3 There are three kinds of people at the tip of this little peninsula jutting into the Mediterranean halfway between Nice and Marseilles. BOSTON, Jan. 9 By the latest count, 499 South Africans were killed in the racial trouble last year. Most of them were black school children, and many died of police bullets in the back. In terms of comparative population, it is as if several thousand American children had been shot.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 Honeybun perched seductively on the edge of a bathtub at the end of a custom-made van. Her long red hair fell gracefully over shoulders that were being slowly massaged by strong hands. Mantovani music and cologne filled the air. Overcome with excitement. Honeybun barked.
ANKARA, Turkey Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union was supposed to visit Turkey in mid- November. Then the trip was put off to the end of November, and then to midDecember.

Aristid von Wurtzler and his New York Harp Ensemble proved at least one thing at their concert Saturday night in Alice Tully Hall. Bit by bit, Governor Carey is hacking away at the political encrustments on the state judiciary. The measure passed for the first time at the ragged end of last year's session. It must carry again and be approved by the electorate before it can take effect.

ST. PAUL From the control room at the Ashland Oil refinery glimpses of the Mississippi River, near-frozen and steaming in the below-zero cold, poke through the trees. Nothing moves on the river during these frigid Minnesota days. But increasingly, in warmer weather, barges laden with crude oil from as far as Saudi Arabia travel north to unload at refineries along the river's banks. Fuel supplies from the south are becoming increasingly important.

Frederick B. Dent, President Ford's chief trade negotiator, urged Japan yesterday to permit import of more beef now that "overfishing has become a problem throughout the world and most maritime nations are in the process of extending their economic control to 200 miles seaward."

BASEL, Switzerland, Jan. 10 (Reuters) Central bankers from leading industrial nations set up a $3 billion plan today to help Britain cover any withdrawals of official sterling balances held by foreigners in London.

We shall soon have an Administration in Washington that is pledged to give human rights a central place in its foreign policy. We welcome that change from recent practice, understanding that it raises some extraordinarily difficult questions.

Senator Carl T. Curtis plans to retire at the end of 1978 after spending 40 years in Congress. Mr. Curtis, who is 71 years old, said yesterday that he was making his plans known now "so that Nebraskans will have ample time to nominate and elect a successor of their own choosing."

PRAGUE, Jan. 10 Pavel Kohout, whose play "Poor Murderer" closed recently on Broadway, was detained by the Czechoslovak security police today a few hours after his wife had been dragged into a police car outside their home.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) Austria, France and the Netherlands joined they Inter-American Development Bank today increasing to 37 countries the bank's membership. Finland and Italy are expected to join soon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 A black woman who began life as the daughter of a dining car waiter spent this morning trying to persuade a panel of 11 male United States Senators that she sympathized enough with the poor and downtrodden to be the next Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

MOUNT HOLLY, Jan. 10 A Brooklyn woman shouting "Hallelujah!" was arraigned today on manslaughter charges after her 21-year-old daughter died yesterday of asphyxiation while reportedly being ridden of "demons."

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 Sheriff Richard Hongisto and his deputy, Under Sheriff James Denman, were sentenced today to five days in jail and fined $500 each for their failure to evict tenants from a downtown hotel here last October.
NEWARK, Jan. 10 Albert Sommers, senior vice president and chief economist of the Conference Board, a business research group, had the best kind of news for the business community today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 Charles L. Schultze, the chairman-designate of the Council of Economic Advisers, said today that he expected to be able to see some results from the Carter administration's economic stimulus package by summer, and possibly sooner.

The two personal attendants for the late Howard R. Hughes, who have disclosed a tragic story of his last secretive, ailing years, said yesterday that they did so because their allegiance had been to him and because they considered that aides who directed the billionaire's empire had manipulated him often without his knowledge.

DETROIT, Jan. 10 (AP) Bill Collins scored a short-handed goal in the first period and the Washington Capitals went on to defeat the Detroit Red Wings, 2-0, in the first shutout of Bernie Wolfe's National Hockey League career as a goalie.

A special financial committee that was set up by Mayor Beame has tentatively concluded that the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation can cut its financial deficit without imposing the wholesale job layoffs that were threatened last year.

WASHINGTON, JAN. 10 (AP) The winter wheat crop planted last fall was suffering from dry weather and severe cold in parts of the nation's breadbasket as of Jan. 1, the Agriculture Department said today.

ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, Jan. 10 The wealthy emirate of Abu Dhabi, which has copied Saudi Arabia's low oil price policy, does not intend to lift production ceilings and order major increases in oil output this year, wellplaced officials maintained here today.

Mayor Beame and City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin have agreed to a preliminary plan to comply with some of the strict demands laid down by banks for marketing future city bonds, but to resist the banks "suggestion" for an extension in the life of the State Emergency Financial Control Board.

Charles M. White, former head of the Republic Steel Corporation and one of the industry's most militant and articulate spokesmen, died yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 85 years old and had been in failing health for a naumber of years.

DEERFIELD, Ill., Jan. 9 Deerfield is a suburban community of 20,000 where the median annual income is $27,500, where the mean cost of a single family house exceeds $80,000, where a bare 0.03 percent of the residents are at poverty level and unemployment is below 3 percent and where in one year 578 incidents of vandalism by Deerfield youngsters were reported to the police.

Over objections from physicians, a State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that a 58-year-old derelict whose gangrenous leg had been scheduled for amputation had the right to refuse the operation.

Eugene S. Levin, one of the founders of the Minuteman Yacht Club of Westport, Conn., and an active member of the boating community, died of a heart attack Saturday while swimming off the coast of Puerta Vallarta, Mexico. He was 47 years old.

Donations from 379 persons yesterday to the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund totaled $29,113.03, sending contributions over the $800,000 mark.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 10 Francis T. Purcell, who is in a three-way race for the Republican nomination for Nassau County Executive, is apparently heavily favored by the party's county committeemen, although the actual nominee will be chosen by the electorate in the primary, which is months away.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 10 (AP) Joe McCall scored 19 points and Kevin Bass, 18, including the go-ahead basket in the final two minutes, as lona upset St. John's, 68-66, tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 10 Norway has moved to reopen deadlocked negotiations for a treaty on the law of the sea, summoning a Geneva conference to work on the controversy over deep-sea mining.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman Jr. said today that one major auto maker had tentatively agreed to market a fleet of cars equipped with air bags to acquaint the public with the controversial safety systems.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 10 Colgate football players and coaches want nothing more than another crack at Rutgers and the teams are scheduled to meet next Sept. 10 at Andy Kerr Field in Hamilton, N.Y.
