DETROIT, Jan. 10 The General Motors Corporation announced tonight that it had extended until Feb. 28 its $200 rebate on three of its subcompact car lines and broadened the program to include other slow-selling small cars and trucks.

BERCHTESGADEN, West Germany, Jan. 10 (AP) Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden overtook three Austrians today with the fastest time in the second heat and won a World Cup special slalom. They raced over a treacherous, icy course that eliminated all but 29 of the 83 starters.
Silver and gold futures fell sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange, reflecting traders, reaction to the strong showing of the British pound.
LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Jan. 10 (AP) Plans to stage the 1980 Olympic Winter Games at Lake Placid cleared a giant hurdle today when the Adirondack Park Agency approved a proposal to build a ski jump.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 The United States Justice Department today issued its first guidelines governing participation by American companies in the Arab boycott with the filing of an agreement between the department and the Bechtel Corporation in a Federal District Court here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) The Supreme Court today let stand orders denying New York longshoremen the right to reload containers prepared elsewhere by cargo "consolidators" before the containers are placed on ships.
Hildegarde Hoyt Swift, an author of children's books, died yesterday at a Redland, Calif., nursing home where she had been living for several years. She was 87 years old.

HONG KONG, Jan. 10 The continued turnout of large crowds in Peking to honor Chou En-lai two days after the anniversary of his death, and the appearance of fresh wall posters, some attacking senior leaders, have begun to create a sense of uneasiness among some Chinese.

VIENNA, Jan. 10 The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today concluded agreements with 24 developing nations to provide interest-free loans totaling $111 million. Ellen Marie Barrett, a doctoral student in social ethics and an avowed lesbian, was, ordained as an Episcopal priest last night. The rites were performed by Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York at the Church of the Holy Apostles in Manhattan.

MARGIN FOR ERA A display and sale of posters at the new Ballet, Opera and Theater Gallery, 961 Madison Avenue at 75th Street, should interest browsers and buyers of nostalgia. Some 300 posters are turn-of-thecentury products of the Strobridge Company, known as the Tiffany of Lithographers for its prolific but quality output of wall bills heralding the performing arts from opera to circus. Except in museums and libraries, few Strobridge specimens have survived.

So go the fun and games here this week among the 80 best players in the National Football League who are leisurely preparing for the N.F.L.'s annual Pro Bowl game to be held in Seattle on Monday night.

LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Bob Bruno of Pelham Manor, N.Y., turned in a four-under-par 68 today for a three-round total of 213 and a one-shot lead in the Professional Golfers' Association's national strokeplay championship. Bruno had scores of 74 and 71 during the first two rounds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--In his eloquent and appealing Farewell Address, President Ford emphasized the importance of maintaining and increasing the military power of the United States. When President Eisenhower left office sixteen years ago, he also called for a strong military establishment but emphasized the dangers of letting it get out of hand.

Stephanie, the real-life heroine of "A Very Young Dancer," is neither very young nor a dancer. She is a 10-yearold of some privilege who takes ballet lessons at the School of American Ballet and spends each summer pony-riding in Wyoming. She has been seen in the leading child role in the New York City Ballet production of "The Nutcracker."

Judge Thomas P. Griesa of United States District Court in Brooklyn ordered 26 Suffolk County towns and villages yesterday to commit themselves to building low-cost public housing or risk the loss of their share of $4.2 million in Federal community development aid funds.
Vice President Rockefeller, who has dominated the Republican Party in New York State for nearly 20 years, has told leading Republicans that he will no longer play an active role in the party.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--Hamilton Jordan, the 32-year-old Georgian who has been President-elect Carter's principal administrative and staff assistant since 1970, will apparently retain that status in the White House staff, which will be formally announced tomorrow.

Brig. Gen. William W. Bessell Jr., who retired in 1965 as dean of the United States Military Academy, died yesterday at the Army hospital at West Point. He was 75 years old and lived in Cornwallon-Hudson, N.Y.
Commodity futures trading set a record high for volume in 1976, according to the latest statistical summary issued by the Futures Industry Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--Jimmy Carter intends in the first weeks of his Presidency to press for a solution of the Cyprus dispute and to speed up negotiations for a new Panama Canal treaty, Congressional sources said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (Reuters)-- Thirty-two Senators and four members of the House of Representatives have signed a letter saying that they "deplore and deeply regret" France's release of Abu Daoud.
LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP)--The dollar declined against the British pound today but strengthened slightly against other major European currencies.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 (UPI)--The Senate Republican leadership has decided to follow the lead of the Assembly by increasing each lawmaker's staff allowance by $5,000, a legislative spokesman said today. If the Democrats follow suit, as expected, the total additional cost to the taxpayers would be $300,000.
Federal officials said yesterday that more than half of the Federal money that Mayor Beame is counting on to help close New York City's budget gap might not be forthcoming.

OTTAWA, Jan. 15--A committee of prominent Canadians issued a lengthy report today giving details of what it said was widespread compliance with the Arab boycott of Israel by Canadian Government agencies, banks and other business organizations.

WASHINGTON, Jan.13 (AP)--Commerce Secretary Elliot L. Richardson said today that he would act before leaving office on a $500 million loan guarantee application, that has become complicated by what he has called a questionable commission to a South Korean businessman.

Shearson, Hayden Stone Inc., a stock brokerage firm, yesterday proposed a merger with the Orion Capital Corporation of Parsippany, N.J., that would involve an exchange of new Shearson Hayden Stone common and preferred securities with a value of about $63.5 million for outstanding Orion common shares.

BENNI EFRAT draws in chalk on the screen as his films are projected, which sounds terrible but is, in fact, spellbind ing. In "Putney Bridge," for instance, on top of a chalk pattern already laid down on black paper for a preceding film, he projects a pale, distant view of a London bridge, some boats on the water and boys on the bank skipping stones. That's all.

"THE DREAM," which was only a twinkle in the eye of the producer Joel Schenker when he took an option on a book with that title two yeas ago, will finally arrive on Broadway on March 9. "The Dream" was a book by Lucy Freeman that has been rewritten as a play by Richard Lortz. It is about a detective and an analyst who work together to solve a murder.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13--Representative Andrew Young said today that as the first black appointed chief United States representative at the United Nations he "wouldn't have any problem" about vetoing a resolution to oust the white Government of South Africa from the United Nations.
WASHINGTON--Deep in the recesses of the Department of Housing and Urban Development officials are at work on new Federal regulations tat may significantly arrest housing deterioration in the cities.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 13 (AP) --Tom Gorman, who ousted favored Roscoe Tanner a day earlier, was eliminated from a $75,000 international tennis tournament today. He was beaten by John Alexander of Australia, 6-4, 6-4.

A question-and-answer panel show, with questions far outnumbering answers, is scheduled this morning at Grossinger, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The Treasury reported to Congress today that "there is no indication of widespread debt servicing difficulties," on the part of less-developed countries that do not export oil despite their big buildup of debt in the last three years.

The protest over France's release of the Palestinian suspected of planning the attack on Israelis at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich widened yesterday with calls for boycotts of French goods and travel to France, angry statements by members of Congress and Jewish leaders and the withdrawal of pledges to a new French cultural center.

A State Supreme Court jury in Manhattan yesterday found two former box-office employees of the City Center not guilty of charges of swindling $9,000 from the theater in the 1973-74 season. They had been accused of reporting as unsold tickets that had actually been bought through department stores.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Bert Lance, the man who will supervise Federal spending in the new administration, said today that President-elect Carter's program to stimulate the economy would widen the budget deficit to from $73 billion to $75 billion in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30.
MIAMI, Jan. 14 The 20-day strike of about 5,000 hotel workers, which has affected nine of this area's largest hotels, was settled late today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 14 An extensive survey of attitudes on 400 campuses has documented a major shift among students toward more moderate views on academic policy, race relations and the use of violence to achieve political goals.

The American Stock Exchange has made a settlement with five members associated with the Becker Securities Corporation, the first such action stemming from its investigation of fictitious options trades an the floor. The penalty, agreed to by all parties, is a $5,000 fine and a one-month suspension for each of the members.
SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 14 Federal District Judge Aldon J. Anderson denied tonight a restraining order that would have stayed the Monday morning execution of Gary Mark Gilmore.
Marion Post remembers the "good old days" of freestyle ("don't call it hotdog") skiing. Marion Post, the women's world freestyle ("don't call it hot-dog") skiing champion, is 21 years old.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 14 (UPI) A Federal appeals court declared the Federal death penalty statute unconstitutional today, saying it failed to meet United States Supreme Court standards.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) The Justice Department said today that it would not prosecute Central Intelligence Agency employees who took part in a secret program of opening overseas mail from 1953 to 1973.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Fred C. Ikle, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, disagreed today with President-elect Carter's view that the Ford Administration was at fault for the failure to conclude a treaty with the Soviet Union last year that would limit each side's strategic bombers and long-range missiles.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 14 (UPI) The dollar and sterling closed higher on European money markets today, ending the week with small overall gains against all continental currencies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 In a ceremony marking passage of a major revision of the archaic copyright law of 1909, and in a private meeting with the Librarian of Congress, representatives of the two major professional writers' organizations in the United States the Authors Guild and the Dramatists Guild projected programs to provide for greater economic security and recognition for creators of literary and dramatic works in the legislative and administrative halls of Washington.

The $25,000 Enrico Fermi Award was presented yesterday to Dr. William L. Russell, an international authority on the genetic effects of radiation in mammals. Dr. Russell was born in England but became an American citizen in 1936, shortly after receiving his doctorate from the University of Chicago. LONDON, Jan. 14 Sir Anthony Eden, who won renown as Britain's Foreign Secretary for his stand against fascism in the 1930's but whose career as Prime Minister was wrecked by the Suez invasion of 1956, died in his sleep today at his home in Wiltshire. He was 79 years old.

THE vast majority of homes built in New Jersey since World War II have walls and ceilings made of gypsum board (also referred to as dry wall or Sheetrock, although the latter is actually a brand name for wall paneling). ALBANY, Jan.15 (AP) An association made up of hospitals that do about 95 percent of the surgery in the state recognized the fiscal facts of life this week by recommending that some beds be eliminated and some hospitals be closed.

THE concept of tenure for teachers is simple and basic. Stated succinctly, tenure is a right earned after a long probation ary period. This right protects against arbitrary dismissal for frivolous, malicious or purely political reasons. It insures that so long as a teacher performs his or her duties, he or she is protected against dismissal or reduction in compensation "except for inefficiency, incapacity, or conduct unbecoming a teaching staff member or other just cause."
Graham Washington Jackson was waiting for a funeral cortege to pass on April 12, 1945, when a photograprer took his picture. The photo became world famous.

The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund received a check for $50 last week from the Rev. Dr. Jitsuo Morikawa, Rlverside Church's new minister, along with a letter congratulating the fund for passing the $800,000 mark.

Joung Ja Kim's debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday night showed the young soprano to be capable of achieving some pleasing things as well as displaying much indifferent singing. The voice, often poorly supported, could vacillate between a nonvibrato, instrumental purity and a wide tremolo, and while certain upper tones came through powerfully and cleanly, the lower range seemed undeveloped.

Najeeb E. Halaby, whose problems as chairman of Pan American World Airways included a shortage of air travelers on that airline's 747's, is currently tackling a very different problem in Saudi Arabia: too many travelers.

Deborah Ellen Finehout daughter of Patricia Mason Finehout of Plainfield, N.J., and Robert Milton Finehout of Chicago, was married in Plainfield yesterday afternoon to William Lawrence Ham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Duncan Ham Jr. of Greensboro, N.C.

Mrs. Ernest G. Harris of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Mary Catherine Harris, to Eric Forsythe, son of Henderson Forsythe, the stage and television actor, and Mrs. Forsythe of Tenafly; N.J. The prospective bride, also is a daughter of the late Ernest G. Harris, who was vice president of Durlacher Company.

The January thaw used to be considered an annual event, almost as predictable as an equinox. But weather patterns change, and the prophet who forecasts the thaw now takes his reputation into his hands at a time when his fingers are stiff with cold. It is even risky to predict a January thaw at all. But if there is one, it usually comes about now.

We accept, very easily, Japanese cameras, television sets and cars. Soon, and happily enough, we are going to be accepting, welcoming and loving, Japanese ballerinas. Last summer Yoko Morishita danced Aurora in "The Sleep ing Beauty" and Odette-Odile in "Swan Lake." Friday night at the 55th Street City Center Theater, she made her debut as swanilda with the American Ballet Theater in Enrique Martinez's staging of "Coppelia." It was all sugar, spice and expertise.

Victor D.Solow, a documentary film maker who headed his own concern, Solo Productions, before becoming associated with Francis Thompson Inc. in New York City, died Sunday morning after a heart attack in his home, 525 Cortlandt Avenue, Mamaroneck, N.Y. He was 59 years old.

Repeal of laws that bar aliens from getting New York State licenses in at least seven occupations as physicians, chiropractors, dentists, pharmacists, landscape architects, certified shorthand reporters and masseurs or masseuses is being urged by the New York Civil Liberties Union.

The United States Supreme Court has reaffirmed, in a case involving suburban zoning, a principle that could restrict the Federal judiciary's ability to provide remedies for segregation in housing and schools. The principle is that an official policy having a disproportionately adverse effect on one racial group is not unconstitutional unless discrimination can be shown to be the motive for the policy.

John Watts of the Composers Theater put together an entire program of his own music Friday night at the New School's May Theater on Fifth Avenue. The first halt was mostly electronic and the second half was mostly instrumental, and the first half was easily the more interesting.

A partial solution to one of the drawbacks of methadone maintenance programs may now be at hand in a related drug called methadyl acetate. Unlike methadone, methadyl acetate need not be taken every day: Three times a week are enough. But like methadone, methadyl acetate relieves the symptoms of heroin withdrawal without producing any euphoria.

WASHINGTON, Jan.15 Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary-designate of Health, Education and Welfare Has, selected Eileen Shanahan of The New York Times Washington bureau as assistant secretary for public affairs.

In 1934, Robert Newdick, a young professor of English at Ohio State University, wrote a letter of warm praise to a poet whose work he especially admired. The professor ventured to suggest a "regrouping" of the poet's "Selected Poems" as an aid to students. "Accept," he said, "my personal salute to you as a beauty-and-truth-revealing American poet."

Trees bear the brunt of most ice storms. Certain varieties are more susceptible to damage than others. Black locust is often the hardest hit because its wood is brittle and older trees are often weakened by the ravages of locust borer. Other trees that are fast growing are usually damaged particularly poplars, willows, elms and maples. The sturdier trees are the mighty oaks, sycamores and beech.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 15 Sixty thousand spectators crammed into the national stadium here today to watch black artists and performers from 48 nations in the opening ceremony of the Second World Black and African Festival of Art and Culture.

WASHINGTON, Jan.15 (AP) A former Nixon Administration official was indlcted by a Federal grand pury yesterday for conducting a partisan hiring program in violation of Civil Service rules.

In the empty gloom of Madison Square Garden, the blades of her white figure skates crunched along the ice. As she soared, there was no sound. When she landed, the crunch was heard again.

THERE is usually a charm about stores along a town street that eludes me in shopping centers. Shopping centers are probably marvelous if you are a shopper, but for a stroller they lack the flavor, no matter how ornately designed, that you get sauntering down a street.

LAGOS Nigeria, Jan. 16 That Africa once produced great art is no longer in dispute. What is not so commonly acknowledged is the breadth and vitality of contemporary African culture. This is the hidden message of the Second World Black and African Festival of Arts and Culture, which opened here yesterday.

MOSCOW, Jan. 16 Although the Soviet Union has an elaborate civil defense program so detailed that some city residents know precisely to which coach in which train they are assigned for evacuation a number of Western attaches, foreign diplomats and Russians are skeptical about its effectiveness in helping the country survive a nuclear attack.

Janet House Auchincloss, the widow of Gordon Auchincloss and daughter of Col. Edward M. House, adviser to President Woodrow Wilson, died yesterday afternoon at her home at 950 Park Avenue. She was 89 years old.

Snowbound television viewers lost the chance for a cozy evening with Fay Wray last night when a previously advertised 11 o'clock showing of the 1933 version of "King Kong" was canceled by WORTV (Channel 9), owned by RKO Television.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16 The Federal Bureau of Investigation today arrested a 23-year-old University of California student and charged him with spying for the Soviet Government during the past 18 months.

Two of the nation's most successful tournament players, who stunned the bridge world a week ago when they withdrew from the most important event in American competition at the point of almost certain victory, did so after having been summoned before a special committee to answer accusations of "improprieties."

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 16 Mark Levasseur of Worcester, Mass., doesn't have much time for ski jumping these days. But when he finds the time, he's often a winner. The 16-year-old high school junior found some time today and he won the New York State ski jumping championship and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Memorial Cup.

Raymond Forsyth DeVoe Sr., retired Wall Street financier and Continental Can Company executive, died yesterday at the Community Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 82 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla.
PARIS, Jan. 16 (Ap) Avalanches swept French mountain regions over the weekend, killing four persons and seriously injuring another.
There were two premieres on the grab-bag program of 20th-century music presented by East and West Artists Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall.

WASHINGTON It was Inauguration Day in 1961 when President Kennedy, riding in the inaugural parade, noted that the parade's route down Pennsylvania Avenue took him past as much urban blight as Federal grandeur. He was so concerned that he appointed a commission to undertake the renewal of the avenue, and the commission, with much fanfare, proposed an elaborate program that would have virtually rebuilt Pennsylvania Avenue's north side from the Capitol to the White House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) At least seven Latin American leaders have joined in addressing a personal message to President-elect Carter stressing the importance for their region of quickly negotiating a new Panama Canal treaty yielding substantial control of the waterway and its zone to Panama.

When Westerners think of Indian music, most of them think of the classical style as represented by Ravi Shankar or Ali Akbar Khan. But the music one hears in most Indian households, and in most of this city's Indian restaurants, is Indian film music, and the reigning queen of the idiom, Lata Mangeshkar, gave a rare public performance Saturday evening at the Felt Forum.

An assault on the city of Cotonou in Benin the former French colony of Dahomey by a number of unidentified armed men was repulsed by Government troops. The Cotonou radio, monitored in Niger, said that the attack occurred at dawn after a DC-8 unloaded the attackers and "large quantities of munitions and took off again" from Cadjehoun Military Airport.[Page 1, Columns 5-6.]

LONDON, Jan. 16 (AP) Gen. Sir John Sharp, commander in chief of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces in Northern Europe, died yesterday in Norway, the Ministry of Defense said today. He was 59 years old.

OAKLAND, Calif, Jan. 16 The New York Knicks got their act together today, against a sub-par performance by the Golden State Warriors, and walked off with a 111-97 victory that brought them back to the 500 won-lost mark at 20-20.

Even as Saudi Arabia continues to complete plans for its war for oil price moderation, pressure appears to be building within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries for an end to the twotier price system that has been in effect for only two weeks.
MADRID, Jan 16 (Reuters) The police today stopped Basque mayors from gathering near Pamplona to discuss regional grievances.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 An unusual analysis by the White House Office of Management and Budget estimates that the Ford Administration's plan to reduce the spread of nuclear weapons to nations around the world would cost $2.8 billion over the next three years.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 16 Once Augustus J. Simmons cut down the cyclone fence at Bradley International Airport and was sent to jail. For 10 years, he had fought to prove that the six acres of the airport that the fence was on really belonged to him.

Twenty-one years have passed since the University of San Francisco enjoyed an unbeaten season (29-0) and won the first of two successive national basketball championships under the domination of Bill Russell and K.C. Jones. Since then, the Dons have had their share of fine players, several of whom are playing pro ball, but they have never been able to climb back to the top.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 16 (UPI) Eighteen persons were injured today when a chartered plane caught fire on a runway at Baltimore-Washington International Airport and had to be evacuated.
Turning up one careful notch the speculation that he will run for re-election, Mayor Beame said yesterday that he was "giving serious consideration" to seeking a second term.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 16 (UPI) Jimmy Connors, in the opening event of the 1977 World Championship Tennis tour, today captured his fourth consecutive Birmingham International indoor tournament, defeating Bill Scanlon of Dallas, 6-3, 6-3.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 16 (AP) Marquette, led by Butch Lee's 27 points, broke open a tight game early in the second half and sent Notre Dame to its fourth consecutive defeat, 78-69, today in college basketball.

MORGAN CITY, La., Jan. 16 (UPI) An offshore natural gas drilling rig blew out today, injuring at least seven men and forcing several dozen workers to leave the platform in saucer-shaped rescue capsules.

PASSAIC; Jan. 16 The 55,000 residents of this city have been given what almost every resident of every city has long sought the chance to tell officials what should be done to make their town better than it is.
The Bank of Virginia Company gave investors some bad news last Friday telling them it had set aside an additional $8.2 million in reserves for foreclosed properties and its stock-reacted accordingly.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 16 Ron Livers of San Jose State set a meet record in the triple jump at the Dartmouth Relays today with a mark of 54 feet 9 inches, just 8 inches short of Tommy Haynes's American indoor record.

MANILA, Jan. 16 (UPI) Military authorities said today that 10 persons, including three Americans, will go on trial before a military tribunal Feb. 7 on charges of plotting to assassinate President Ferdinand E. Marcos. Conviction could bring the death penalty.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Jan. 15 Groups of militant young men and women are running through the hamlets and cities of this country, passing burning torches in preparation for celebrations next month to mark the tenth anniversary of Tanzania's embarkation on its own road to socialism, which many observers felt was the most innovative and coherent program to have emerged in Africa.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 The cash value of food stamps is enough to bring about one-quarter of poor recipients above the poverty line, a Congressional Budget Office report has found.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 When the Coast Guard recently fired cannon shells into the abandoned hulk of the Argo Merchant, a split-apart Liberian tanker, and sank it after a nasty oil spill off Nantucket, it was carrying out "Murphy's Law."

DETROIT, Jan. 16 (UPI) The United Automobile Workers has set strike deadlines this week at five General Motors Corporation and Chrysler Corporation facilities to put pressure on the auto makers into winding up negotiations on local contract issues.

POINT OF THE MOUNTAIN, Utah, Monday, Jan. 17 The State of Utah made the final preparations yesterday to execute Gary Mark Gilmore at sunrise today and to end a 10-year moratorium on the death penalty in the United States.

KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 16 (AP) Ingemar Stenmark won his third straight slalom today, but Franz Klammer, Austria's downhill ace, blocked the Swede's bid for the World Cup lead. Stenmark won the slalom with a combined time of 1 minute 39.63 seconds. He was tied for the fastest time in the first run with Piero Gros of Italy at 47.66 seconds, but was the fastest in the second with 51.97.

CAIRO, Jan. 16 (AP) Foreign ministers of five Arab oil-producing countries have deferred a decision on more financial aid for Egypt and Syria until the leaders of their countries meet in March, a Foreign Ministry source said today.

Greg Thompson, competing in his first season on boards, became the only high school junior ever to clear 7 feet in the high jump indoors yesterday at the 21st annual St. Francis Prep Games in the 102d Engineers Armory.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 16 (UPI) Ten cars of a southbound Amtrak passenger train derailed north of here early today, sending 149 passengers and crew members to hospitals. There were no reports of serious injuries.

MONTREAL, Jan. 16 The political and economic climate in Quebec and in Canada generally appears to have worsened in recent weeks as conflicts between Quebec and federal authorities in Ottawa have sharpened. WASHINGTON, Jan. 16(AP) A Ford Administration study group recommended today that dairy cooperatives, insurance companies and ocean freight shippers should no longer be exempt from the Federal laws against price-fixing and illegal monopolies.

The credit markets last year made their strongest gain since the Depression. So far this year, they have declined day after day in a dramatic reversal that has left fixed-income analysts and traders without definite conviction about the outlook for bond prices and interest rates.

Dr. Samuel I. Cohen has been named executive vice president of the Jewish National Fund of America. He succeeds Abram Salomon, who died last October. The fund is the afforestation and landreclamation arm of the World Zionist movement.

Who should lose?

Turetsky of White Plains.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today a decline in the toll of death and injury from bombings in the first 11 months of 1976 as against the same period the previous year.

James W. Sasser, a former New York newspaper reporter who became a public relations executive, died Friday in New Orleans after a three-month illness. He was 51 years old.

Four major United States tire manufacturers are no longer guaranteeing the tread life of their tires or their resistance to punctures or other damage from road hazards. They have, however, extended their warranty protection against defects in materials or workmanship.

To the Congress of the United States: The budget is the President's blue print for the operation of the Government in the year ahead. SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 A sense of historic purpose pervaded deliberations at the University of San Francisco this past weekend as more than 500 women from throughout the United States met to found the National Women's Studies Association.

MADRID, Jan. 17 (Reuters) Interior Minister Rodolfo Martin Villa of Spain has agreed to meet with mayors from the northern Basque country to hear demands for regional autonomy and an amnesty for political prisoners, Basque sources said last night.

After five days of hearings, the Senate Judiciary Committee is moving rapidly toward a vote on the nomination of Judge Griffin Bell to be Attorney General of the United States. With two superlative performances, some beautifully employed music and an intelligent skirting of the gaps in its talents, the Equity Library Theater production of "Twelfth Night" grows steadily through the evening from bare adequacy to a moving radiance.

The coldest weather of the winter subzero temperatures that shattered records for the date put an Arctic hammerlock on the New York City area yesterday, shutting schools in some suburban areas and throwing commuter travel into turmoil.

A gift of $38,290.60 from the trust fund of Sophia Louise Miller has helped the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to pass the $900,000 mark. A state audit of a nursing home run by an upstate county disclosed yesterday that the home had overbilled Medicaid by some $2 million over an 11-year period, including claims for salaries of public employees unrelated to nursing homes.

Fourth-quarter earnings of the Republic Steel Corporation increased 9.6 percent to $9.2 million, or 57 cents a share, the company said yesterday. But for all of last year it reported a 9.6 percent profit decline to $65.9 million, or $4.07 a share.
DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 18 By early this afternoon, the downtown streets of this weather-locked city were as empty of cars as the sidewalks were of people.

The United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare charged yesterday that the New York City school system had violated Federal civil-rights laws by discriminating against minority, female and handicapped pupils.

The Armco Steel Corporation said yesterday that it planned to reduce its selling price for wide-flange structural steel shapes in the Gulf Coast market by about $40 a ton. Shortly afterward a spokesman for the United States Steel Corporation said his company would be "competitive where necessary and where commercially advisable" in that market.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 Governor Carey proposed an $11.345 billion New York State budget today that calls for major cuts in welfare and Medicald, along with a revised formula that would reduce local school aid to many districts.

Carl Zuckmayer, a leading Germanborn playwright and author who lived in the United States during World War II, died last night in a hospital in Visp, Switzerland. He was 80 years old and lived near the Swiss village of Saas-Fee.

MIAMI, Jan. 18 The Dade County Commission today gave its final approval to an ordinance that prohibits discrimination against homosexuals in housing, public accommodation and employment. The law takes effect in 10 days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Kenneth M. Curtis, the incoming Democratic national chairman, said today that he expected to handle "some of the political activity that's been in the White House" in past Administrations.
An increasing number of help-wanted advertisements bear the cryptic abbreviations EDP, EDP program managewent and MIS. At least, these are cryptic to persons not familiar with computer technology.

TRENTON, Jan. 13 The major supplier of natural gas to New Jersey informed the state's major utilities today that gas supplies, which were cut back 35 percent yesterday, leading the Governor to declare a gas emergency, would be reduced an additional 10 percent tomorrow.

An unfortunate fringe effect of the oil price crisis is that it has given devil theories a good name. Let there be an imagined shortage in toilet paper or a real jump in the price of sugar and we have been schooled to assume, darkly, a conspiracy. Now we have the Great Coffee Crisis and with it, an instant supposed villain, profiteering in Brazil, which produces half the world's supply.

Breaking with tradition, Senator Daniel P. Moynihan announced yesterday that he would recommend that three Republican-appointed United States attorneys in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Buffalo continue in office under the Carter Administration.

SALEM, Jan. 18 The New Jersey Public Advocate challenged, at a Nuclear Regulatory Commission hearing today, a contention by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company that groundings of liquefied-natural-gas tankers in the Delaware River could not spill flammable gas near the huge nuclear power plant utilities building here.

HARTFORD, Jan. 18 The future of the Minnesota Fighting Saints remained uncertain today after trustees of the troubled World Hockey Association franchise asked for time to sell the club to local interests in St. Paul. They were given until 11 P.M. Thursday, Eastern standard time, to find a buyer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Indiana, which refused on two previous occasions to ratify the equal rights amendment to the Constitution, ratified it today. Supporters of the amendment said that the action signaled a break in the long logjam over its adoption.

The chairman of the State Commission of Correction has told New York City to reduce immediately the inmate population at the Rikers Island House of Detention for Men from 1,400 to 1,200 and to reduce it to 1,000 by Feb. 15.

Susan Mary Alsop will never forget when President Kennedy unexpectedly slogged through knee-deep snow at 2 A.M. after his 1960 Inaugural Ball to get to Joseph Alsop's glowing Georgetown salon for a warming drink and some companionship. Mrs. Alsop, now an author of books and divorced from the former columnist, remembers it this way:

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 18 Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, today identified Frank A. Gulotta, the presiding justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, Second Department, as "the highly placed judge" who relayed an offer from the Republican county chairman of a nomination for State Supreme Court if he dropped out of the County Executive race.

TOKYO, Jan. 18 (AP) Teruyoshi Tasaka, president of the Nippon Steel Corporation, died today in a Tokyo hospital at the age of 68. He had been president of the company, the world's largest steel producer, since last June.

Sitting in her cozy living room in Weston, Conn., where she lives alone, Bette Davis struck a kitchen match on the underside of a table, lit a cigarette, inhaled deeply and recalled, "Not long ago Blondell said, 'If some of us only knew that we were going to be stuck with these films forever ...'"
TRENTON, Jan. 18 William J. Hamilton Jr., the new Speaker of the State Assembly, wants to look over Governor Byrne's shoulder this year to make sure he is doing a good job.

American reporting about Britain's economy is reflecting a new optimism about our prospects. World confidence in Britain has been shown by the International Monetary Fund's decision to help the country over its short-term, difficulties and by the agreement among central banks on sterling balances. These were only possible because Britain could convince the world that it has a stable, prosperous and free future.

DETROIT, Jan. 18 The financially troubled American Motors Corporation will have its $63 million in short-term loans renewed by the end of this month, Roy D. Chapin Jr., the company's chairman, said today.
Twenty-one professional soccer coaches from Brazil started a two-week tour of the United States on Monday, giving clinics and offering technical advice to coaches and players in 11 regions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) The Supreme Court ruled today that some evidence gathered from a secret wiretap that is technically illegal can be used in criminal trials.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 As icy winds knifed through the capital, the five-day inaugural celebration for President-elect Jimmy Carter began this morning on a quietly ebullient note.

Two elderly men were found dead from exposure to cold yesterday afternoon in their icy rooms in a residence hotel on Amsterdam Avenue, just a block north of City College on the Upper West Side.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 18 The Trident, the Navy's third-generation, submarine-launched missile, successfully passed its first-flight test here today.

A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that New York City, to clean up its air, must carry out a controversial transportation control plan that includes imposing tolls on bridges across the East and Harlem Rivers.

Capital Cities Communications Inc. yesterday offered to buy for cash the Kansas City Star publishing company for $125 million.

THE FEELING is familiar to most everyone nothing seems satisfying, things don't work out, much of anything and your mental landscape is bleak. It's called depression, and few of us get through life without experiencing it at one time or another.
Paul Nordoff, American composer and music therapist, died yesterday of cancer in a clinic in Herdecke, West Germany. He was 67 years old.

ZARAGOZA, Spain, Jan. 18 (AP) A France-to-Madrid train caught fire at dawn today as it passed through a tunnel. Four coaches were destroyed, but the 149 passengers and the crew escaped unhurt, railroad officials reported.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Vice President Rockefeller said farewell to the Senate today and received the sentimental accolades at which that body excels.

George Balanchine, artistic director and co-founder of the New York City Ballet, denied yesterday that he was planning to work in Europe because of a musicians' strike that closed down the company's winter season.

MANILA, Wednesday, Jan. 19 (Reuters) The terminal building at Manila's domestic airport burned by the ground during the night. The Philippine Civil Aviation Administration said that the blaze, which disrupted domestic flight schedules today, caused at least $3 million in damage.

The American Jewish Congress, a human rights organization, has announced the cancellation of its members' travel programs to France.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 18 (Reuters) Former students in China's largest city are demanding an interview with municipal leaders to discuss their charges of persecution by the purged mayor, Chang Chung-chiao. The students have pasted up posters throughout Shanghai describing their ordeal in the northern province of Heilungkiang.

Up like a rocket and down like a meteor went the construction fortunes of the partnership of Michael Newmark and Lawrence Rosano between 1969 and 1974. They had $30 million worth of new low-rise housing in place in Queens before their more ambitious projects Village Mall at Hillcrest, in the Hillcrest section of Flushing, and Village Mall Townhouses and the contiguous Village Mall Towers, in Bayside faltered.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Representative Shirley Chisholm of Brooklyn today became the second woman in memory and the first black woman ever named to a seat on the influential House Rules Committee.

ONE OF THE best, most easily made and least costly of fine dishes is the one known in France as escalopes de veau viennoise. Escalopes de veau are simply scaloppine of veal. Viennoise means in the style of Vienna, and the dish is the French version of wiener schnitzel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 As Henry A. Kissinger's term expires, he has been closing out the public record with a round of farewell lunches and dinners. He has used these usually routine affairs to say some unusual things, trying to make peace in the last days with some of the groups with which his relationship has been most uneasy during his tenure as Secretary of State.

The Staten Island Rapid Transit system returned to full operation yesterday afternoon as workers returned to their jobs following a walkout that had shut down the line Monday morning. All trains were reported running on schedule during last night's rush-hour, a welcome relief to the 9,000 commuters who had been forced to use crowded busses and car pools.

An official of the Soviet Union's Olympic Organizing Committee said yesterday that his nation was ready to resume talks with the three major American networks over the sale of broadcast rights to the 1980 Summer Games in Moscow.

Miss Printemps was for many years one of the most sparkling ornaments of the French theatrical scene, and her marriage to Sacha Guitry, the dramatist and actor, constituted one of the most famous partnerships in modern stage history until it was terminated by divorce in 1934.

President Ford sent to Congress yesterday proposed legislation that would earmark about $3 billion in aviation surcharges to help the airlines replace or modify the 1,600 jets that exceed Federal noise standards.

MONDAY EVENING'S sparsely attended "gala" concert celebrating the Decade of Women at Carnegie Recital Hall led off with three mostly a cappella (there was a bit of percussion) choral pieces by Alice Parker, Merle Montgomery and Julia Smith all very brief and all run together, almost as if they were one piece. Which they might have been, given the pleasant but similarly conservative idiom they shared.

Governor Carey's clemency proclamation on Dec. 30 to "firmly and finally close the book" on the 1971 Attica prison uprising ran into a snag yesterday with the disclosure that the State Board of Parole had denied parole at this time to John Hill, now serving a 20-year-to-life term in the fatal beating of a prison guard, William Quinn.

TRENTON, Jan. 18 (AP) State officials have confirmed the results of independent audits detailing how nearly $1 million in state funds was misspent because New Jersey made payments to some day-care centers for children who did not attend regularly.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 Following is a table showing the credit that taxpayers would receive on their state income tax under Governor Carey's budget proposal. The income figures reflect total adjusted gross income. The repeal proposed by the Governor of the 2.5 percent income-tax surcharge would affect all taxpayers regardless of income.

Two armed youths, after breaking into a house in Queens on Monday and robbing an 84-year-old handicapped woman of $35, went upstairs, robbed a 68-yearold man of $60 and his watch and, before leaving, pushed his head into the toilet bowl and flushed it, according to the police and court reports.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 Federal scientists believe that they have discovered the cause of the mysterious legionnaires' disease that killed 29 persons who were in Philadelphia during an American Legion convention there last July.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 18 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, declaring her "unshakable faith in the power of the people," announced today that parliamentary elections would take place in March as part of a major relaxation of her 19-month-old emergency rule.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 18 (AP) The Virginia Attorney General's office accused 14 sugar refiners yesterday of price fixing in a class-action antitrust suit filed in United States District Court.
WASHINGTON, Jan 19 By the rough index of street addresses in the telephone directory, about two-thirds of the 600-odd Carters who already live in the District of Columbia are black.
AMERICUS, Ga., Jan. 18 Presidentelect Jimmy Carter and Pentagon spokesmen today confirmed reports that his oldest son, Jack Carter, was discharged from the Navy in 1970 for smoking marijuana.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 State Department and United Nations officials said today that they saw no conflict in the fact that both Secretary of State-designate Cyrus R. Vance and Secretary General Kurt Waldheim planned diplomatic missions to the Middle East next month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The Justices of the Supreme Court, lawyers all, struggled with obvious concern and occasional humor today to decide whether lawyers should be allowed to advertise. For the Justices it was a complicated question, involving the First Amendment, free competition and the possibility that some lawyers might produce ads that mislead the public.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 19 Foreign Minister Yigal Allon today strongly reaffirmed Israel's refusal to negotiate with the Palestine Liberation Organization. In an address to Parliament, Mr. Allon labeled the P.L.O. a "murderous organization" that did not represent the Palestinian people.
"Hellzapoppin," the million-dollar "musical circus" that was to have been Jerry Lewis's debut on Broadway, will close in Boston on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Federal scientists are beginning to explore the possibility that the strange microbes linked to legionnaires' disease are a more general although hitherto unknown cause of pneumonia in humans.

DETROIT, Jan. 19 The American Motors Corporation announced today it was negotiating to sell a stamping plant in South Charleston, W. Va., to Volkswagen. A.M.C. needs to dispose of the plant to raise badly needed money, industry sources said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 At the first reception given by a President of the United States at 10 Cherry Street, in the then capital of New York City, guests were served tea and coffee and small cakes, a teetotal soiree that set no precedent at all for later Presidential entertaining.
MOSCOW, Jan. 19 (Reuters) A Soviet general today rejected charges made in the West that the Soviet Union's precautions against nuclear war could undermine the strategic balance between East and West.
CLEMSON, S.C., Jan. 19 (AP) Clemson hit on nine of its first 10 shots to jump to an 18-9 lead and coasted to a 93-71 triumph over 13thranked Maryland in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 19 (AP) The jury in Wendy Yoshimura's weapons possession trial declared itself "at a standstill" this evening, but the judge ordered the panel to continue its deliberations for a sixth day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Griffin B. Bell was approved today as Presidentelect Carter's nominee to be Attorney General, making him the last of Mr. Carter's Cabinet nominees to win recommendations from Senate panels.

The Caterpillar Tractor Company, the nation's largest maker of earthmoving machinery and equipment, reported yesterday a 28.5 percent decline in fourthquarter earnings to $70.3 million, or 81 cents a share. It was the third consecutive quarterly decline in profits last year with a consequent drop in annual earnings.

Thousands of commuters who use the Harlem division of Conrail were delayed for "at least an hour" yesterday during the rush and were again subject to delays of up to 20 minutes last night because of Tuesday night's derailment in Scarsdale, N.Y., a rail official reported.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The 1977 "New Spirit" Inaugural Concert at the Kennedy Center tonight had a whole galaxy of famous flashing stars and even a few famous flashing teeth. This was an unusual gala that James Lipton had arranged for the incoming Administration, for two very special reasons.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 19 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, who has long been regarded as a master of politics and timing, has perplexed the opposition once again with her surprise call for parliamentary elections in March.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Ruth Carter Stapleton, sister of the incoming President, stood quietly today among 50 worshipers from various faiths on the west steps of the Capitol for a service of prayer that was indicative of the deep religious aspects of this inauguration.

The highly competitive citizens band radio business heavily discounted 23channel sets all during the Christmas selling season after the Federal Communications Commission ruled that the industry could not sell new 40-channel outfits until Jan. 1, 1977.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz reported yesterday that his office had obtained an order in State Supreme Court under which the owners of three apartment complexes in Yonkers, Lynbrook, L.I., and Flushing, Queens, must maintain $110,628 in rent securities in interestbearing accounts.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 23 Vice President Mondale arrived in Brussels tonight and strongly affirmed the Carter Administration's commitment to the Atlantic alliance.

An 8-year-old girl was thrown to her death from the roof of a Brooklyn housing project yesterday afternoon according to the police, who said her body was found at the base of the six-story building about 20 minutes after she had been sent on an errand from a third-floor apartment.

Christine Redpath started training her dog, Pigalle, which she got after the New York City Ballet's fall season in Paris. Daniel Duell put up shelves in his apartment and pegboard for Kyra Nichols, a fellow dancer.

ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 23 Gov. Reubin Askew, acting on the basis of preliminary reports of crop damage from last week's cold wave, has declared the entire state a disaster area, but not everyone in Florida sees the situation as dire.
Howard Golden, the interim Brooklyn Borough President, welcomed some 700 Brooklynites to "an open house" at Borough Hall yesterday, but not all of them had turned out to wish him well.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 At a time of great concern over violent crime, heightened last week by the first execution in the nation in a decade, the number of homicides in big cities continued to decline last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) Opponents of abortion said today that more than double the police estimate of 35,000 people marched from the Capitol to the White House yesterday on the fourth anniversary of the United States Supreme Court's decision easing legal restrictions on abortions.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 23 (UPI) Ricky Sobers hit for 11 points in a five-minute span in the fourth quarter to lead the Phoenix Suns to a 98-88 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics today. It was the Suns' eighth straight home triumph.
Kim Commons of Los Angeles triumphantly marched through Bulgaria taking first prize in three successive international tournaments and, while he was at it, gaining the rank of international master.
About half of New York City's school custodians employ a relative, and 23 custodians earned more than $40,000 in 1975, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday.

Ana Maria Trenchi de Bottazzi is the Argentine pianist who returned to the recital stage several seasons ago against all odds, having overcome apparent brain damage that resulted from an auto accident in 1962.

Federal investigators are seeking the cause of the recent near-crash of an Argentine airliner that came within about 100 feet of smashing into heavily populated areas near Kennedy International Airport.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 23 (UPI) The Baltimore Colts' owner, Robert Irsay, has picked two men Dick Syzmanski and Ernie Accorsi to fill the job held by General Manager Joe Thomas, according to an official associated with the Colts.

Ron Perry is an exception amid basketball's attempted swing toward specialization. In the age of the small or reboundiag forwards, the shooting and playmaking guards, the Holy Cross freshman, one of the nation's top scorers (23 points a game), is gaining acclaim as the all-round backcourt man in the Bob Cousy tradition.
YONKERS, Jan. 23 The sun shone brightly on Sunday afternoon racing today, but Tim Rooney wasn't wearing blinkers.
PANAMA, Jan. 23 (AP) Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera has announced a new austerity program for Panama, including wage and price controls and Government pay cuts.

MADRID, Jan. 23 (AP) Riot policemen swinging clubs and firing rubber bullets battled thousands of Communist-led demonstrators in the heart of Madrid today. Authorities said that one student had been shot dead by unkown gunmen and an undetermined number of policemen and protesters had been injured.
Warren Kempton Page, the former gun editor of Field and Stream magazine and a member of the Hunting Hall of Fame, died Saturday in New Canaan, Conn. He was 67 years old.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. Jan. 23 Tom Watson won the 36th Bing Crosby National Pro-Am golf tournament today in a Hairbreadth Harry finish, by only one stroke. He took the first prize of $40,000 with a bogey 6 on the 18th hole just a few moments after Tony Jacklin of Britain, playing in the foursome immediately ahead, had handed him the opportunity with a bogey of his own.

LONDON, Jan. 23 Enoch Powell, the abrasive right-wing critic of Britain's immigration policies, was threatened today with charges of inciting racial hatred because of a speech this weekend in which he said that the country faced the prospect of racial civil war.

TOKYO, Jan. 23 With the indictments Friday of two major figures in the murky world where political and economic power overlap, the investigative phase of the Lockheed scandal here is assumed to have virtually ended and the reckoning before the courts is about to begin.

A strong affirmation of the Carter Administration's commitment to the Atlantic alliance was made by Vice President Mondale when he arrived in Brussels on the first stop of a tour of Europe and Japan. Harriet Lillian Lazer and James W. Walker were married yesterday at the Tavern on the Green by State Supreme Court Justice Alfred Ascione.
Israel has turned over to the Pentagon a full line of captured Soviet military equipment, Time magazine reports in its current issue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 It was a frosty day in Washington, with temperatures from 17 to 31 degrees, and throughout the day curious, or perhaps skeptical, persons telephoned the White House to ask what the indoor temperature was.
"Harlan County" was shown at the last New York Film Festival. The following is an excerpt from Richard Eder's review, which appeared Oct. 15. The film begins today at the Cinema II Theater.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 23 (AP) Notre Dame's basketball coach, Digger Phelps, has long believed that the Irish's heated rivalry with U.C.L.A. is the greatest in college basketball, and he saw no reason to change his mind after today's 70-65 loss to the Bruins.

There will be a memorial mass at 12:30 P.M. today in St. Patrick's Cathedral for the 24 Navy men and 24 Marine Corps men who lost their lives Jan. 17 when their launch capsized in Barcelona Harbor following a collision with a Spanish freighter.

The National Boat Show, which opened at the Coliseum with a whimper after a snowstorm, went out with a bang yesterday. Show officials reported the best turnout in seven years, with attendance "way over 400,000."

The marriage of Claudia Zeitz, manager of management sciences at the American Express Company, to Harold Seth Poster, an associate with the New York law firm of Bartel Engleman Fishman, took place yesterday at Temple Har Zion in Penn Valley, Pa. Rabbi Gerald Wolpe performed the ceremony.

More than 50 persons were left homeless last night when a four-alarm fire swept through a six-story apartment building in the South Bronx. There were no reported injuries in the blaze, which broke out shortly after 9 P.M. at 600 East 141st Street. The fire was declared under control at 11:30 P.M. Victims were being lodged by the Red Cross at a Manhattan hotel.

Richard Dyer-Bennet gave his first New York recital in 14 years Saturday afternoon in Alice Tully Hull, but the program did not consist of the folk songs, ballads and art songs for which he is noted. On this occasion Mr. Dyer-Bennet not only tackled one of the greatest German song cycles, Schubert's "Die shone Mullerin," bu the also sang it in his own English translalation, which he calls "The Pretty Milleress."
Louis Beverley Gnaedinger, a retired journalist who had worked for several metropolitan publications, including The New York Times, died Saturday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 78 years old.

During the recent holidays a brief mention was made of boudin noir, one of the finest creations of the French sausage-maker's art. Boudin noir is a black blood sausage and is utterly delectable when broiled or baked until piping hot.

CHICAGO The Apparel Center, a two-towered, $50-million plus complex built by the Joseph P. SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Monday, Jan. 24 (Agence France Presse) Bishop Abel Muzorewa, a moderate black Rhodesian leader, yesterday sent his condolences to the family of Jason Moyo, a military leader in a rival group headed by Joshua Nkomo. Mr. Moyo was killed by a parcel bomb Saturday.

PARIS, Jan. 23 Former Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, who took over and relaunched the old Gaullist party and is now running for mayor of Paris to reinforce his political base, said today that the Socialist-Communist opposition would win power in France if he did not take the initiative.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 23 (AP) President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France and King Khalid of Saudi Arabia talked for 40 minutes today in the first formal talks of the French President's state visit to the world's major exporter of oil.

PRAGUE, Jan. 23 (AP) Czechoslovak television broadcast a program today in which several British diplomats and a British journalist were accused of being spies. The accusation was promptly denied by the British.

Formula One driving championship competition with 13 points after two races. LANDOVER, Md., Jan. 23 (AP) The streaking Washington Bullets won the 11th of their last 13 games tonight defeating the Detroit Pistons, 119-108. Elvin Hayes scored 30 points for the victors.

The nation's energy companiesthose that supply its gas and oil and generate its electricity-are expected to earn millions of dollars in additional profits as a result of cold-induced high demand, for their products, according to Wall Street analysts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Representative Jim Wright, the House majority leader, predicted today that the House Assassination committee would be continued but that its budget would be "considerably curbed below the grandiose figures that have been bandied about."

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Company reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 34 percent behind the yearearlier level despite an increase of 5.1 percent in sales. Net income for the year rose 70 percent higher than in 1975 as sales increased by 15.8 percent.

Four years ago,the intelligence section of the Police Department compiled a list of 100 "major narcotics violators." Among them were eight men considered important cogs in the city's narcotics traffic.

TRENTON, Jan. 24 The State Senate passed today a bill giving municipal courts the authority to define obscenity and another measure asking Congress to call a convention to amend the Federal Constitution so as to outlaw abortions.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 24 (UPI) The dollar rallied on European money markets today and in a sharp reversal of early morning declines closed higher on all markets except London and Brussels.

President Carter is urging an instant and complete halt to all testing of nuclear weapons as a step toward curbing their spread and ultimately banning them, he disclosed in his first White House interview. He said he had received an encouraging message from the Soviet Union. He was hopeful also of fairly rapid ratification of a new treaty with the Soviet Union limiting strategic arms.[Page 1,Column 6.]

RAHWAY, Jan. 24 "Imagine being buried alive and knowing that there was no way out," the stern-faced prisoner told the 11 obviously frightened teen-agers who sat almost motionless on a long bench in front of him.

A well-known Episcopal priest on Long Island has been stripped of his parish duties and his position as dean of the Diocesan Seminary by his superiors who objected to his stated intention to get a divorce from his wife and to remarry.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 24 King Khalid suggested today after weekend talks with President Valery Giscard d'Estaing that France could play an "eminent role" in the search for a Middle East settlement.

The way Rory Kotinek tells it, Francie Larrieu Lutz was seated with some friends in the bar of the Hilton Inn in Philadelphia last Friday night, drinking nothing more than hot chocolate, when Jan Merrill's coach, Norm Higgins, walked by.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 President Carter is calling for a halt to all nuclear testing, "instantly and completely," as part of a broader program to curb the spread of nuclear weapons and ultimately ban them altogether.

"Discretion in sentencing has been a double-edged sword," Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said recently. "It permits a judge to accommodate unusual circumstances relative to each defendant. But this sometimes results in defendants who ought to be similarly treated receiving substantially disparate sentences."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Amy Carter completed her transition to Washington today by arriving late for her first day of classes.
MAHILA, Thuesday, Jan. 25 (AP) For the fourth time in four monts the Philippine Government has expelled an American on grounds of internal security.
LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP) Britain received a $1.5 billion bank loan today to bolster its reserves of foreign currency.

The Rajko Hungarian Gyspy Orchestra and Dancers pranced onto the stage of Carnegie Hall for performances Saturday night and Sunday afternoon. The troupe is a young one, average age 19, and judging from yesterday's show it possesses boundless reserves of energy.

With a shattering of reputations, The Times Literary Supplement of Gray's Inn Road, London, has just come out with its 75th anniversary issue. The reverberations should keep the Oxbridge dons and erudite readers firing off letters to the editor, the mild-mannered John Gross, for the rest of 1977.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Disclaiming any attempt to influence the outcome, the two top Democratic leaders of the House said today that they would vote in their party caucus Wednesday to retain Representative Robert L.F. Sikes of Florida as chairman of a key appropriations subcommittee.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 Ilie Nastase of Rumania advanced tonight to the quarterfinals of the $200,000 United States Pro Indoor tennis championships by eliminating Italy's Corrado Barazzutti, 4-6, 6-0, 6-3, at the Spectrum. Nastase relaxed for a set, then came on strong with nine straight game triumphs.

An unpublicized dispute between two of America's largest electronics corporations over allegations of large-scale bribery of Indonesian officials has again raised questions about the lack of Federal controls over such payoffs and the need for international cooperation to end them.
TRENTON, JAN. 24 The Legislature today completed action on a bill easing the point system covering the suspension of drivers' licenses. Governor Byrne is expected to sign the bill into law.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 (UPI) John Vincent, composer and former chairman of the music department of the University of California at Los Angeles, died on Friday. He was 74 years old.
MAFEKING, South Africa, Jan. 24 (AP) Bophuthatswana, one of South Africa's eight remaining black tribal homelands, will be declared independent next Dec. 6, it was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Senate approved on a vote of 95 to 1 today the nomination of Joseph A. Califano Jr. to be Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare despite minor opposition to his views on abortion.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24 Five years ago, a young man who grew up in Houston and had wanted to join the church since he was 17 years old, was ordained a minister here at the United Church of Christ, or, as it is also called, the Congregational Church.

Chain store sales in December rose 13.6 percent over the level of December 1975, according to Chain Store Age magazine. The gain was the fifth best of the year, exceeded only by an 18.3 percent increase in April, 17 percent in January, 14.7 percent in October and 13.7 percent in February.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The president of The Washington Post's parent company will resign effective Feb. 1, apparently after losing the confidence of Katharine Graham, The Post's publisher and the principal owner of the diversified communications corporation.

The Hughes Aircraft Company, a privately owned company of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, does not build aircraft; it specializes in the design and manufacture of sophisticated electronic equipment and components.

HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N.J. Jan. 24 Synagogues in New York State were warned today to beware of professional gamblers with possible Mafia ties who might seek to take over the operation of so-called "Las Vegas Nights" and other fund-raising games of chance.
DETROIT, Jan. 24 (UPI) The United Auto Workers ended one potentially crippling strike against General Motors today and extended the deadline on negotiations to avert a second one.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Concerned that the Supreme Court is no longer providing the impetus toward further racial integration in the country, many civil rights lawyers and lobbyists feel that the burden of leadership toward an integrated society has shifted to the new Carter Administration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 President Carter presided over his first Cabinet meeting today and immediately sounded as the opening notes of his Administration his campaign themes of simplicity, frugality and candid discourse.

Mayor Beame and a group of leading bankers met yesterday and later declared themselves in "broad agreement" on steps to meet New York City's debt and budget problems but they appeared to be no closer than ever on the key issue of outside controls of the city's finances.

The St. Francis College basketball team threw a scare into streaking Manhattan last night, but the Jaspers hung on to win, 69-63, before 1,800 fans at the St. Francis court and stretched their winning streak to six games. They now have won nine of their last 10.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 A plan to establish a legal resources center to assist in the court actions many civil liberties groups are initiating against police spying was agreed upon here this weekend at a conference on government spying.

If we read the news from Cairo correctly, President Sadat seeks now to turn a time of domestic turmoil and weakness into something of a foreign-policy advantage. He seems to feel that the United States and others owe him an extra measure of support, and perhaps in our own interest we do.

Eli Lilly, retired president and chairman of Eli Lilly Company, the drug company founded by his grandfather, died yesterday in Indiana University Hospital in Indianapolis, his home and the headquarters of the company. He was 91 years old.

Hundreds of bettors filed angrily out of Aqueduct yesterday without waiting to get even. They were disgusted by the mob scene in the clubhouse as a result of the race track's closing of its grandstand betting windows for "economic" reasons.
Energy crises mounted in Ohio, Pennsylvania and other states yesterday in one of the bitterest and most unrelenting winters on record. The Federal Government took action to keep homes warm.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Senate Rules Committee cut through delicate issues of jurisdiction and power today and unanimously approved a compromise measure to streamline the Senate in its first major reorganization in 30 years.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 24 Elliot L.Richardson, who has held four Cabinet positions in Republican administrations, has been chosen by President Carter to head the United States delegation to the United Nations' Law of the Sea Conference.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Jan. 24 (UPI) An Eritrean guerrilla leader said today that rebels fighting for independence now control 75 percent of Ethiopia's restive northernmost province.
Steel production for the week ended Jan. 22 fell 6.3 percent to 1.97 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Negotiations on a new treaty to limit strategic arms have been deadlocked since last March when the Soviet Union rejected a proposal to bypass two major obstacles to an accord and proceed with the signing.

Earlier this month, within a few days, two leading private institutions that regularly track the level of confidence among American consumers issued what seemed to be directly conflicting reports on the public's recent mood.

DETROIT, Jan. 24-The financially troubled American Motors Corporation reported today that it had halted its recent accumulation of heavy losses by earning $1.2 million, or 4 cents a share, during the three months that ended last Dec. 30.

The dissolution of a culture is the greatest of all dramas. We can feel this in Gibbon's "Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire," Spengler's "The Decline of the West," and Huizinga's "The Waning of the Middle Ages." In America, in varying degrees, some of us are experiencing the dissolution of what we regarded as our own culture. In fact, the phenomenon is a commonplace of our century; we can find it everywhere.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Representative James C. Wright, the House majority leader, said today that Congress would do "whatever is necessary" to keep New York from defaulting on its obligations "even if it means renewal of the emergency loan program" grudgingly approved last year.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 24 Britain's attempt to achieve a settlement between Rhodesia's white minority and the black majority failed today.

BONN, Jan. 24 Vice President Mondale, citing increased Soviet military strength in Europe, said today that the Carter Administration was prepared to increase defense spending in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
CAIRO, Jan. 24 (Reuters) The International Monetary Fund has agreed to lend Egypt $140 million to help boost the country's ailing economy, the semiofficial newspaper Al Ahram reported today.
MONTEREY, Calif., Jan. 24 Gerald Ford had barely entered the ranks of the retired last week when he got the word from his wife.
Funeral services have been scheduled for Bernard (Toots) Shor, the celebrated New York "saloonkeeper" who died of cancer of the colon Sunday night at the age of 73.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 Columbia Gas of Pennsylvania said today because record cold temperatures resulted in abnormal use of natural gas for home heating it will increase curtailment of supplies to industrial users on Feb. 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Government took two emergency actions today to increase fuel supplies and, in a separate action, President Carter rescinded former President Ford's order to end gasoline price controls.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 24(AP) The Louisiana Supreme Court upheld today the conviction of Gary Tyler, a black teen-ager accused of killing a white schoolmate after a racial disturbance at Destrehan High School.

Lane Bryant Inc., which entered the discount-store field 16 years ago by acquiring the Town and Country chain, announced yesterday that it would terminate that division within three months because of continuing losses from its operations.

Columbia's 92-77 victory over Fordham at Levien Gym on Morningside Heights last night will not go down as an artistic basketball achievement. It was, however, a case of scrappy basketball in a game that was supposed to be an easy triumph for the Lions but was far from a walkaway.

The New York State Power Authority agreed yesterday to sell electricity to 27 local governments and school districts in Westchester County that have been seeking to withdraw from using the Consolidated Edison system. The sale is contingent upon approval by Governor Carey.

ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Jan. 24 (AP) Heini Hemmi of Switzerland, an Olympic champion, posted his third giant slalom victory of the season today. He beat the runner-up, Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden, the World Cup holder, by three-quarters of a second.
Moving with unexpected speed, the Transit Authority yesterday cut the number of cars by half on many off-peak subway trains weeks before the service cuts were scheduled.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The North Atlantic Treaty Organization must redeploy its fighting units and increase its firepower to meet a heightened threat of short war from Soviet-bloc forces, according to a study made public today by Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia.

With a shattering of reputations, The Times Literary Supplement of Gray's Inn Road, London, has just come out with its 75th anniversary issue. The reverberations should keep the Oxbridge dons and erudite readers firing off letters to the editor, the mild-mannered John Gross, for the rest of 1977.

LOS ANGELES Jan. 24 (AP) Senator Alan Cranston's office and aides to President Carter are working to establish a panel to recommend people for appointment as Federal judges and prosecutors in California in an attempt to remove partisanship from the selection process.

Ken Stabler, the 31-year-old lefthanded quarterback who led the Oakland Raiders to their finest season, topped by a victory in the Super Bowl, yesterday was named the winner of the 27th annual S. Rae Hickok Award as the professional athlete of the year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) The head of an independent panel that studied the collapse of the Teton Dam in Idaho told a Senate hearing today that engineers could have foreseen factors that led to the structure's failure.

The chairman of the board of directors of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday that he would convene a special meeting this week to seek the removal of Dr. John L. S. Holloman Jr. as president.

A company provides income-replacement payments to temporarily disabled employees for all disabilities that both men and women incur, such as lung cancer, alcoholism and skiing injuries, and all disabilities that only men incur, such as prostatectomies. For three years the Federal Energy Administration has been warning of dangerous shortages of natural gas, on which the country depends for a third of its energy. Little heed was paid. The F.E.A., in fact, was accused of crying "wolf" during a succession of unusually warm winters. But now the wolf is at the door.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 President Carter presided over his first Cabinet meeting today and immediately sounded as the opening notes of his Administration his campaign themes of simplicity, frugality and candid discourse.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI)-Amy Carter matched her father's famous grin after school today when she first saw Grits, a black and White 12-weekold puppy that was born the day Jimmy Carter won election as President.
Reports that China was buying cotton in both Central and North American markets caused cotton futures prices to rise to the daily limit of $10 a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
The Public Securities Association, an organization linking the dealers and dealer banks that buy and sell municipal and government securities, was officially established yesterday.

CAIRO, Jan. 24 Even if no new violence occurs in the near future, it is now taken for granted by foreign observers here that last week's riots transformed the political landscape of Egypt and seriously impaired President Anwar el Sadat's freedom of action at home and abroad.
