At the bar were freshly scrubbed cowboys and sheepherders.
Daniel Schwartzman, a past president of the Architectural League of New York, died yesterday in a nursing home in the Bronx. He was 68 years old and lived at 35 Park Avenue and in Sea Cliff, L.I.

I.Sy Seidman, a photographer and a collector of old photographs, memorabilia and Americana whose archives became a resource for movie makers, magazines and newspapers, died Saturday in Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 85 years old.

PRAGUE, Jan. 24 (Reuters) The Government today called a press conference in which workers, artists and Communist Party officials rejected a Czechoslovak human-rights document published recently in the West.
ALTOONA, Pa., Jan. 24 (UPI) John Edward Holtzinger, publisher of The Altoona Mirror and Pennsylvania Mirror in State College, Pa., died yesterday. He was 73 years old.

Ambitious plans to revitalize the shopping center of Flushing, Queens were made public yesterday with strong support from Borough President Donald R. Manes, Council President Paul O'Dwyer and Victor Marrero, chairman of the City Planning Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 A book that has stirred controversy in Britain because of reports that it was commissioned by a propaganda vehicle for the Central Intelligence Agency was also published in the United States and has been on sale here since 1974.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) A former aide to Gov. Edwin Edwards of Louisiana said today that he had told a Federal grand jury that the Korean businessman Tongsun Park had given thousands of dollars to Mr. Edwards when he was a member of Congress and to Representative John B.Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana.
Two major airlines, American and Trans World, made public yesterday preliminary 1976 net earnings figures that sharply reversed the large losses of the year before.

Wrapped in the embrace of the bitterest winter in more than a decade, the anticipated pleasures of dawdling along a June trout stream seem more intense than unusual, particularly when they are described by one of the most accomplished and articulate fly fishermen in America.

NEW HAVEN In "The Shadow Box," which recently opened at the Long Wharf Theater, Michael Cristofer has written a play about dying that also deals with living. In contrast, David Rudkin's "Ashes" (at the Public Theater) is a play about life that also deals with death. Both are certainly among the best plays of this season.

After eight hours of deliberation, a six-man, six-woman jury late last night found Oswaldo Diaz, 18 years old, guilty of stabbing to death a young woman in Central Park last Sept. 11 in an attempt to steal her purse.

Currently on its annual East Coast tour, the Oberlin College Choir arrived in Alice Tully Hall Sunday night for a varied concert of choral music covering a wide range, from late Renaissance (Lasso) through the Classical (Mozart, Haydn) and Romantic eras (Mendelssohn, Bruckner) to the 20th century (Poulenc, Earl George, James Fritschel and Knut Nystedt).

John LaGatta, a leading magazine illustrator of the 1920's and 30's, died Friday in Santa Monica, Calif., where he had lived for many years. He had taught at the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 Governor Carey apparently will not submit to the Legislature his proposal for a 45-day cutoff period to employables on home relief because of growing criticism of the measure as unconstitutional. This leaves a $45 million portion of the Governor's budget proposal in doubt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) Following are excerpts from the official White House transcript of President Carter's first interview as President, conducted yesterday in the White House with two reporters from The Associated Press and two from United Press International.

Dr. Lincoln Dryden, a professor of geology at Bryn Mawr College for 40 years until his retirement in 1970, died Saturday in Calvert Memorial Hospital, Prince Frederick, Md., after a short illness. He lived in Port Republic, Md., and was 74 years old.

The Federal Reserve System is facing potential serious problems because many smaller commercial banks have been leaving the central banking system, Paul A. Volcker, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said here yesterday.

PRAGUE Czechoslovakia is letting it be known that if the Carter Administration wants to improve the ice-cold relations between Washington and Prague, the United States will quickly have to give this country gold, credit and advanced technology.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 New orders for durable goods placed with the nation's manufacturing industry last month rose by a substantial 6.6 percent in one of the biggest increases of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.

After paying a $1,000 fine for staging a one-man, one-day strike last September 23, Ken McFeeley, former president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said yesterday: "If I had to do it all over again, I would." Mr. McFeeley, who also got his badge and gun back, estimated that his strike, which resulted in his suspension, had cost him nearly $7,000 in fines and back pay.
ANKARA, Jan. 24 (Reuters) The Turkish Government announced today that it was withdrawing 1,000 troops from Cyprus. The withdrawal will apparently reduce its forces there to about 27,000 men.

Earnings of E.F. Hutton Company, the brokerage firm, rose 16.9 percent to $23.5 million, or $3.88 a share, in 1976 from $20.1 million, or $3.39 a share, in the preceding year. Revenues also increased to $314.7 million from $253.1 million in 1975.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 (UPI) Clarence M. Kelley should be retained by President Carter as head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to maintain stability within the nation's law enforcement community, according to many of the nation's police chiefs.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 24 (AP) Phil Hubbard and Dave Baxter helped second-ranked Michigan score the last 12 points of the game tonight as the Wol verines added to their Big Ten basketball lead with a 92-81 victory over Ohio State.

GENEVA, Jan. 22 Teams of doctors have flown to two remote areas of Africa in a mission to collect blood from the few survivors of a deadly new viral disease. The doctors hope transfusions of the blood plasma portion will save lives in future epidemics.

Four of the outstanding college basketball teams in the East will participate in the third annual Madison Square Garden Classic this week, and the four head coaches agreed yesterday at a news conference that picking the winner would be a very difficult assignment.

A State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed one of two indictments against a prominent Harlem judge.

A SERIES of inquiries from readers about a dish of Italian origin, hitherto unknown to me, was the inspiration for today's column. The name of the dish is chicken scarpariello, which I learned from Italian friends means chicken shoemaker-style. It is an interesting name because the lowest compliment you can pay a French chef is to say, "He cooks like a shoemaker."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Ernest G. Green, one of nine black children who integrated Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., under the protection of Federal troops in the 1950's, will be named Assistant Secretary of Labor for Manpower.

CBS announced yesterday its "unequivocal withdrawal" from the negotiations with the Soviet Union for the 1980 summer Olympic Games from Moscow. The action was surprising in light of the fact that for much of the last year CBS was intensively bidding for the rights and had made friendly overtures to Soviet officials in the form of special programs in this country featuring the Bolshoi Ballet and Nadia Comaneci, the young Rumanian gymnastic star.

DETROIT, Jan. 25--American new car sales climbed 15.3 percent in mid-January. Analysts called it a strong performance and in line with expectations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--After an occasionally acrimonious debate in which one Senator accused another of demagoguing, the Senate confirmed Griffin B. Bell today as Attorney General.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 25 (AP)--A tanker filled with almost six million gallons of gasoline ran aground today in an approach channel to Baltimore's ice-clogged harbor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--The White House announced today that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance would make a weeklong visit to six Middle East countries starting Feb. 14 to lay the groundwork for efforts by the Carter Administration to promote further Arab-Israeli accords.

Baseball's troubled times continued yesterday when Tom Seaver advised the New York Mets that he had broken his nose playing squash racquets and Sparky Lyle advised the Yankees that he wanted a $500,000 contract for three years, or else.

TRENTON, Jan. 25--Leaders of the medical profession today issued guidelines setting up a procedure whereby lifesupport systems could be withdrawn from patients, such as Karen Anne Quinlan, who are in a vegetative, comatose state and for whom there is no hope of recovery.

EAST BURKE, Vt., Jan. 25--The mystery of why Bill Koch is not competing in this week's national crosscountry championships at Burke Mountain had more light cast on it today. Koch is the energetic Vermonter who amazed the skiing world last February by winning a silver medal in the 30-kilometer event at the Winter Olympics at Innsbruck, Austria.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 25--Melvin Dummar, a 29-year-old manual laborer from Ogden, Utah, refused under intense pressure today to denounce as a fraud a handwritten will that would give him one-sixteenth of the estate of Howard R. Hughes.

Earnings of Merrill Lynch Company rose 16 percent in the fourth quarter of 1976 and a record 11.4 percent for the full year, the securities concern announced yesterday. For 1976, moreover, the company's revenues exceeded $1 billion for the first time.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI)--Following is th 75-to-21 roll-call vote by which the Senate confirmed today the nomination of Griffin B. Bell as Attorny General.

Many advertisers consistently use the same media from year to year. Not so The New Yorker magazine, which believes the element of surprise ("Dear me, what is The New Yorker doing here?") gives additional impact to its relatively small budget.
WHEN LISTENERS of an elder generation get together, someone eventually gets around to asking, in a querulous tone, why they don't write music the way they used to. Well, in fact, they do.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 25--Syrian troops in Lebanon were today reported to be closer to the Israeli border than at any time since they intervened in the civil war.

Christy Elliott, the middleweight champion of Ireland, dropped by Madison Square Garden yesterday and met his boyhood hero, Emile Griffith, whom Elliott will fight next Wednesday in the featured 10-rounder of a tripleheader. Griffith will be 39 years old Feb. 3.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation served some 350 subpoenas yesterday on persons in the East and Gulf Coast ship- ping industries in an investigation of what one source described as "wholesale kickbacks by shipping companies to the International Longshoremen's Association."
BOSTON, Jan. 26 The body of Grace R. Garment, the missing wife of Leonard Garment, a former aide to President Nixon, was identified here today.
PARIS, Jan. 26 About the boycott by American artists, dealers, critics and collectors of the new Georges Pompidou National Center of Art and Culture, which will be opened here Monday evening by

Petr Kotik has been composing music for instruments and voices using texts by Gertrude Stein since 1971. His latest work, "Many Many Women," is too long for a conventional concert presentation, but a portion of it was performed Tuesday night by two flutists, two trombonists and four singers from the S.E.M. Ensemble at the Paula Cooper gallery, 155 Wooster Street.

MINEOLA, L.I. Jan 26 Dr. Charles E. Friedgood was sentenced today to the maximum 25-years-to-life imprisonment by a Nassau County Court judge who told the physician that he had committed a "cold, calculated and deliberate act of murder" in killing his wife.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 26 King Hussein of Jordan said today that contacts were under way for a meeting between him and Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, but that no date had been set.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 26 (AP) The secretary-treasurer of the United Mine Workers announced today that all payments and checks for the union's political action committee had been stopped as of 9 A.M.

Becton, Dickinson Company and National Medical Care Inc., announced yesterday that they had reached an agreement in principle to merge National Medical Care into Becton, Dickinson in a stock transaction valued at $143 million.

In the months leading to the Olympics, it had dominated the conversations of all those stopwatchers who speak in numbers instead of words the duel between John Walker of New Zealand and Filbert Bayi of Tanzania in the 1,500meter run. But then the African nations boycotted the Olympics last summer at Montreal and the duel evaporated. John Walker's gold medal was hollow because Filbert Bayi had not run.
Well, come to think of it, maybe moving from furniture and floor polishes into hair rinses isn't that much of a diversification after all.
Seton Hall and Holy Cross won rousing battles among Eastern basketball powers last night in the first installment of the third Madison Square Garden Classic.

BONN, Jan. 26 Chancellor Helmut Schmidt has begun talks with the new United States Government on ways to modify a controversial West German treaty to supply Brazil with nuclear technology, according to American and West German officials.

The system for disciplining physicians set up by the New York State Legislature in 1975 as part of an effort to stem the increase in malpractice suits has failed to weed out incompetent and unethical physicians, according to a report released yesterday by the New York State Consumer Protection Board.

Throughout his long campaign for the Presidency, Jimmy Carter said that he would give the enhancement of human rights in other nations a central place in his foreign policy. Thus it was no surprise that he emphasized human rights in his Inaugural Address and also in his subsequent message to "citizens of the world." And it is consistent with his intention that the State Department yesterday took note of the latest repressions in Czechoslovakia.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 26 (UPI) Rumania's ruling Communist Party has increased the membership of its top-level Permanent Bureau from five to nine, with Elena Ceausescu, the wife of the party leader and President, one of the new appointees.

Municipal labor leaders angrily warned Mayor Beame yesterday that they would refuse to accept any long-term continuation of the State Emergency Financial Control Board or any other outside control mechanism that the major banks in New York City have said would be necessary before the city could be restored to credit-worthiness.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Asserting that the natural gas shortage and cold weather had caused unemployment for 400,000 persons, President Carter submitted emer- gency legislation to Congress today and again called on the public to help ease the crisis by turning down thermostats to 65 degrees.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Bill D. Moyers, a former aide to President Johnson, was reported today to be among those seriously under consideration by President Carter as the Director of Central Intelligence.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 26 (UPI) The dollar eased on most European money markets today but inched upward against the British pound, which weakened on the expectation the Bank of England might again lower interest rates.

Recent arrests in Czechoslovakia of human rights activists drew a State Department charge of violation of the 1975 Helsinki agreement. It was the department's first public accusation against any government of noncompliance. The Carter Administration has pledged more attention to foreign failures to observe human rights. [Page 1, Column 6.]

Tonight at 9, on NBC-TV, the memory of John Fitzgerald Kennedy is gently encased in reverential dullness. The vehicle is "Johnny, We hardly Knew Ye," adapted from a chapter in the book of the same title. The fault is not in the star, Paul Rudd, but in Lionel Chetwynd's script and Gilbert Cates's direction, both of which reduce the raucous world of Boston Irish politics to stately tedium and overly calculating charm.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) E. Howard Hunt Jr., who pleaded guilty for his role in planning the Watergate break-in, will be released from prison Feb. 25 if he pays a $10,000 fine still pending against him, the Federal Parole Commission said today.
A 15-year-old girl who has been in and out of centers for difficult juveniles was accused yesterday of having killed her 50-year-old mother by strangling her with a pair of panty hose.

TRENTON, Jan. 26 Bills that would establish a legal definition of death in New Jersey and empower individuals to refuse futile medical treatment appeared today to have only a slim chance of passage this year following a legislative hearing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The State Department affirmed today that the Carter Administration intended to work for normal relations with Vietnam but said progress depended on clearing up a number of issues, including information about Americans still listed as missing from the Vietnam War.
DUBLIN, Jan. 26 (UPI) The Government announced a record $5.4 billion budget today that will increase welfare benefits and spend millions for new jobs to cut unemployment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) The International Monetary Fund today sold 780,000 ounces of gold at $133.26 an ounce in the sixth of a series of auctions that will benefit developing countries.

The New York City Planning Commission unanimously approved new zoning regulations yesterday that would ban all so-called massage parlors and eliminate pornographic movie theaters, topless bars, "peepshows" and adult bookstores in and near residential areas, and sharply curtail their numbers in commercial districts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Democratic representatives, heeding warnings that the ethical integrity of the House was at stake, ousted Representative Robert L.F. Sikes of Florida today as chairman of a key Appropriations subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) A top officer of the nation's third-largest private detective agency defended today the agency's use of information gathered by an organization that says it monitors political activists.

The Homestake Mining Company announced yesterday that it had completed a number of contracts with a group of major electric utility companies for the sale by Homestake of about 7.1 million pounds of uranium.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (AP) Bill Scanlon of Texas, a newcomer in the play-for-money ranks, upset thirdseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania, 2-6, 6-1, 6-4, tonight to reach the third round of the $200,000 United States pro indoor tennis championship.

MOZART SCOREBOARD The St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, proud to be the nation's second oldest orchestral unit, also wants it recalled that it's softball team beat that of the touring New York Philharmonic in the Missouri city last June. The Missourians hope to have another winner tonight at 8 o'clock at Carnegie Hall, when the St. Louis group makes one of its infrequent local appearances to perform Mozart's Mass in C minor.

It was Rudolf Serkin's kind of program last night in Carnegie Hall. The celebrated pianist settled for three Beethoven sonatas. Mr. Serkin really does have an extensive repertory, from Bach through Bartok but, more and more, he concentrates on Beethoven, his greatest love. At this stage of his life he is obviously willing to let the younger generation explore the repertory. He is going to for the unsearchable in Beethoven.

ROME, Jan. 26 Vice President Mondale arrived in Rometoday after a visit to the Berlin Wall to reaffirm a United States commitment to use whatever means may be necessary to preserve the freedom of the divided city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Mayor Beame arrived at the Capitol today lugging a 120-page Federal legislative program for New York City for 1977. It calls for a massive increase in Federal spending and responsibilities.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported yesterday a decline of 47.5 percent in fourth-quarter net income as sales edged ahead by 1.6 percent. This contrasted with the United States Steel Corporation's fourth-quarter decline of 27.9 percent in net income on a sales gain of 4.2 percent.

Trustees of the State University of New York, which is smarting from its own budgetary wounds, said yesterday that it would prefer to remain a system separate from the financially crippled City University, but would consider merger if the state's financial position worsened.

CROSS RIVER, N.Y., Jan. 26 The tall red pine trees stood gaunt against the sky on the snow-covered banks of the reservoir here, their limbs devoid of the bright evergreen needles that are the tell-tale signs of healthy, normal pine trees.

OTTAWA, Jan. 26 Like many other Canadians, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau reacted sharply today to the remark of Premier Rene Levesque in New York last night that independence for the French-speaking province of Quebec was inevitable.
Glamour stocks, once the market's favorite group, came under renewed selling pressure yesterday as prices generally gave ground across a broad front in active trading.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 26 (AP) The troubled financial situation involving the National Hockey League's Cleveland Barons remained unclear today as Mel Swig, the team owner, withheld his decision on the league's offer of assistance.

The board of directors of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation voted yesterday to remove Dr. John L.S. Holloman Jr. as its president at the insistence of Mayor Beame and despite angry protests by blacks that resulted in an assault on one board member.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 In renewing today his plea for the public to accept discomfort and chilly rooms by conserving heating fuel, President Carter was embarking on an early test of his personal leadership.

TRENTON, Jan. 26 The New Jersey Supreme Court held today, in a 4-to-3 ruling, that it did not have the power to require cities to provide "quotas" of housing for low-income and middle-income families, and that such decisions must be made by the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, sent a message of discontent to President Carter today, signaling the first suggestion of strained relations between the White House and Congressional Democratic leaders.

Donald M. Klock, former president of the Duffy-Mott Company, received a oneyear prison sentence on tax-evasion charges yesterday from a Federal judge who said that wealthy defendants should not receive special treatment.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 26 Melvin Dummar, a beneficiary in the so-called "Mormon will" of Howard R. Hughes and a central figure in the attempt to establish the document's authenticity, was dismissed from the United States Air Force after six months because of emotional problems, it was disclosed in court today.

Robert de Gaetano's recital at Kaufmann Concert Hall of the 92d Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. Tuesday night reaffirmed his reputation as a pianist of formidable technical equipment. In works as different in their demands as Shostakovich's Sonata No. 1 (Op. 12), Ravel's "Jeux d'eau" and three pieces by Chopin, the young product of the Juilliard School played with impeccable fingers.

MADRID, Jan. 26 Confronting a menacing wave of political violence, the Government announced tonight that it was banning public demonstrations, expelling foreigners with "extremist" sympathies and restricting the use of private arms while at the same time continuing with its plans to hold general elections.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that his department would conduct a broad study of welfare reform with help from other Cabinet agencies, key Congressional committees, state and local officials and welfare recipients.

A State Supreme Court justice in White Plains upheld an arbitrator's decision that the Yonkers school board illegally dismissed 300 teachers last year in an economy move. But in rendering the decision, Justice Fred Dickenson in effect told the plaintiff, the Yonkers Federation of Teachers, it would have to sue the City of Yonkers in a separate action to get the teachers rehired.
Fred I. Archibald, former publisher of The Baltimore News American, died Tuesday at Johns Hopkins Hospital. He was 83 years old and was a resident of Baltimore.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 26 An opposition political leader charged today that continued enforcement of an emergency decree by President Park Chung Hee would weaken national unity. Lee Chol Sung, speaking at a news conference, said the two-year-old decree, which prevents free political activity, should be abolished.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) The Senate today confirmed the appointment of Representative Andrew Young to be the chief United States delegate to the United Nations.

BARNEGAT LIGHT, Jan. 26 A few of the birds took flight in alarm, but most of about 1,000 black ducks and brant remained a few hundred feet offshore as the two men walked slowly across the sand strewing handfuls of corn along the water's edge.

Bruce Hungerford, concert pianist and Egyptologist, was killed early yesterday in an automobile accident in the Pelham Bay Park area of the Bronx. He was 54 years old. Also fatally injured in the accident were Mr. Hungerford's mother, Anna Hungerford, and Mr. and Mrs. Sal Azriel, Mrs. Azriel was Mr. Hungerford's niece.
"Better late than never, but I've doubled my usual donation in honor of our country's 200th birthday," wrote Emily A. Stanley of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Asserting that the natural gas shortage and cold weather had caused unemployment for 400,000 persons, President Carter submitted emergency legislation to Congress today and again called on the public to help ease the crisis by turning down thermostats to 65 degrees.

CHAMWINO, Tanzania Amid recurrent reports of shortages and unemployment in the cities, this rural cooperative village and others like it sustain the vision of a socialist, egalitarian and selfsufficient Tanzania.
PARIS, Jan. 26 In France, it appears that haute couture and Communism are compatible.

CAIRO, Jan. 26 (Reuters) The Egyptian Government today banned demonstrations and strikes but said there would be no going back on political and economic liberalization measures introduced by President Anwar el-Sadat.
An order by a Federal judge in a libel suit that CBS turn over to him a producer's notes about a CBS documentary has raised new questions about the confidentiality of the editorial process.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (AP) A movie producer and director, Laurence Merrick, maker of the documentary film "Manson," based on the Charles M. Manson cult, was shot to death today at his film school in Hollywood by an unidentified assailant, the police said. The gunman escaped.
Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

The Museum of Modern Art has decided to recommend Cesar Pelli, the Los Angeles architect who became dean of the Yale School of Architecture this month, as architect for its proposed $40 million condominium apartment tower and gallery addition.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 26 (Reuters) A Greek Cypriot journalist, Eleftherios Papadopoulos, was charged today with having supported the 1974 coup attempt against Archbishop Makarios.

Following is the text of Charter 77, a Czechoslovak human-rights manifesto cited by the State Department yesterday as evidence of rights violations. It was translated by and published in the current issue of The New Leader, dated Jan. 31.

Louis J. Lefkowitz, the New York State Attorney General, said yesterday that he already had a lawsuit pending against the Korean Cultural and Freedom Foundation, but that he expected to seek an injunction against the group in response to action by the state's Board of Social Welfare.

There were two encouraging aspects to the program of music by Neely Bruce presented in Town Hall on Tuesday night. The composer's interest in musical Americana seems to have rubbed off on him; his best work has a maverick humor. Also, the more recent his music, the better it gets.

LOS ANGELES In a little-noticed item in the financial news recently, the Walter Reade Organization of New York, which operates 29 major movie theaters around the country, announced it had filed a petition seeking protection from creditors under Federal bankruptcy laws.

Expressing concern for the "scandalous potential" involved in the suddenly flourishing agent business, Marvin Miller severely criticized some player agents yesterday for what he charged were their ripoff and fee-gouging practices.

Market Place A leading stock brokerage firm rescinded a trade for one of its customers in mid-November last year in a stock in which the firm had an interest. The action has raised questions about whether a conflict of interest existed.
PARIS, Jan. 26 President Valery Giscard d'Estaing made his first personal attack today on the decision of his former Prime Minister, Jacques Chirac, to run for mayor of Paris.

HOBOKEN, Jan. 26 Tensio nin a threeday-old strike by the faculty of the Stevens Institute of Technology heightened today when three professors accused the administration of violation of free speech and "the traditions of academic freedom" after they were barred from entry to the campus to give a student meeting their side of the contract dispute.
HUNTINGTON, W. Va. Hope is an active dream. It does not exist unless there is also the possibility of that dream coming true.

The United States has not had a coherent policy toward the third world. What we have mistaken for a policy has been a set of reactions, usually negative, to demands by third-world spokesmen and international secretariats or a set of tactical improvisations until the latest crisis or the next deadline.

The election of Fred M. Hechinger, a member of the editorial board of The New York Times, as president of The New York Times Company Foundation was announced today by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and president of The New York Times Company.

Studies of oysters, clams and mussels that grow in scores of America's polluted coastal bays and rivers have disclosed cancer-like growths in a relatively large number of the shellfish, the National Marine Fisheries Service has reported.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 26 (UPI) The state's smog control standards will force Californians to pay more for new cars in the next eight years than residents of other states, a legislative analyst, A. Alan Post, says.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) The Pentagon Civil Defense Agency has told more than 2,000 stations on its national warning system to improve their plans for action in the event of an accidental Soviet missile attack on the United States.

Pledging to "liberate" the city from the banks and from Governor Carey and the Emergency Financial Control Board, Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan announced his candidacy for Mayor yesterday.

HONG KONG, Jan. 26 China regards defense against the Soviet Union as its most important problem and believes the Taiwan question is a secondary issue that can wait, according to a speech purportedly given by a senior Chinese official last summer.
Raymond F. Maguire, a retired New York City police inspector, died yesterday at Peninsula Hospital, Far Rockaway, Queens. He was 72 years old and lived at 2210 Avenue T. Brooklyn.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 Los Angeles is experiencing a widespread outbreak of measles that has already claimed the life of an 18-month-old child and threatens to leave hundreds more victims with complications ranging from pneumonia to encephalitis.

The tone was friendly enough. The salutation was "Dear Abe" and the signature was "Chuck," a persona that Charles F. Luce, chairman of the Consolidated Edison Company sometimes takes on when he is dealing with city officials.
The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest reports of changes in stock ownership by large stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 26 Vietnam is planning to establish its own state oil company and will shortly approve a detailed foreign-investment code designed to pave the way this year for the large-scale entry of foreign oil companies and other major international private investors.

In the last 20 years in the United States and Europe there have been many experiments, some successful, some less so, with computer scoring. Some of these plans have been combined with the Swedish idea of a "barometer," which allows players to know round by round how they are faring.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation served some 350 subpoenas yesterday on persons in the East and Gulf Coast shipping industries in an investigation of what one source described as "wholesale kickbacks by shipping companies to the International Longshoremen's Association."

NEW HAVEN Christopher Durang, a young graduate of the Yale Drama School, is a one-man Yale lampoon. He is a diabolically comic writer whose ammunition is ridicule and whose weapon is scattergun. He splays his satiric shots all over the stage, a stage which in the case of Mr. Durang's new comedy, "The Vietnamization of New Jersey (A American Tragedy)," is also littered with cornflakes, smashed crockery and other detritus of civilization.

The New York City Planning Commission unanimously approved new zoning regulations yesterday that would ban all so-called massage parlors and eliminate pornographic movie theaters, topless bars, "peepshows" and adult bookstores in and near residential areas, and sharply curtail their numbers in commercial districts.
Margaret Hayes, stage, television and screen actress, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Medical Center in Biami Beach. A resident of Palm Beach, Fla., she was 63 years old.

PARIS, Jan. 26 So how is the revolution doing down at Yves Saint Laurent's place? Just fine, thank you. The peasants are prospering. Things are quieter. Everybody's becoming a bit more bourgeois. Consolidating the gains, so to speak.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) The United States Department of Justice filed suit today to revoke the citizenship of a suspected Nazi war criminal accused of beating and killing civilians in Poland in World War II.

CROSS RIVER, N.Y., Jan. 26 The tall red pine trees stood gaunt against the sky on the snow-covered banks of the reservoir here, their limbs devoid of the bright evergreen needles that are the tell-tale signs of healthy, normal pine trees.
Dr. Sydney Mark Kanev, an osteopathic physician in New York City for 45 years, died yesterday in his home at 530 Park Avenue. He was 73 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 Syracuse University's basketball coach, Jim Boeheim, believes, with some justification, that he has the best pure center in the East. This is Roosevelt Bouie, a 6-foot-11-inch coordinated freshman from Kendall, a little town in the upstate New York snow belt.

The credit markets moved in a narrow range most of the day yesterday as they waited to see how the Treasury would refinance its 8 percent notes maturing in mid-February and how much additional cash it would borrow.

The gradual yet careful exploration of the lesser-known reaches of Euro- pean drama continues apace in Brooklyn, where the Chelsea Theater Center yesterday gave us the American premiere of Stanislaw Ignacy Witkiewicz's play "The Crazy Locomotive." It was certainly crazy even loco but not uninteresting.

Discerning visitors to the State Department used to find a touch of squalor in the hushed, cherry-paneled elegance of the executive offices: each telephone carried a button marked "MON." By pushing the button when officials took phone calls, stenographers would listen in silently, without the callers' knowledge, take furious' shorthand, and later provide typed transcripts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Treasury's new debt-management team, announcing terms of a February refunding package, appeared today to have charted a course that envisions no radical departures from policies of the Ford Administration.

Cries of "George" filled the air on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater. The occasion, of course, was the New York City Ballet's first performance since its orchestra returned to work after a six-week strike and the resumption of the winter season.

Steve Cauthen didn't want to talk to the press yesterday at Aqueduct. He made it hard not to, though. The 16-year-old jockey wonder rode four consecutive winners, including Make Amends in the $36,550 Count Fleet
Max Stern, a Jewish civic leader and business executive, has been elected president of the advisory council of the New York Board of Rabbis.

ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 26 (AP) A defense attorney for the entertainer Claudine Longet, who was convicted Jan. 15 in the shooting death of her lover, said today that he would not try to delay her sentencing, set for Monday.

DETROIT, Jan. 26 American auto production is scheduled to total 191,408 this week, an increase of 17.7 percent from 162,681 last week and a 13.6 percent rise from the 168,481 units built in the year-earlier level, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.

Pledging to "liberate" the city from the banks and from Governor Carey and the Emergency Financial Control Board, Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan announced his candidacy for Mayor yesterday.

While Deborah Lawson believes that a number of humane societies have evolved into huge bureaucracies, the Philadelphia-based radio talk show commentator made it equally clear recently to members of the Dog Fanciers.

PHOENIX, Jan. 26 John Harvey Adamson, a Phoenix racing dog owner, testified today that he had been hired by a wealthy Phoenix contractor, Max Dunlap, to murder a reporter, Don Bolles, and two other men for $50,000 at the request of Kemper Marley Sr., one of arizona's wealthiest men.

Petr Kotik has been composing music for instruments and voices using texts by Gertrude Stein since 1971. His latest work, "Many Many Women," is too long for a conventional concert presentation, but a portion of it was performed Tuesday night by two flutists, two trombonists and four singers from the S.E.M. Ensemble at the Paula Cooper gallery, 155 Wooster Street.

The electric utility industry's reaserch organization and two energy companies announced yesterday that they planned to spend $7.6 million over the next three years to spur development of zinc-chlorine batteries. The batteries would be used in electric cars and as an energystorage system for utilities.

The Japanese Government, responding to evidence that the American pilot of a Japan Air Lines cargo jet was intoxicated when the plane crashed in Alaska Jan. 13, took steps yesterday to have pilots of all its airliners undergo preflight alcohol checks.
Bernard (Toots) Shor, who died Sunday night at the age of 73, was eulogized yesterday at Temple Emanu-El as "the world's greatest saloonkeeper" who also was a "warm, generous and religious man."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Defense Secretary Harold Brown said today there were "reasonable prospects" for a new agreement on strategic-arms limitation with the Soviet Union this year, and that his attitude toward spending money on new strategic weapons was partly influenced by that possibility.

The Museum of Modern Art has decided to recommend Cesar Pelli, the Los Angeles architect who became dean of the Yale School of Architecture this month, as architect for its proposed $40 million condominium apartment tower and gallery addition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 In June of 1963, President Kennedy appointed Henry Cabot Lodge of Massachusetts, who had been the Republican candidate for Vice President in 1960, to be Ambassador to South Vietnam. This foreclosed "mainstream" Republican opposition to the way the war was conducted until 1967.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Great Western United Corporation is to refund almost $4 million to some 14,000 investors in three land development projects in Colorado, California and New Mexico under an agreement negotiated with the Federal Trade Commission and an announced today.
The news in the key commodity futures markets came after the close of trading again yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The State Department said today that the United States would not support any negotiations initiated by Prime Minister Smith for a solution in Rhodesia that excludes the black nationalist leaders of that country.

DETROIT, Jan. 26 The Michigan Highway Commission today canceled a 20year-old plan to build a 24-mile stretch of highway that would have saved drivers eight minutes but would have cost $69.5 million and cut through a state park.

DETROIT, Jan. 26 (AP) Ralph Simpson and Marvin Barnes came off the bench tonight to rally the Detroit Pistons from a 15-point deficit to a 103-101 overtime victory over the New York Nets in a National Basketball Association game.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 Standing before a stern-faced judge, his back to his weeping relatives, Alan G. Hochberg was sentenced today to spend one year in jail for attempting to bribe a potential opponent into not running for his Bronx Assembly seat. He immediately lost the seat, in the 81st Assembly District, to which he had been re-elected overwhelmingly last November.
Gov. Milton Shapp of Pennsylvania yesterday ordered all the state's public and private schools closed until at least next Monday to conserve natural gas.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 26 (AP) The military Government banned two religious sects today on the ground that they flouted the principles of Argentine nationhood, morals and customs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 A potential flashpoint in relations between the new Carter Administration and the nation's business and industry is the issue of environmental regulations and their enforcement. It is a conflict that could flare up quickly.

The Atlanta Rhythm Section has been toiling along in the second echelon of Southern rock-and-roll bands for quite a few years now. Its members are much too good to be relegated to the rank and file, but so far they have not been able to find a hit that would put them over the top. This is too bad; musically speaking, they are the best the South has to offer.
LONDON, Jan. 26 A special Government committee today proposed radical changes in the running of British industry, including giving workers an equal say with their bosses in all business decisions.
DETROIT, Jan. 26 Charles Hume Patterson, who served as the No. 3 man at the Ford Motor Company from 1963 to 1967, died Monday in a nursing home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. He was 74 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The State Department charged Czechoslovakia today with having violated the provisions of the 1975 Helsinki agreement by a series of arrests and harassment of humanrights activists.
Houston H. Wasson, a lawyer, died yesterday at his Waccabuc, N.Y., home. He was 65 years old.

A one-year moratorium was established on the installation in five New Jersey counties of new computerized X-ray devices criticized by Blue Cross and state officials as too expensive for widescale use. Seven devices, already installed or approved, will not be affected by the ban.

Buoyed by strong domestic petroleum earnings, the Mobil Corporation, parent of the Mobil Oil Corporation, yesterday reported a fourth-quarter earnings gain of 33.5 percent. Earnings for the year were up 16.3 percent.
Charles P. Heidt, a Broadway producer who was a World War I combat pilot, died in Philadelphia on Monday. He was 82 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The State Department charged Czechoslovakia today with having violated the provisions of the 1975 Helsinki agreement by a series of arrests and harassment of humanrights activists.
Dick Szymanski, who has been drawing Baltimore Colts' paychecks since 1955, was elevated to general manager yesterday to replace Joe Thomas.
"Better late than never, but I've doubled my usual donation in honor of our country's 200th birthday," wrote Emily A. Stanley of New York City.

MOZART SCOREBOARD, The St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, proud to be the nation's second oldest orchestral unit, also wants it recalled that it's softball team beat that of the touring New York Philharmonic in the Missouri city last June. The Missourians hope to have another winner tonight at 8 o'clock at Carnegie Hall, when the St. Louis group makes one of its infrequent local appearances to perform Mozart's Mass in C minor.

FRANKFURT The Arthur F. Burns of West Germany is Karl Klasen, president of the Bundesbank, the country's central bank. The similarities between the two men are striking: both are courteous and conservative in style and thought.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Jan. 26 (UPI) A major dog hunt is under way in two jungle regions to stamp out a rabies epidemic that has killed more than 50 persons, the Health Ministry said today.

DETROIT, Jan. 26 (UPI) Federal prosecutors said today that Archbishop Valerian Trifa, accused of participating in a pro-Nazi movement in Rumania in World War II, had answered all questions at a meeting with Government attorneys yesterday.

Maurice Rubin, a lawyer, author and engineer who worked on a phase of the atomic bomb project, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He lived at 1 Plaza Street, Brooklyn, and was 78 years old.

TRENTON, Jan. 26 The New Jersey Supreme Court held today, in a 4-to-3 ruling, that it did not have the power to require cities to allow housing "quotas" for low-and middle-income families, and that such decisions must be made by the Legislature.

MADRID, Jan. 26?Confronting a menacing wave of political violence, the Government announced tonight that it was banning public demonstrations, expelling foreigners with "extremist" sympathies and restricting the use of private arms while at the same time continuing with its plans to hold general elections.
LEBANON, Beirut, Jan. 26 The Syriandominated Arab peacekeeping force today seized four army barracks that had been under the control of the rebel Lebanese Arab Army.

The board of directors of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation voted yesterday to remove Dr. John L.S. Holloman Jr. as its president at the insistence of Mayor Beame and despite angry protests by blacks that resulted in an assault on one board member.
PEKING, Jan. 26 (Agence FrancePresse) China today supported Charter 77, a manifesto signed by 300 Czechoslovaks in protest against human rights violations.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 26 Two local players moved into the quarterfinals of the $20,000 Avon Futures women's tennis tournament today and a third was eliminated.

TRENTON, Jan. 26 A special state task force on juvenile justice urged the New Jersey Supreme Court today to adopt "substantial changes" in the rules governing confidentiality of court proceedings ;involving juveniles. One change would require the disclosure of the identi- ty of juvenile delinquents involved in serious crimes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 In renewing today his plea for the public to accept discomfort and chilly rooms by conserving heating fuel, President Carter was embarking on an early test of his personal leadership.

HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 26 (AP) Irina Rodnina and Aleksandr Zaitsev of the Soviet Union won the European pairs figure-skating championship today. For Miss Rodnina it was the ninth European title; it was Zaitsev's fifth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 F. Ray Marshall, confirmed as Secretary of Labor by the Senate this afternoon, admonished industry today to press forward with the hiring of minority and women workers despite the current high level of unemployment.
Mr. Kong, the celebrated simian, has waited 44 years to tell his story. Countess Ciano, Il Duce's daughter, has waited only 30 years to tell hers. On the whole Mr. Kong is more credible.

Stanley H. Moger is the kind of guy who collects tapes of old radio series as well as decoder rings and other related memorabilia. He also is the kind of guy who believes that advertisers lost a lot when they lost their identification as program sponsors.
JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 26 (UPI) Britain and the United States have been in contact over the failure of the latest peace plan for Rhodesia, the British negotiator, Ivor Richard, said today.

Recent arrests in Czechoslovakia of human rights activists drew a State Department charge of violation of the 1975 Helsinki agreement. It was the department's first public accusation against any government of noncompliance. The Carter Administration has pledged more attention to foreign failures to observe human rights.

TOKYO, Jan. 26 The Liberal-Democratic Party, a governing party of many rival factions that is still numbed by the shocks of the Lockheed scandal and its subsequent defeat in the December parliamentary election, met today for its annual convention and acted as if nothing had happened.

CRANS-MONTANA, Switzerland, Jan. 26 (AP) The French women's team, led by Perrine Pelen, a 16-year-old newcomer, staged a World Cup comeback today in a slalom race marked by unusual snow and weather conditions.

LOS ANGELES In a little-noticed item in the financial news recently, the Walter Reade Organization of New York, which operates 29 major movie theaters around the country, announced it had filed a petition seeking protection from creditors under Federal bankruptcy laws.

The sudden death of Marshall Williams, 21-year-old starting center on the Adelphi University basketball team, in Tuesday night's game at Southampton College may cause the postponement or cancellation of Saturday's Adelphi-New Hampshire game, and may also result in the cancellation of the remainder of Adelphi's basketball schedule.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, sent a message of discontent to President Carter today, signaling the first suggestion of strained relations between the White House and Congressional Democratic leaders.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 27 A delegate from the tiny West African country of Gambia took the floor and suggested that a resolution be passed demanding total amnesty for all imprisoned African intellectuals. He was loudly applauded, but no such resolution was offered.

ABC-TV has hit the jackpot with its gamble in scheduling "Roots" over eight consecutive nights beginning last Sunday. That pattern of presentation is rare in prime-time television and risky, since ABC's ratings for an entire week would have been seriously damaged if the program had failed to capture the fancy of the viewers on the first night.
The American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday that reserves of home heating oil continued to drop faster than normal, although not as markedly as a week earlier.

UNIONDALE, L.I. Jan. 27 The Islanders lost, 2-1, to the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight, but no one is sure how it happened. Most of the 60 minutes played at Nassau Coliseum were consumed with Islanders shooting at the Maple Leaf goal or chasing an iced puck at the other end of the rink.

The bond market declined sharply yesterday in the wake of the Treasury's announcement of its plans to refinance $2.1 billion of publicly held 8 percent notes and to raise $3.7 billion of additional cash.

The Adelphi University basketball team, mourning the death of its starting center, canceled its game tomorrow against New Hampshire College. The Adelphi players will hold a team meeting today to decide whether to continue playing this season. The Panthers' next scheduled game is Wednesday night at Brooklyn College.

PRAGUE, Jan. 27 Czechoslovakia appeared to be moving today toward expelling some human-rights activists as four dissidents reportedly were asked to appear at the passport and visa office here tomorrow.

William F. Doscher, who retired last summer as president and chief executive officer of USLIFE Mutual Funds Management Corporation of Manhattan, now known as Sentinel Advisors Inc., died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 56 years old and lived at 17 Anondale Drive in Huntington, L.I.

Kirk Nurock, a composer for theater and dance groups and director of "Natural Sound" workshops for singers and audience participation, performed as a jazz pianist at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday. His style welded classical techniques onto the structures of jazz compositions through the medium of a rather remarkable facility.

Industrial consumption of silver in the United States rose by 6 percent in 1976 to an estimated 167.5 million ounces, according to the 61st annual review of the silver market released yesterday by Handy Harman. This was the first increase in industrial usage since 1973 when such consumption hit a record high of 196.4 million ounces.

SPRINGFIELD, Ore., Jan. 27 (AP) A special issue of Life magazine on the American woman has been banned from use as a high school text by the school board because it contains a photograph of a nude woman.

DALLAS, Jan. 27 A biology textbook containing the New Testament concept of the creation theory of the origin of man was approved here yesterday by the trustees of the Dallas Independent School District for use as a source book by high school biology students.
TRENTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) Five of New Jersey's largest banks have filed suit to recover $185,000 lent to the 1973 campaign of Governor byrne.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 27 (AP) Prime Minister Ian D. Smith won the backing today of his governing party, the Rhodesian Front, for a plan that he said would end racial discrimination and in two years set up black majority rule.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 211.6 from 208.2 last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) The National Weather Service says the harshest winter in at least five years shows no signs of releasing its frigid grip on the Eastern and Midwestern sections of the United States during the next two weeks.

BELGRADE, Jan. 27 Mounting criticism of civil-rights proponents at home and abroad seems unlikely to faze Czechoslovakia's leaders who evidently feel that their political and economic base is secure and that Soviet backing remains strong.

The Public Service Commission, which last month rejected an application by the New York Telephone Company for a $393 million rate increase on the ground that the utility had not submitted sufficient data, agreed yesterday to consider an amplified application.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The Carter Administration presented to Congress today its $31.1 billion package of economic stimulants, including a $50 tax rebate aimed at 96 percent of the population as the centerpiece of plans to spur growth through greater consumption.

HIS SPRING a first novel called "Jocelyn" will be published here by Holt, Rinehart Winston. Written by John Sinjohn in 1898, it had a printing of only 750 copies in England before being branded a "dreadful little book" by its author and relegated to oblivion. "Jocelyn" was withdrawn by him because it was a thinly disguised autobiographic story of a passionate and illicit romance.
New York City has won a $500,000 grant from the Federal Government to create an experimental pedestrian mall in Times Square this summer that would become permanent if it proved successful.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Jan. 27 Joe Namath, deeply tanned, smiling and relaxed after this pro-am competition today in the American Airlines Golf Classic, had an even bigger smile when asked whether he would like to continue his fading football career with the Los Angeles Rams.
Nobody expects two-thirds of Maine to be given back to the Indians, but a lawsuit with that objective is causing officials of the state serious concern all the same and with good reason.
Shearson Hayden Stone Inc. withdrew its offer yesterday to merge with the Orion Capital Corporation after Orion's directors unanimously rejected the proposal put forward by the investment firm.

Although the formal tax package presented by the Carter Administration on Capitol Hill yesterday contained some tax breaks for business, many industrialists believe it was still not clearly focused enough to achieve the Admin istration's economic goals.
Jury selection continued in the New Brunswick murder trial of Joanne Ches imard as 12 jurors were retained in a preliminary screening process.

For some years now various Christian communities stemming from the 16thcentury Reformation or of later origin have been admitting women to the pastoral office on a par with men. Total pretax income of black Americans will increase 13.2 percent this year to $87.3 billion, Andrew F. Brimmer, president of Brimmer Company and former governor of the Federal Reserve System, predicted yesterday.

A Federal grand jury in Manhattan indicted three business executives yesterday on charges that they had participated in a scheme involving "secret kickbacks" to defraud the Hartz Mountain Corporation.

DETROIT, Jan. 27 In an effort to increase sales, the General Motors Corporation announced today a program whereby its 500,000 hourly employees and retiress in the United States would be able to receive cash refunds ranging from $200 to $500 on the purchase of new vehicles.

The soprano saxophone, which is straight, not curved like the other members of the saxophone family and looks something like a slightly swollen clarinet, was considered an archaic instrument during the 1950's. It was played by a few old-time jazz musicians, notably Sidney Bechet, but modern jazz and classical players would not touch it. It was too unreliable, they said, too difficult to play in tune.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 27 (UPI) The American Legion's national organization is not trying to expel President Carter from membership, William J. Rogers, Commander, said today.
Honeywell Inc. yesterday introduced what it called the largest most powerful computer in its 20-year history in the data-processing field.

The five Croatian nationalists who have been accused of air piracy involving the hijacking of an airliner and the killing of a police officer last September can be prosecuted in Brooklyn, a Federal appeals court ruled yesterday, reversing a lower-court ruling.
The Grumman Corporation said yesterday that the settlement of its long-stanling claims with the United States Navy for F-14 fighter costs will reduce the company's fourth-quarter earnings for 1976.
LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP) Oil production from the British sector of the North Sea last year fell below expectations to about 12 million tons, the Energy Department said today.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 26 Saudi Arabia's oil minister Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said today that individual talks would start soon with other oil-producing countries to seek an agreement that would end the two-tier pricing system established in December.

RICHFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 27 By making three pressure baskets in the final two minutes the Cleveland Cavaliers who trailed by 7 points with 4 minutes to play managed to beat the New York Knicks, 113-111, tonight before a vocal crowd of 15,194 at the Coliseum.
TOKYO, Jan. 27 Former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka tearfully denied all accusations on the opening day of his trial on charges of accepting bribes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

Investment bankers who underwrite municipal bonds are telling the New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, that they agree with the leading commercial banks in the city on the necessity of an outside agency to monitor New York's finances to market the city's bonds in the future.
Robert Molloy, novelist, translator and newspaperman, died yesterday at Bergen Pines Hospital, Paramus, N.J. He was 71 years old and lived in Paramus.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 27 Emmitt Berry, a junior from the University of Texas at El Paso, and Ian Pyka, a sophomore from the University of Maryland, captured the Millrose Games' 35-pound weight throw and shot-put events tonight at Yale's Cox Cage.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 27 (UPI) An attorney for Howard R. Hughes's relatives accused Melvin Dummar today of researching material for the so-called "Mormon will" that would leave millions of dollars to Mr. Dummar. He also accused Mr. Dummar's wife, Bonnie, of writing the document.

The important position of director of the United Nations Human Rights Commission went yesterday to Theodoor van Boven, a lawyer and diplomat from The Netherlands who was educated in Texas. Mr. Van Boven, an official in the Dutch Foreign Ministry, has been serving on a United Nations subcommission on the prevention of discrimination and protection of minorities. He is a graduate of the University of Texas and also studied at Southern Methodist University in Dallas.

There has been a sharp decrease in the number of defendants who have been detained in jail for more than a year while awaiting trial, the statewide administrative judge said yesterday. Charles F. Grisham, an enlisted Navy man who rose from the ranks to become a captain, and flagship commander for several admirals, died Wednesday at the Veterans Hospital in New Orleans after being stricken while on vacation. He was 86 years old and lived at 56 Willard Avenue, Old Saybrook, Conn.

A month after the General Electric Company consummated the largest merger in United States history, the company's chairman, Reginald H. Jones, appeared at a news conference in New York yesterday to announce record profits and support for a program of economic stimulation.

President Carter's fiscal stimulus proposals, as presented to Congress by Budget Director Bert Lance, have been expanded to an investment of $31.1 billion over a 20-month period. ROME, Jan. 27 (UPI) The Vatican, affirming the refusal of the Roman Catholic Church to ordain women as priests, said today that they could not qualify because Jesus was a man and His representatives on earth must have a "natural resemblance" to him.

The New York State Racing and Wagering Board announced yesterday that in the last race on the last program of Roosevelt Raceway's summer meeting last July 17, a 4-year-old pacer named Main Morris went a mile in 1 minute 59 3/5 seconds. This may strike some as a matter of less than cosmic significance, and it does seem that the N.Y.S.R. W.B. took its own sweet time about making the announcement.

In another attempt to strengthen their frontline, the New York Nets picked up Mike Bantom yesterday from the Seattle SuperSonics. The 6-foot-9inch, 210-pound Bantom, who played college basketball at St. Joseph's in Philadelphia, is in his fourth season in the National Basketball Association.
CHANGING THE SET in full view of the audience is almost a stage convention nowadays. But in the T. Schreiber Theater's production of "Curtains" by the British playwright Tom Mallin, it is disastrous.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 President Carter will soon announce, according to Administration sources, the appointment of Douglas Costle as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.

The two-week-old natural-gas crisis bit more deeply for millions of Americans yesterday as the effects of the bitter, persistent cold were forcing shutdowns of stores and factories in Pennsylvania and causing school closings there and in Ohio, new layoffs for hundreds of thousands of people in a dozen states and warnings of possible further hardships.
The nation's money supply declined in the week ended Jan 19, according to data released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 When Warren M. Christopher goes before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee for confirmation hearings as Deputy Secretary of State, Senator Jacob K. Javits says he intends to raise the question of Mr. Christopher's role in the Government's surveillance of citizens' political activity in the late 1960's.

First Boston Inc., parent company of the First Boston Corporation, reported yesterday that its earnings for the fourth quarter of 1976 were $8.6 million, or $2.59 a share, up 83 percent from $4.7 million, of $1.47 a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenues totaled $39.8 million, up from $27 million in the fourth quarter of 1975.

EVANSTON, Ill., Jan 27 A book by a Northwestern University professor that says the Nazi extermination of European Jews was nothing more than a Zionist-inspired myth has caused a storm of campus and community protest and has embarrassed university administrators.

THE TITLE of Earl Thompson's new novel, "Caldo Largo" which literally means "abundant soup"-refers to a "Mexi can bouillabaise" that keeps simmering day and night in a fishing boat's galley and is called by its cook "the soup of life." The novel is well-named, for it brims with boisterous vitality and Fairly bubbles along.
CHERRY HILL, Jan. 27 "The phone never rings when I'm on a horse," Addison G. Bradley said today.

Sanders Associates Inc. said it had entered into an agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation whereby Sanders would develop advanced computer-related products for I.B.M. and Sanders would withdraw its antitrust suit against the large computer company.

Eleven firemen were injured in two fires in Nassau County, 10 of them when a home in Bay Park exploded after it caught fire. Six of the volunteer firemen from East Rockaway were blown out of the one-story house while fighting the fire and four others were injured by flying debris.

THE CANADIAN ANIMATOR Caroline Leaf has devised a technique in which lines have a dreamy smudginess and seem to float out of one another. The effect is half comical, halt poetic, and Miss Leaf used it triumphantly in a short film about the love of an owl for a duck, shown last year at the Film Forum.
The soaring cost of product liability Insurance has produced "real horror stories" among small businesses, according to the National Federation of Independent Business.
WASHINGTON, JAN. 27 (Reuters) The International Monetary Fund said 15 banks and dealers submitted successful bids at the auction yesterday of 780,000 ounces of gold.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 American Catholic spokesmen here emphasized today that the question of ordaining women was a closed matter now that the Vatican had affirmed its opposition.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 (UPI) A codicil to a purported will of Mr. Hughes has been sealed in plastic and stored in a special vault pending the outcome of litigation over the Hughes estate.
A Federal grand jury in Wichita, Kan., is investigating the possible submission of identical bids to the Federal Government by grain milling and processing companies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The State Department said today that if the Soviet Union tried to silence Andrei D. Sakharov, the political dissident, it would be in conflict "with accepted international standards of human rights."
TRENTON, Jan. 27 The New Jersey Supreme Court's latest zoning ruling handed down yesterday, left unanswered a major question: Who is going to build suburban housing for the poor?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Secretary of Labor F. Ray Marshall announced today a plan to create 200,000 jobs for unemployed Vietnam veterans, a $1.3 billion proposal designed to complement President Carter's pardon of Vietnam draft resisters last week.

What could be lovelier than chamber music by candlelight? Chamber music by candlelight with champagne-which is what they'll have Sunday night at 7:30 at the exquisite Burden Mansion, 7 East 91st Street. L'Ensemble, a six-year-old chamber group of top-level professionals, will give a Russian program Rachmaninoff and Tchaikovsky-in the landmark building's rococo ballroom (which is reached via one of the most elegant marble stairways in town).
No sooner had three tellers at a Chemical Bank branch on Madison. Avenue handed more than $60,000 to a holdup man yesterday than one of the bank's tellers chased the suspect.

LONDON, Jan. 27 A high British court broke new constitutional ground today in ruling that aggrieved private citizens were free to appear before it even when the Government's highest legal officer did not want them to.
Steve Cauthen and the New York Racing Association both had losing days yesterday at Aqueduct.
A former executive of the Korvette department stores has filed charges of religious discrimination against the retail chain, alleging he was dismissed because of his refusal to work on Sundays.

LONDON, Jan. 27 Vice President Mondale arrived in London today after an hour-long meeting with Pope Paul VI, who strongly endorsed President Carter's call to curb the spread of nuclear weapons and who likened President Carter to President John F. Kennedy.

MANY OF HANDEL'S oratorios are admired with hardly a reservation. "Judas Maccabeus" has its propo nents, but it has its strong detractors as well. Heard in Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night in a performance by the choir and orchestra of Musica Sacra of New York, one could see why.

It was supposed to be a great adventure. Here was India, newly free of the British Raj, its downtrodden millions eager for a better life a country with energy, with resources, most of all with the resolve to change from an impoverished, underdeveloped land into a nation of, if not prosperity like its Western counterparts, at least of economic stability, a land whose people did not starve and who had decent housing.
HONG KONG, Jan. 27 China has disclosed that army troops sent to the troubled city of Paoting near Peking have rounded up weapons, stopped fighting and conducted public trials.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 27 The opposition Janata Party charged today that thousands of its sympathizers were still being held in jails in India, despite Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's announcement last week that normal political activities could be resumed.
MADRID, Jan. 27 (UPI) Strikes spread throughout Spain today on the third day of protests against the right-wing violence that has claimed seven lives since Sunday.

"Roots," ABC's 12-hour adaptation of Alex Haley's book, continues to be this week's most ambitious presentation, coming to a conclusion with its eighth consecutive daily episode Sunday at 9 P.M. As the dramatized black family moves on to its own piece of land in Tennessee, in the decade after the Civil War, Mr. Haley walks toward the camera to summarize briefly the real family's history that led to his own birth in Henning, Tenn.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Following is a table prepared by the Treasury Department that shows the tax changes for various categories of taxpayers under the proposals of President Carter, starting in 1977.

Nathaline Frackman, who wrote "The Complete Book of Entertaining, Nata Lee's Guide for Every Hostess," under the name of Nata Lee, died yesterday in her home, 36 East 36th Street. after a brief illness. She was 74 years old.

THE HIGHLIGHT of the New York City Ballet's performance Wednesday night at the State Theater was definitely George Balanchine's "Stravinsky Violin Concerto," led with panache and pungency by Kay Mazzo, Peter Martins, Karin von Arnoldingen and Jean-Pierre Bonnefous.

Someone is practicing a scale in the foyer. It is part bell-like soprano, part fire-siren wail. The vocalist, a small, round-faced woman in her 40's, waits by the door. She is possessed, as Clive Barnes once put it, of a certain "batbered friendly charm." Her anklelength, flowered cotton skirt is faded and her lavender T-shirt is full of discreet but hardly unnoticable holes.

The day after 73-year-old Mary Kain was raped and murdered in her bed in the West Brighton Houses on Staten Island, detectives working on the case were raking through the garbage in the incinerator room. At about noon, a pair of blood-stained men's shoes came tumbling down the chute.

Confronted by dwindling natural-gas supplies and continuing bitterly cold weather, the Governors of New York and New Jersey declared states of emergency yesterday to cope with the worsening energy crisis.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 27 (Reuters) The Government is investigating a report that millions of dollars in bribes were paid to Indonesian officials in connection with a multimillion-dollar domestic satellite system, a Communications Ministry spokesman said today.

GENEVA, Jan. 27 (UPI) Swiss watch exports dropped 2.2 percent in 1976 as competition increased from cheaper electronic timepieces made in the United States and Japan. Swiss exports amounted to $1.22 billion, against $1.25 billion in 1975, the Swiss Watchmaking Federation said.
MIAMI, Jan. 27 (AP) The contract that ended a three-week hotel employee strike does not require hotel owners to rehire striking union members, a top union official said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance says the Carter Administration would regard the release of political prisoners by Cuba as an indication that it is seriously interested in restoring relations with the United States, according to testimony released today.
There are signs of growing frustration in stockholder circles over recent instances of management refusal to pass merger offers along.

MADRID, Jan. 27 The Spanish political landscape has been marked by acts of violence, from the right and from the left, in the 14 months since Franco died. According to one count, there have been 48 political deaths since the disappear ance of the Caudillo.

Lukas Foss and the Brooklyn Philharmonia Orchestra are celebrating American music in their current "Meet the Moderns" series at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and what finer Americans to present tonight than Bartok, Hindemith, Schoenberg, Stravinsky and Varese?

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 27 (AP) Iran is withdrawing some of its troops from Oman, a Government spokesman said today.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Company said it would increase its monomer capacity by over 50 percent during the next 18 months by expanding the company's Parkersburg, W.Va., manufacturing facilities for fluoroplastics. The company said it also planned to expand its polymer and copolymer resin capacities in stages after the monomer capacity increase.

Anyone contemplating suicide should not count on being talked out of it by a voice on the red telephone of the New York City suicide-prevention hot line. Getting an answer at the longpublicized, 24-hour number is not much more dependable than the "hot line" that television's Mary Hartman operated for awhile from her kitchen table.

A resolution deploring excessive violence in television programming has been passed by the board of directors of the Screen Actors Guild. The union has 32,000 members, many of whom appear in socalled action shows.

The opening of trading in farm commodities on the Chicago Board of Trade was delayed for 30 minutes until 10 A.M. yesterday because of the bitter cold weather prevailing in the Midwest. All futures contracts opened strong but some apparent speculative liquidation later in the day turned prices downward.
UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 28 Outmanned, outrun and outscored as usual, the New York Nets dropped a game to the Golden State Warriors tonight, 10684, before 5,042 fans at the Nassau Coliseum.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 28 Adelphi University's basketball team, though still shaken by the death Tuesday of Marshall Williams, its most popular player, voted today to continue the season.

MIAMI, Jan. 28 (AP) James (Ding) Schoonmaker of Miami kept the 1977 Bacardi Cup for Star Class yachts today by placing third in the last of five heats. Schoonmaker, the defending champion, has won seven Bacardi titles since 1953.

Wagner's "Die Walkure" returned to the Metropolitan Opera repertory last night, with some changes. LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 (AP) Burt Mustin, one of Hollywood's oldest and busiest actors, died today at the Glendale Manor Hospital in Glendale, a family spokesman said.

There were two significant events last night at Columbia University's Levien Gym. Columbia walloped Yale, 71-44, in an Ivy League basketball game, and Alton Byrd, the Lions' backcourt wizard, broke the school's singleseason assist record.

The chancellor of the City University of New York said yesterday that the system did not plan to shut down any city colleges and that he thought it was "unlikely" that any institutions would have to be merged for reasons of economy.

Seton Hall and Holy Cross renew their long-standing basketball rivalry today in the championship round of the annual Madison Square Garden Classic.

Bank stocks sank in price yesterday after a leading brokerage house downgraded the group, citing "uncertain earnings prospects" for the industry. The Dow Jones industrial average, meanwhile, rose 2.99 points to 957.53 in a session of brisk trading.
The State Insurance Department's Consumer Affairs Division has issued a free guide on auto insurance advising consumers on what to look for in policies and the kinds of coverage available.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 One of the Government's principal economic barometers, the composite index of leading indicators, showed its biggest gain in a year and a half last month.
