The National Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest steel producer, an nounced yesterday that it was holding discussions with the Revere Copper and Brass Corporation concerning purchasing the 33 percent interest in Revere Copper and Brass Corporation owned by Asarco Inc.

MOSCOW, Jan. 28 Four Soviet writers with links to the dissident movement today asked leaders in the West, including President Carter, to express their support for the dissident physicist Andrei D. Sakharov, who has come under new official pressure.

PRAGUE, Jan. 28 (Reuters) Six prominent Czechoslovak campaigners for human rights came under official pressure today to leave voluntarily for Austria in the next 48 hours, but dissident sources said all were resisting the move.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 The Pennsylvania Supreme Court today ordered a new trial for W. A. Boyle, the 74-year-old former president of the United Mine Workers of America who was convicted almost three years ago of ordering the murder of a union insurgent, Joseph A. Yablonski, and his wife and daughter.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 (AP) House Speaker Herbert Fineman, one of the most powerful men in the Pennsylvania legislature, pleaded not guilty today to Federal charges that he has extored money from parents to get their children into professional schools. He was arraigned before Federal Magistrate Edwin Nathons. The Speaker is accused of blackmail, bribery, conspiracy, obstruction of justice and mail fraud. He was allowed to remain free under a $50,000 bond.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 James R. Schlesinger, the Carter Administration's energy chief, told Congress today that natural gas deliveries to homes in some states might be cut off "in a few weeks, indeed in a few days."

ALBANY New York State's continuing tight fiscal situation requires a hard look at the allocation of our limited resources. At a time when money for state programs is scarce, we must be certain that the programs we do have operate efficiently and deliver maximum services to the people.

PARIS, Jan. 28 Vice President Mondale, who flew to Paris today from London, was honored last night by Prime Minister James Callaghan at a working dinner that turned into one of the most ebullient nights at 10 Downing Street in years.

TRENTON, Jan. 28 Although Governor Byrne's office and other state officials said that "an hour by hour" watch was being kept on the situation in New Jersey, no one today seemed to know how much natural gas or fuel oil was available.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The Carter Administration has turned down a request from the South Korean Government that Vice President Mondale visit Seoul during his current tour abroad, according to American officials and diplomatic sources.

SAINT GERVAIS, France, Jan. 28 (AP) Perrine Pelen, a 16-year-old French schoolgirl in her second international racing season, surprised the world skiing followers today with her second straight World Cup slalom victory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The Carter Administration's forceful, outspoken statement on human rights in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe are a striking departure from the diplomatic style of former Secretary of State Henry A. Kis- singer, who favored "quiet diplomacy" for such issues.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 28 (AP) Tom Watson, hoping for a second consecutive victory mastered the par-5 holes on his way to a five-under-par 67 that put him in a three-way tie for the second-round lead today in the $180,000 Andy Williams-San Diego open golf tournament.

Deborah Eldredge du Pont of St. David's, Pa., and Honolulu and A. Michael Hogan of Honolulu were married at the Colony Surf Hotel there yesterday. The Rev. Douglas Oldsen performed the Protestant ceremony.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 29 (AP) Eight bombs exploded in the Oxford Street shopping area of central London shortly after midnight, starting fires at Selfridges Department Store and a jewelry shop, but causing no casualties.

American League owners will meet in Tampa, Fla., on March 24 to consider a proposal that would realign their 14 clubs into three divisions starting with the 1978 season, a league spokesman said yesterday.

What appeared to be a threatened bank holdup was thwarted yesterday by an alert guard who recognized a suspect from pictures taken in other recent bank robberies and notified F.B.I. headquarters in Manhattan three blocks from the bank.

Leaders of municipal unions and the major bankers in New York City met with Mayor Beame yesterday and held what they said was a "constructive" discussion that nonetheless did not lead to any resolution of their dispute over outside control of city finances.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 28 The ninth annual team boxing competition between the United States and the Soviet Union takes place tomorrow at Caesars Palace, where the series began in 1969, with the American team still seeking its first victory.

LONDON, Jan. 28 Philip Agee, a disaffected former employee of the United States Central Intelligence Agency and for four years a resident of Britain, is a convert to revolutionary socialism who has enraged the agency by exposing many of its secrets, including the identities of overseas agents. He is seen in some quarters as a vicious and vindictive man who has endangered the lives of other Americans.

The unidentified New York City officials allegedly bribed by the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation to get equipment contracts were described yesterday by Stanley Sporkin, head of enforcement for the Securities and Exchange Commission, as employees "not in high positions."

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 28 (Reuters) Ethiopian students threw firebombs and stones at the American Cultural Center in Addis Ababa today, then attacked a similar British center and tried to set it on fire.
The Shell Oil Company announced yesterday a 6 percent advance in earnings for the final quarter of 1976; a two-forone stock split, and a 5-cent-a-share increase in the quarterly dividend.

BILLINGS, Mont., Jan. 28 (AP) A consortium of power companies has won at least a partial victory over the Environmental Protection Agency in a battle to subject them to strict new air quality standards in the construction of a $1 billion power complex in southeastern Montana.

HOBOKEN, Jan. 28 Students at the Stevens Institute of Technology called today for an end to the five-day strike by 57 faculty members that has disrupted classes at the 107-year-old engineering school.
The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation acknowledged yesterday that it had made some $4.1 million in questionable payments between 1972 and 1976.

Sexual assault in jails and prisons remains an issue shadowed in fear and embarrassment.

The Chilean Communist party leader, released from jail in his native country last month in exchange for the release of a Soviet dissident, was received in East Germany in a manner usually reserved for a head of state or ruling party leader. Louise King has official letters that help attest to the miseries of a frigid winter in Brownsville. One, from the city, informed her that the $75 rent she paid for four rooms in a crumbling building could be reduced by half because of, as the form tersely stated, "no heat or hot water."

Dozens of men and women on welfare as well as a number of labor and civic organizations, told a group of New York State legislators yesterday that the impact of Governor Carey's proposed home relief cuts would be disastrous, and they urged the lawmakers not to approve such reductions.

LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP) The trend toward lower British interest rates accelerated today as the Bank of England announced that it was cutting its minimum lending rate 1 percentage point to 12 percent, effective Monday.

Roland Kohloff, the New York Philharmonic's principal timpanist, had a rare opportunity to perform as a soloist in the orchestra's Thursday night concert in Avery Fisher Hall, Mr. Kohloff, who succeeded his former teacher, the noted Saul Goodman, in 1972, was heard is the New York premiere of Franco Donatoni's Concertino for Strings, Brass and Solo Timpani.
With bitter, persistent cold plaguing the nation, manufacturers of portable electric heaters are finding themselves flooded with orders and say they may soon be hard pressed to meet the demand.

The resignation of Wallace W. Booth as president of the United Brands Company of Boston was disclosed yesterday with the announcement that he is being replaced by Seymour Milstein, who has been vice chairman, Mr. Booth reportedly resigned because of a policy disagreement.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 One of the Government's principal economic barometers, the composite index of leading indicators, showed its biggest gain in a year and a half last month.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP) William H. Johnston, owner of dog racing tracks at Miami Beach, Tampa, Jacksonville and Orange Park and once known as a key man behind the scene in Florida politics, died at his home yesterday. He was 76 years old.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 27 The alumni of Crispus Attucks High School are returning here for the weekend to join with students in the celebration of a rare event the 50th anniversary of a school that has remained black in its orientation.

An agreement for the sale of The New York Times Music Corporation to Freddy Bienstock Enterprises, a leading music publisher, was announced yesterday by Sydney Gruson, executive vice president of The New York Times Company. The price, paid in cash, was not disclosed.

The National Weather Service yesterday predicted another month of colder-thannormal weather, further raising chances that this will be the coldest winter of the century for the eastern two-thirds of the country.

Floyd Sears, head of the financial copy desk of The New York Times from 1956 to 1962, died yesterday of leukemia at South Nassau Community Hospital, Oceanside, L. I. He was 80 years old and lived on Glover Place, Baldwin, L. I.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 28 (UPI) Melvin Dummar was allowed to leave Nevada today after four days of questioning by lawyers in which he adhered to his account of finding at his Utah gas station Howard R. Hughes's purported "Mormon will" leaving him millions of dollars.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 28 (UPI) Norway ordered five Soviet diplomats and newsmen out of the country today in what the Government termed the breakup of an espionage ring involving a Foreign Ministry official.

ATLANTA, Jan. 28 (UPI) Midwinter outbreaks of influenza or flu-like illnesses, striking mostly school children or young adults, were reported in 23 states today by the National Center for Disease Control.

A blizzard swept across the already frozen Central states into the East, nearly paralyzing vast areas with winds up to 60 miles an hour. DETROIT--Detroit is going European. Once that would have been heresy. ROME, Jan. 30 (AP) Pope Paul VI today defended his stand against the ordination of women as priests, saying that Roman Catholic women, could still occupy first place in charity and social fields.

HACKENSACK, Jan. 30 Hundreds of Community Action trainees are getting on-the-job experience throughout the state in the Federal Government's winterization program for needy homeowners. The program seeks to reduce energy waste through proper insulation. The work has taken on increased significance in the wake of the current fuel crisis.

MORZINE, France, Jan. 30 (AP) Bernhard Russi of Switzerland, a for mer world and Olympic champion, won a World Cup downhill race today, ending the season-long string of victories of Franz Klammer of Austria.

BREEZEWOOD, Pa., Jan. 30 With thousands of trucks snowbound on Midwestern highways, the Independent Truckers Association today postponed a demonstration against the national 55-mile-anhour speed limit that had been set to begin at midnight tonight.

WASHINGTON Jan. 30 The Social Security Administration last month penetrated its own system of safeguards supposedly designed to prevent all unauthorized access to computerized information about the private affairs of hundreds of thousand of Medicare patients.

Surprise vacations transfers to other schools and other emergency moves will begin today for thousands of students as a result of a directive by Governor Carey on Saturday to close 1,319 gasheated schools for a week because of the cold-induced energy crisis. The national board of directors of the Girl Scouts of America endorsed the Equal Rights Amendment yesterday.

OLD TAPPAN, Jan. 30 To the youngsters of this rural North Jersey community, the expanse of wooded fields and an old gravel bank just across the state line in New York have always been known as the sand pits. Though the land is posted with "No Trespassing" signs, the tract and its excavation have for years been something of a big sandbox where youngsters scoot about on motorbikes, fly model airplanes, or ride horses.

"Some time ago," Ira Ashley of New York wrote recently, "you ran an interview with a Spanish woman from Andalusia, then living in New York and printed a few of her recipes, including one for gazpacho, which is the only authentic one I have ever seen published in English (I lived for a while in southern Spain). ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Jan. 30 The most extensive layers of ice to cover Jersey coastal waters in half a century are lifting, twisting and breaking hundreds of small docks, piers and boat slips with each succeeding high tide, officials said today.

George Q. Herrick, retired director of the network division (engineering) of Radio Liberty and a key figure in State Department campaigns to prevent jamming of American radio broadcasts to the Soviet Union during the cold war, died Thursday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 61 years old.

Henry T. Berger, a lawyer and district leader, was chosen by Democrats yesterday to fill out, until the end of this year, the City Council post vacated by Theodore S. Weiss's election to Congress.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 Acting Mayor Michael A. Bilandic, who was chosen as the temporary successor to the late Mayor Richard J. Daley on the premise that he would not be a candidate in the forthcoming special election, now appears certain to be the Chicago Democratic organization's choice to make the race.

Milton Hyams, who is in charge of the supplies section of the Environmental Protection Administration in the Municipal Building on Centre Street, insists that his is one of the most smoothly run operations in New York City government. His messengers are prompt, Mr. Hyams says, his photocopy machinists are finely efficient, and his clerks are unfailingly polite. There is nothing in their work that suggests that many of these staff members are mentally retarded.

Recycling paper cuts the cost and the environmen tal damage of garbage disposal, and reduces the necessity of cutting forests. At the peak of the environmental effort, enthusiasm for this direct action was high; across the land, station wagons on a Saturday morning were filled with kids, old newspapers and good intentions.

Reports of corporate profits in the fourth quarter of 1976 are showing moderate to relatively strong gains. Profits at many brokerage houses however, are expected to be down this year.

Clarence M. Mitchell Jr., Washington bureau chief for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, has been elected chairman of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, perhaps signaling the end to his more than three decades of association with the N.A.A.C.P.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 30 After the Soviet Union's boxing team had beaten the United States amateur team for the ninth straight year here yesterday, Doc Broadus, one of the two American coaches, expressed outrage at only one thing: the American boxers had been brought together for only one week to prepare for the match.

BUFFALO, Jan. 30 Snow began falling again here this afternoon as western New York struggled to recover from the worst storm of the worst winter in its history.
