LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 30 (Reuters) Ivor Richard of Britain faced the final breakdown of his Rhodesia peace mission today when two key African nationalists refused even to meet him here.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 30 (AP) Tom Watson cruised in with a three underpar 69 and won the Andy Williams-San Diego, open golf tournament by five strokes today, making it his second consecutive record-setting victory.

What do you do if you worship someone I mean really worship someone and then decide to write a biographical play about the object of your adoration. You could, if you were particularly sensitive, be worried that your unquestioning adulation might glint through like a searchlight, destroying objectivity and even credibility. This, I suspect, was Jeff Wanshel's problem when he decided to write about Isadora Duncan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 A sweeping new code of ethics was approved today by a panel in the House of Representatives. The action signaled a willingness to take stringent measures to halt what members fear is an erosion of confidence in Congress.

An 80-year-old woman and her 77-yearold brother, who rarely ventured from their old, ramshackle house in a tidy middle-class neighborhood in Brooklyn's Sheepshead Bay section, were found dead yesterday amid thick layers of ice hanging from broken water pipes.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 31 When Ohio's energy crisis closed the schools in metro politan Cincinnati last Friday, Nancy Sherman was faced with a problem that hundreds of thousands of other working mothers across the country are having to confront during this harshest of recent winters: What do you do with the children?

An investigation to determine whether the State Banking Department acted as promptly as it should have to protect thousands of buyers of money orders sold by the bankrupt U.S.N. Company was announced yesterday by two state senators.

It was the most important day in the mottled life of the Democratic Party of Suffolk County. For the first time in the traditionally Republican county, the Democrats had won control of the 18-member legislature, and on that day, a year ago, the new county legislators were being sworn in. The attention of the audience in the wood-paneled room of the Riverhead, L. I., County Center, was riveted on the new legislators.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 26 The new President of Mexico, noting that 30 percent of his country's 63 million people are still living in a "marginal" economic state six decades after the Mexican Revolution, readily acknowledges that the nation is passing through a period of crisis, presenting both risk and opportunity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) A Federal judge today ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to turn over all tapes and transcripts gathered in the wiretapping of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to the National Archives and directed that they be kept there under seal for 50 years.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP) Evel Knievel, the stuntman, was injured today in a practice motorcycle leap only hours before a scheduled jump over a pool full of sharks. The nationally televised leap was canceled, spokesmen said. Mr. Knievel was taken to a hospital emerimmediately known.
Northern New York State reeled under new howling storms yesterday that dumped more than 18 inches of snow on the Watertown area within 24 hours.

PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 31 Ralph A. leavitt ,chairman of the board of Chase Leavitt and Company, steamship agents, and who helped set up the Maine Maritime Academy at Castine, died yesterday at the Maine Medical Center. He was 78 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) The prices farmers get for raw products rose 1.5 percent between Dec. 15 and Jan. 15, the Agriculture Department said today.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 31 (Reuters) Black nationalist guerrillas have abducted 400 black students and marched them across the border to neighboring Botswana, a communique of the Rhodesian armed forces said today.
TOKYO, Jan. 31 (UPI) Two former Government officials and an executive of a Japanese airline denied today that they received bribes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.
Three baseball figures from long ago Amos Rusie, Joe Sewell and Al Lopez were voted into the Hall of Fame yesterday by a special committee that searches the corridors of major-league history.

The travel package offered by the American Museum of Natural History isn't to be confused with a Cook's tour, a Linblad safari or a Holland America cruise. It is simply a collection of useful effects for the traveler duffel bag, cosmetic kits and the like in a distinctive animal print that is certain to attract attention and elicit queries.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 26 The new President of Mexico, noting that 30 percent of his country's 63 million people are still living in a "marginal" economic state six decades after the Mexican Revolution, readily acknowledges that the nation is passing through a period of crisis, presenting both risk and opportunity.

TRENTON, Jan. 31 Reports from around the state today showed a general, though grudging, compliance with Governor Byrne's executive order curtailing businesses to a 40-hour week and reducing temperatures in homes and businesses to 65 degrees during the day.
A New York City official said yesterday that sabotage was responsible for 10 to 15 percent of the heating breakdowns that have occurred during the current cold wave.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 President Carter today put business and labor on notice that his Administration will play an active role in seeking to curb price and wage increases, but his economic deputy, Charles L. Schultze, said the President still opposed outright controls.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The White House, backing the Senate Banking Committee, today opposed a five-year extension of the $2.3 billion Federal loan assistance to New York City beyond its June 30, 1978, expiration date.

A suspected flaw in the General Motors diesel locomotives that pull most of Amtrak's passenger fleet has prompted railroad officials to order a slowdown of trains around the nation, widely disrupting service schedules.

The Johns-Manville Corporation said that it would delay its previously announced $77 million capital expenditure program at its asbestos mine and processing plant in Quebec pending conclusion of a provincial study of nationalization of the asbestos industry.

AVALON, Jan. 31 This shore community of 2,100 people is prepared to use ambulances to move residents to the Community Hall at the south end of its boardwalk if natural gas to their homes is cut off. Meanwhile four miles away, in Stone Harbor, a resort town of 1,600 people, gas-using residents will be, if necessary, evacuated to their new firehouse.

Former Representative James F. Hastings, Republican of upstate New York, was sentenced to Serve 20 months to five years in prison for accepting salary kickbacks from two men on his Congressional payroll. Mr. Hastings, who resigned from the House a year ago, was convicted Dec. 17 by a jury of 20 counts of mail fraud and eight counts of making false statements to the House Finance Office.

Benjamin Kaufman, a real-estate investment counselor and benefactor of many Jewish institutions in New York City and in Israel, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 1056 Fifth Avenue.
Two brothers carrying more than $30,000 in cash decided yesterday to save 50 cents by going through a Queens subway turnstile together on one subway token.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 31 Andrew Young took over his duties as chief United States delegate today and was welcomed by hundreds of applauding staff members.

DULUTH, Minn., Jan. 31 Three Minnesota District Court judges today ordered state environmental agencies to issue permits allowing the Reserve Mining Company to dump potentially hazardous ore waste at a disposal site on land in the northeastern corner of the state that the company prefers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The Joint Chiefs of Staff believe the Soviet Union has yet to achieve military superiority over the United States but is bent on seeking that superiority, they said in a statement made public today.

John Ralston, the coach who led the Denver Broncos to the most successful campaign in the team's 16-year history last season, resigned yesterday and thus he ended a battle for power and control of the team. The winner was Fred Gehrke, the man on the inside who had the ear of the owners, Gerald and Allan Phipps.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The Western Union Corporation disclosed today that its 1976 earnings of $34 million would be erased if it had based its depreciation charges on the current cost of replacing its entire physical plant.

If Rip Van Winkle awakened this morning from his twenty years of sleep he would find surprisingly little to startle him. The price of his eyeopening coffee would certainly open his eyes, and so would the price of everything else. Perhaps the most shocking change to a man who had dozed off in 1957 would be the universal display of undressed girls on magazine covers at the newsstand where he buys his morning paper.
Dr. David Scherf, a cardiologist, died at his Manhattan home on Sunday. He was 77 years old and lived at 10 East 85th Street.
Cushrow R. Irani, who for eight years has led the fight for freedom of the press in India, was honored in absentia last night at the 35th anniversary meeting of Freedom House.
Paul Sann, executive editor of The New York Post, resigned yesterday after more than 40 years at the paper.

TOKYO, Jan. 31 On his Air Force jetliner flying from Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland to Brussels eight days ago, Vice President Mondale sat in an armchair and quietly discussed his unusual journey through Europe to Tokyo.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31 (Reuters) The Soviet Communist Party today affirmed its claim to be at the center of the world revolutionary movement and indicated that Communists everywhere should follow its basic doctrines or face failure.
Northern New York State reeled under new howling storms yesterday that dumped more than 18 inches of snow on the Watertown area within 24 hours.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 31 (Reuters) More than 100 Lawyers with cases on the docket boycotted the Supreme Court today to protest the appointment of Mirza Hammeaullah Beg as India's new chief justice over the head of a more senior colleague.
VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 31 The agent at the United States Customs office on the border at Blaine, Wash., 30 miles south of here, seemed perplexed.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass. Ibsen's final drama, "When We Dead Awaken," just produced here by Stage West, is in some ways the playwright's most puzzling, most opaque drama. It is rarely given partly because of the difficulties of its staging and partly because of the mixture of realism and symbolism that make its texture, let alone its theme, difficult to appreciate. Yet it is a great play.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31 Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. today ordered the controversial diamond lane on the San Diego Free way open to all traffic.
The sharp rise in prices of frozen orange juice futures-10 consecutive limit advances of 3 cents a pound-came to an end yesterday in a confusing rush of selling mixed with still pending buy orders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 The United States and Panama pledged today to make "a sustained and continuous effort" to conclude a new treaty that would set dates for termination of American control over the Panama Canal and the Canal Zone.
Olga V. Kaltenborn, widow of H.V. Kaltenborn, the colorful radio and television news broadcaster and analyst who died in 1965, died Saturday in the Sunrest Nursing Home, Port Jefferson,L.I.

WASHINGTON The case for increasing energy conservation has been made repeatedly. Experts in and out of government agree that it costs about half as much to save a barrel of oil or the equivalent amount of electricity or natural gas as it does to produce similar amounts of new energy.
Major Eastern and Midwestern steelmakers are being forced to curtail their operations because of natural gas cutbacks and weather-related problems.

President Carter and Secretary Vance have already recognized that their desire to champion human rights in Communist countries adds a complication to foreign policy. They do not intend to speak out in every case, they say, but they do wish to burden diplomacy with ideals. When we last made that observation, it evoked the question of whether the burden is worth bearing. The answer is yes, decidedly yes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The Senate, after an all-day debate, approved this evening the Carter Administration's emergency bill to authorize Federal shifting of natural gas supplies to protect service to homes, small stores and essential public services.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 31 (UPI) The Kenyan Government suspended sports events with Tanzania today and demanded that Tanzania halt its "provocative and indecent" attacks.

An American Roman Catholic bishop who conducted two irregular rites of general absolution without individual confession did so despite knowledge of a warning from the Vatican that such procedures could violate church regulations.

Time passes, bringing nearer the moment possibly Thursday on which the city must show the Court of Appeals how it will pay off a billion dollars in notes, originally subject to the moratorium the court struck down in November. We regret that agreement between the parties arrives more slowly than the deadline.
LONDON, Jan. 31 (AP) The price of gold rose today while the dollar fell in almost all West European money markets.

BUFFALO, Jan. 31 Snowplows manned by city crews and National Guard troops fought a losing battle with howling winds and drifting snow today as Buffalo remained buried, isolated and paralyzed after the worst winter storm in its history.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The White House, backing the Senate Banking Committee, today opposed a five-year extension of the $2.3 billion Federal loan assistance to New York City beyond its June 30, 1978, expiration date.

AUBURN, N.Y. In recent years, New York's Finger Lakes region has suffered along with the nation as natural gas supplies grow tight. Prices are on the rise, industry has been forced to other, far more expensive fuels and fears of damage to the economy mount.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The director of the National Association of Arab Americans has written to President Carter protesting a recent public characterization of Ralph Nader as "a dirty Arab" by Paul Rand Dixon, a Federal Trade commissioner and a prime target of a Nader-sponsored report on the F.T.C.

Bache Halsey Stuart Inc., the securities firm, takes a measured view of this season's most controversial accounting innovation the replacement cost disclosures due from the nation's largest companies by the end of March.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31 Despite an early run-in over human rights, the Soviet leadership is still looking to the Administration of Jimmy Carter to help revive the kind of accommodation that flourished during the Nixon years and has stagnated since.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the Carter Administration would "speak frankly about injustice" wherever it occurs including the Soviet Union but only "from time to time" and in a nonprovocative way.

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Jan. 30 On a dark and stormy night, the temperature at zero, the wind howling up the mountain, sending snow hissing against leaded glass windows, there they were, 250 people with a single interest, 100 miles north of Gotham, in a cavernous parlour filled with carved chestnut, upholstered sultan's corners and memories of men long gone who had lounged there, men like Andrew Carnegie and Chester A. Arthur.

A man and his wife were shot during a street robbery in the Bronx last night. The police later seized a suspect they identified as the brother of a man who was slain while he was acting as an accomplice to the couple in an attempted robbery last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Growing doubts that the House Committee an Assassinations can resolve the questions surrounding the deaths of President Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. have led to a substantial loss of support for the committee in the House of Representatives.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 President Carter gave his Cabinet members another lecture on symbolic frugality today, asking them to eschew the traditional ostentation of their rank and place in Government.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (AP) Edwin O. Guthman, the Pulitzer Prize-winning national editor of The Los Angeles Times, today was named editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer. He will be in charge of The Inquirer's editorial and op-ed pages when he begins his new job on March 1.

World Team Tennis has reached an oral agreement with the tennis federation of the Soviet Union that would allow a six-member Soviet squad to play a full schedule this season in W.T.T., a 10-team professional league.

MORZINE, France, Jan. 31 (AP) Josef Walcher, a 22-year-old Austrian, whipped the world's downhill skiing elite today in winning a World Cup race for the first time. And he vowed to repeat his victory at St. Anion, Austria, next weekend.

College football teams that like to flip little short passes have gained a jump on the opposition linebackers and cornerbacks because of rules changes last month. A team will be able to block any distance downfield on a pass completed at or behind the line of scrimmage.
ALBANY, Jan. 31 The State Department of Education released computer printouts today showing the effect, district by district, of Governor Carey's proposed new school-aid formula.

Call it the cold weather market. While energy stocks particalarly natural gas producers, have been getting a lot of attention lately, the rest of the stock market has taken a drubbing as subzero temperatures throughout much of the nation have put a drag on business.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 The Democratic ward committeemen who served Richard J. Daley for morn than 20 years continued their solidarity today by endorsing Acting Mayor Michael A. Bilandic as the party organization's candidate to serve the remaining two years of the late Mayor's term.
Although the bitter cold besetting much of the nation has caused major industrial dislocations, it also means booming business for a number of industries.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the nation's leading domestic copper producer, reported yesterday a $5.1 million loss for the fourth quarter, excluding the $11.1 million, or 33 cents a share, earned by its Peabody Coal Company subsidiary, whose sale awaits Federal Trade Commission approval.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31 The National Broadcasting Company today insisted that it had obtained the American television rights to the 1980 Moscow Olympics, despite an earlier denial by a Soviet Olympics Committee spokesman.

ASPEN, Colo., Jan. 31 (AP) Claudine Longet, pleading with a judge to have mercy on her as the mother of three children, was sentenced today to serve 30 days in jail "at a time of her own choosing" in the killing of Vladimir Sabich, a professional skier with whom she had been living.
TRENTON, Jan. 31 The New Jersey Assembly approved a restoration of the death penalty for first-degree murder today and sent the measure to Governor Byrne, who has indicated he will sign it.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, in administrative hearings convened in New York yesterday, said it would seek "sanctions" against Raymond L. Dirks and five others for their role in the collapse three years ago of the scandal-ridden Equity Funding Corporation of America.

ST. PETERSBURG. Fla., Jan. 31. Running Tide, a yacht found tried and true after seven years of campaigning, and Imp, a new vessel in competition for the first time, shared honors in the Southern Ocean Racing Conference's opening event, which ended here yesterday.

Because of increased damage to the West Side Highway from the cold weather and heavy salting the exit-entrance ramp at 57th Street will be closed today through Friday between 10 A.M. and 3 P.M., according to the Transportation Administration. During those hours, motorists are to use the exit-entrance ramps at 46th and 79th Streets.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) The Agriculture Department has done an inadequate job in preventing conflict of interest among high-ranking employees, a Congressionai report said today.

For years, just the mention of New York Law School would evoke condescending giggles from many New York lawyers and law students. But recently that giggling has stopped, for the school is in the midst of a comeback.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 31 (AP) Thailand has sealed its border with Cambodia and will use "drastic measures" to repel future Cambodian raids across the border like the weekend killing of 30 Thai civilians, Deputy Prime Minister Boonchai Bamroongphong said today.

ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 31 Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland said today that he planned to develop en "all-risk, allcrops" insurance program to protect producers against disasters of the kind that had occurred in many parts of the country in the last year.

WASHINGTON Jan. 31 The committee that organized Ronald Reagan's nearly successful primary challenge against former President Gerald R. Ford last year has been converted into a permanent political group to back conservative Republican causes and candidates.

A plan to curtail travel and schedule more play within divisions and conferences will be presented to the National Basketball Association owners for approval Feb. 12, a day beforo the AllStar Game in Milwaukee.
TRENTON, Jan. 31 The New Jersey Assembly approved a restoration of the death penalty for first-degree murder today and sent the measure to Governor Byrne, who has indicated he will sign it.

It was a busy time for newcomers to major ballet roles last weekend. At the City Center, American Ballet Theater ended its season Sunday night with Gelsey Kirkland's being partnered by Charles Ward as a new Albrecht in "Gi selle." Saturday night, Martine van Hamel and Clark Tippet made their debuts as Giselle and Albrecht.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 31 Foreign Minister Yigal Allon proposed an agreement today stating how near Syrian or Palestinian forces in Lebanon could approach the Israeli border.

HACKENSACK, Jan. 31 A steadily increasing shortage of beds for Medicaid patients in nursing homes throughout the state is causing alarm among the aging and their relatives, as well as among social workers, nurses and others in the health care field.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31 (AP) Family and friends of Freddie Prinze said farewell today to the young television performer who took his own life. His co-performer, Jack Albertson, and best friend, Tony Orlando, read eulogies.

CAPE TOWN, Jan. 31 The South African Government today unveiled sweeping legislation giving it wartime powers, including censorship of the domestic and foreign press, in the event the army is called in to suppress the recurrence of last year's riots.

Business executives and some economists are predictably asserting that President Carter's proposed tax credit against employer payroll taxes just won't do. This was predictable because (a) the payroll credit is too novel to be accepted at once, and (b) the businessmen wanted a big new investment credit to shift much of the cost of private investment to the Government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 A sweeping new code of ethics was approved today by a panel in the House of Representatives. The action signaled a willingness to take stringent measures to halt what members fear is an erosion of confidence in Congress.
Andrew Fletcher, honorary chairman of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, 250 Park Avenue, New York City, died Sunday in his apartment at 953 Fifth Avenue. He was 81 years old.

The Carter Administration will "speak frankly about injustice" wherever it occurs including the Soviet Union but only "from time to time" and in a nonprovocative way, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said at a wide-ranging news conference at the State Department.

PARIS, Jan. 31 France officially thanked Libya today for helping end the 33-month ordeal of Francoise Claustre as a hostage in the Sahara. The case of Mrs. Claustre ignited widespread indignation and charges of bungling and cowardice against the Government.
ALBANY, Jan. 31 Twenty-six days after opening its 1977 session, the New York State Legislature today sent to Governor Carey the first bill of the new year. It could not have been a more typical bill.
Houston McTear has an answer for critics who contend he has burned himself out as a world-class sprinter at the age of 19.

BUFFALO, Jan. 31 Snowplows manned by city crews and National Guard troops fought a losing battle with howling winds and drifting snow today as Buffalo remained buried, isolated and paralyzed after the worst winter storm in its history.

BANGKOK, Thailand Jan. 31 (UPI) The National Liberation Front of South Vietnam, formed 16 years ago to lead the war against Americans, is to be phased out this week during a five-day meeting that began today in Saigon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The General Accounting Office, conducting an unprecedented investigation of Federal bank regulators has concluded that they have failed to bring sufficient pressure on errant banks to mend their ways.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Representative Morris K. Udall, the new chairman of the House Interior Committee, which now exercises oversight over the nation's nuclear programs, says that he is "leaning" toward a program that holds in abeyance the development of the fast breeder reactor as a major energy source.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 31 (AP) The National Basketball Association's Indiana Pacers announced today a public offering for sale of 40 percent of the club.

Teresa Stratas, the soprano who Was to take the title role in the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Berg's "Lulu" next month, has withdrawn, charging the opera company with breach of contract in failing to provide as much fullscale rehearsal time as she had assumed her contract guaranteed.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31 A 23-year-old student and an unemployed cabinet maker pleaded not guilty today to charges of spying for the Soviet Union in the last 18 months.

In the first campaign from its new agency, Epstein, Raboy Advertising, Playboy magazine will be using its readers to sell themselves to potential advertisers. The theme of the campaign is "The Playboy reader. His lust for life."

NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 31 (UPI) A plane belonging to Uganda's President, Idi Amin, and its 18 British passengers have been found safe after the craft made an emergency landing in rough weather, airline officials said today.

Victor Gotbaum sits back and shrugs and frowns when asked what he's going to do about politics this mayoral year. It's not an easy question for a labor leader who has been forced by events into the yoke of city statesmanship and who lately talks more favorably of David Rockefeller than of Governor Carey or Mayor Beame.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The Carter Administration, seeking to dampen criticism about not placing enough women in high-level jobs, has found compromise posts for at least three women who worked in the Carter transition operation, sources close to the President said today.
Michael Chen, 27-year-old leader of the Flying Dragons, a Chinese youth gang, has been arrested for the murder last October of David Wong, a member of the rival Ghost Shadows gang.

WASHINGTON Jan. 31 Brock Adams, Transportation Secretary, in his first major action since taking office, moved today to tighten marine safety rules and practices to prevent the kinds of oil spills that have threatened United States coastlines and waterways in recent weeks.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP) Bobby Orr of the Chicago Black Hawks, nursing a bad knee for most of the last two seasons, will miss the remainder of the National Hockey League season, The Chicago Tribune reported in its Tuesday editions.
MADRID, Jan. 31 Bolstered by new government powers after last week's outbreak of terrorism, the police today continued to detain "extremists."

For the last four days the Cornell women's basketball team has been living on oatmeal, peanut butter and spaghetti in a motel one mile north of Watertown, N.Y. The 12-woman team left Ithaca last Friday morning for a game that night against the women of St. Lawrence University. 200 miles away at Canton, N.Y. But a blizzard forced their two vans to abandon the snow-clogged roads halfway through the trip.

A renewed flurry of activity by Bella S. Abzug meetings with potential campaign workers and contributors, studies of poll results, talks about strategy has convinced some of her political friends and foes that she will run for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

PARIS Besides serving as a source of carefully made clothes for rich women who have the time to have them fitted, the couture here likes to justify its existence by saying that it serves as a laboratory of fashion for the world.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 31 (AP) Oman has raised its oil price 9 percent retroactive to Jan. 1, the authoritative Middle East Economic Survey said today.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 Dominic J. Baranello, the Suffolk County Democratic leader, was elected Democratic state chairman today, an action that symbolized the growing role of the suburbs in the Democratic Party. He succeeded Patrick J. Cunningham, who resigned under pressure from Governor Carey.

Having surmounted with remarkable adaptability the loss of what was then its primary food, so-called eel grass, by switching to a marine algae known as sea lettuce, the Atlantic brant (Branta bernicula hrota) now faces the threat of starvation in its wintering area along the New Jersey coast.

A 5-year-old mare who gets three extra blankets is uncovering some class in winter horse racing. Tarport Hap, one of the best pacers in the country, registered a 1:591/5 mile in below-freezing weather last Saturday night at the Meadowlands.

The Montreal Canadiens, running away from the rest of the National Hockey League, are unhappy. If that surprises you, the Islanders, Rangers, Buffalo Sabres, St. Louis Blues and a host of other clubs are also unhappy.
The help-wanted advertising index, a monthly survey of the Conference Board, was up six points in December to 105 (1967=100) from the November level and 17 points over December 1975.
The stock market declined moderately yesterday as the nation's energy crisis chilled investor enthusiasm.
Phyllis Ackerman Pope, an expert on Asian art, died last Tuesday in Shiraz, Iran. She was 83 years old and had been a resident of that city for a number of years.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31 Despite an early run-in over human rights, the Soviet leadership is still looking to the Administration of Jimmy Carter to help revive the kind of accommodation that flourished during the Nixon years and has stagnated since.
MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Jan. 31 (AP) H. Julian Allen, a space pioneer whose discoveries made possible the safe return of astronauts to earth, died last weekend of a heart attack. He was 66 years old.

PARIS, Jan. 31 President Valery Giscard d'Estaing tonight opened France's remarkable modern-art center, named for his predecessor, Georges Pompidou, asserting it was time for a great new "temple for artistic creation." This need existed because Mr. Pompidou had been "worried lest the extraordinary home for the arts which is Paris wander abroad, across the seas." His reference was to widespread talk that New York has re placed Paris as the artistic crossroad of the world.

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Jan. 30 On a dark and stormy night, the temperature at zero; the wind howling up the mountain, sending snow hissing against leaded glass windows, there they were, 250 people with a single interest, 100 miles north of Gotham, in a cavernous parlour filled with carved chestnut, upholstered sultans corners and memories of men long gone who had lounged there, men like Andrew Carnegie and Chester A. Arthur.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The cold wave is cutting into the nation's economic recovery and if it continues will produce an appreciable reduction in growth during the first quarter of this year. This in turn could affect the economy's performance for the year as a whole.

The Yankees, who seem to believe that Willie Randolph will be their starting second baseman for a long time, showed some evidence of that sentiment yesterday by signing the 22-yearold infielder to a three-year contract. Financial terms of the agreement were, as usual, not revealed.

WASHINGTON Something dramatic and sobering happened to me on Jan. 20. When Jimmy Carter was sworn in at the age of 52, I was, for the first time in my life, older than the President of the United States.

Prices of fixed-income securities advanced early yesterday and then fell back to close little changed from Friday as the credit markets headed into this week's heavy schedule of Federal Government financing. Meanwhile, the LTV Corpora tion set the yield on an offering of debentures at 9 percent a rate not seen on new issues since last July.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 31 Over the strenuous, sometimes impassioned objections of religious Jews, the Israeli Parliament today passed a law that legalized abortions but fell short of providing abortion on demand.

For years, just the mention of New York Law School would evoke condescending giggles from many New York lawyers and law students. But recently that giggling has stopped, for the school is in the midst of a comeback.
TRENTON, Jan.31 Governor Byrne will present New Jersey's first $4 billion budget tomorrow to a joint session of the Legislature.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 1 Vice President Mondale affirmed the United States military and economic commitment to Asia today and made it clear that the United States would keep some forces in South Korea.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 President Carter today put business and labor on notice that his Administration will play an active role in seeking to curb price and wage increases, but his economic deputy, Charles L. Schultze, said the President still opposed outright controls.

The double blow of frigid temperatures and a fuel shortage in the last 10 days have caused losses in retail sales and curtailments of store operations in the Northeast, Mid-Atlantic states, the Midwest and parts of the South.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 31 (AP) A little fish on the Federal Endangered Species List was helped today when the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit halted construction on the $100 million Tellico Dam project.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (UPI) More than two years after the army overthrew the late Emperor Haile Selassie, Ethiopia is racked by political assassinations and unrest, military suppression and a war against seccesionists in Eritrea, the northernmost province.
The world's strongest pair tournament was played in London during weekend, and resulted in a victory for a famous French partnership, Henri Svarc and Jean-Michel Boulenger.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) The General Electric Company was barred under Federal order today from making false or unsubstantiated claims about its television sets or other major appliances.

Adolfo has an idea or two about what men should be wearing when they ease on down the road next fall. So, last night he rented the stars of "The Wiz" and the stage of the Majestic Theater to tell the world.

As one of the hottest teams in the National Basketball Association right now, the Los Angeles Lakers are something of a surprise. But even if their hot streak runs out, their method of creating it may have a lasting effect on the style of other teams.

A number of the nation's major magazine publishers, having overcome the paper-shortage problem and having almost come to peace with the postal problems, are now facing production problems brought on by this miserable winter.

DETROIT, Feb.1 The American Motors Corporation announced today it had agreed in principle to extend for one year its $72.5 million line of credit with United States banking interests and thant it had completed sale of its South Charleston, W.Va., stamping plant to help pay off $20.5 million owed a Swiss bank.
LONDON, Feb. 1 The cartoon on the front page of The Guardian showed a bored and weary bull standing on his hind legs and holding a cloth, presumably red, to the much smaller figure of a raging man.
In what seemed like the end of an era at Madison Square Garden, Walt Frazier was on the bench when the game started last night as part of several changes in coaching tactics by Red Holzman.
Even as they were warning of the coming natural gas crisis in recent years, many of the nation's gas utilities were adding customers and encouraging use of gas-consuming appliances.

DENVER, Feb. 1 (AP) Dave Hudson, who had two assists and scored what proved to be the winning goal in the first period, and Michel Plasse, who put on a strong goaltending performance, helped the Colorado Rockies beat the New York Rangers tonight, 5-2.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1 Earl E.T. Smith, who may be the only politician ever to have spent more than $6 a vote campaigning to be elected to a nonsalaried job with no actual power, has, after six years, decided to step down as Mayor of Palm Beach. Mr. Smith, a former United States Ambassador to Cuba, whose social lineage is impeccable (his mother was a descendant of William Tailer, the first Governor...

President Carter told the Soviet envoy at their first meeting that the United States would not back down in its commitment for strengthened human rights in the Soviet Union and elsewhere. He called this a commitment on a position, not an attack on the Soviet Union. Plans for next month's resumption of strategic arms negotiations in Moscow took up most of the one-hour White House meeting. [Page A1, Cols. 1-2.]

ROOTS "A Quaker Reader," a musical tribute to his faith, is Ned Rorem's initial composition since winning the Pulitzer Prize last year and his first large-scale work for solo organ. The 11-movement, 30-minute piece contains sayings by such Quaker writers as William Penn and John Greenleaf Whittier. There are pauses. The composer calls them "the silence which for members of the Society of Friends can sometimes explode into light."

CHERRY HILL, N.J., Feb. 1 The "new" Garden State Park opened the state's 1977 thoroughbred racing season today. Gurkhas Band, the 4-5 favorite, won the Garden State Inaugural, the opening-day feature, with ridiculous ease.

NEW DELHI, Wednesday, Feb. 2 Jagjivan Ram, the senior member of the Indian Cabinet, dramatically broke with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today, with a stinging denunciation of her emergency rule of the country. Mr. Ram's defection was a major political development, posing a serious threat to Mrs. Gandhi in the current parliamentary election campaign.

TO JUDGE from the program distributed at Carnegie Hall on Monday night, we were about to hear the second performance within a week of Mozart's "Great" Mass in C minor (K. 427) in the antiquated and generally discredited edition of Alois Schmitt. We also were promised Bach's Magnificat in D with two of the four choral interpolations that were included in the first performance, in 1723.

Tennis pros that is, those who get paid for teaching are a diverse breed. Some are frustrated tournament players; some are dreamers; some are genuine students of the game; some enjoy the work; some despise it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 President Carter told Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin today that the United States would not back down on its commitment to strengthen human rights in the Soviet Union and elsewhere, the White House said.
What does imitation cheese taste like? Comparisons that come most quickly to mind are kneaded rubber erasers and crayons. But food terminology would more aptly apply, so let us try.
MOSCOW, Feb. 1 (AP) A fire today wrecked the office of the United States Embassy doctor, who serves much of the Western community, and he said the office would be closed for a month.

PRAGUE, Feb. 1 (Reuters) The Communist Party newspaper Rude Pravo today accused Western politicians and officials of interfering in Czechoslovakia's internal affairs by expressing concern over the fate of dissidents.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (UPI) They once lived in opulence and for 3,000 years ruled this land of Solomon and Sheba virtually by divine right. But more than two years after a military revolution swept them from power, Ethiopia's prin cesses, princes and aristocracy continue to languish in dank jails, their future uncertain.

Seth M. Glickenhaus, a 62-year-old speculator who says he made $6 million in American Telephone and Telegraph convertible bonds in 195999, is back in Wall Street engaging in his favorite speculation convertibles.
The United States Steel Corporation yesterday tested the Carter Administration's new policy of taking an active role in curbing wage and price increases.

Edwin H. Yeo 3d, who served as Undersecretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs since 1975, will join the First National Bank of Chicago as chairman of the asset and liability management committee and as executive vice president, the bank announced yesterday.

Joe Frazier, the former heavyweight champion who is heading his own nightclub revue at the Rainbow Grill this week and next, knows from his ring experience the value of preliminaries. They should be good enough to keep the audience interested but not so distracting that they diminish the building anticipation for the headliner.

TURIN, Italy The sale by Fiat to Libya of a huge block of stock is an interesting pilot project of the kind of association between Western industries and rich oil-producing lands that is bound to spread.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 1 (UPI) The dollar was generally lower on European money markets today, but dealers said it seemed to have stabilized following its sharp decline yesterday.

The Caribbean World Series was on in San Juan, Puerto Rico, when an invitation arrived at the hotel to join the` admiral for cocktails at his residence. It was a bleak prospect, making manners with the braid and maybe having to miss dinner before the evening ball game. Still, the invitation had the ring of an order to be obeyed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 House and Senate conferees worked out an agreement tonight on pricing of emergency natural gas sales to interstate pipelines, thus appearing to clear the way for final passage tomorrow by Congress of the Carter Administration's emergency gas allocation bill.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn. A mixture of corn, sugar and yeast the recipe for moonshine whisky has been thrown into the battle of the Great Smoky Mountain National Park against a horde of wild boars.

The proposed construction of a 25-story hospital for burn victims and for plastic surgery on Manhattan's East Side is expected to be rejected tonight by the Health Systems Agency of New York City in favor of expanding a new burn-treatment center that opened last December in the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

THE W-2 forms have been sent out, the Internal Revenue Service is putting on more staff, and private tax-preparing serv ices such as H R Block Inc. are bracing for what could be their biggest year ever.
Scholastic Aptitude Tests are graded on a scale of 200 to 800. If Johnny gets a 525 and Bobby a 475, most people probably assume that Johnny is substantially more promising academically.

BUFFALO, Feb. 1 Warmed by the first bright sun they had seen in a week and buoyed by a dropoff in snow flurries and driving winds, citizens of this frozen city yesterday bent to the task of digging out.

MOLIERE'S PLAYS are always concerned with follies and foibles. What makes them so engaging and so instructive is that those follies and foibles are instantly recognizable. Few, if any, playwrights understood human nature the way Moliere did. He listened to the heartbeat of the world and recorded it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 The House Rules Committee approved today a resolution re-establishing the Select House Committee on Assassinations, but only for the next two months and with a somewhat restricted investigative mandate.

EMIL GILELS, one of the most popular of Russian exports, played a rather curious program last night in Carnegie Hall. Either he was trying to prove something, or merely dumped together a group of disparate pieces.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 President Carter told Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin today that the United States would not back down on its commitment to strengthen human rights in the Soviet Union and elsewhere, the White House said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Hamilton Jordan occupies the southwest corner office of the White House Executive Suite Gen. Alexander Haig's old command post in the Nixon days. It used to look a little like the English library in "Upstairs-Downstairs"; now it has all the tidiness of an unmade bed. The contrast is worth noting.
Along with the cigar store Indian and the trolley car, the neighborhood pool hall is all but gone.
BECAUSE WALLACE STEVENS is one of my favorite poets, it is painful to have to confess that I find the journal he kept and the letters he wrote as a young man to be almost without interest.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 The National Broadcasting Company has agreed to pay the highest amount in the televised history of the Olympics for exclusive rights to broadcast the Moscow games to the United States in 1980.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1(Reuters) Plans are being made for a student expedition to investigate the reported sighting of a snake-like monster in a mountain lake in Soviet Kazakhstan, a scientist involved in the project said today.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 1 Six feet of snow covered the ground, with drifts rising to 25 feet. All roads were closed, and as many as 2,000 cars were believed snowbound. Dairy farmers were losing an estimated $500,000 a day because they had to dump milk that they could not get off their farms. Four barns collapsed, trapping 150 head of cattle.
A program of music by contemporary black composers will be given by the Brooklyn Philharmonia on Feb. 27 at the Billie Holiday Theater, 1368 Fulton Street, Brooklyn.

"Hold on, I'll look," said John Updike, the writer, pulling the telephone cord over to the refrigerator and taking a census of the radishes in it: "I'd say 17 radishes, 7 scallions, half a cucumber, 2 lemons looking a little tired, 1 drawer I can't open, filled with ... my God ... onions, 3 pounds of onions..."

RALEIGH, N.C. Thirty-five-year-old Arthur Epps, who calls himself King Arthur when he is behind a microphone, has had his ups and downs as an entertainer, singing on street corners in New York, recording his first single when he was 16, composing the sound track for a grade B movie in the early 1960's, playing and singing in barrooms and clubs across the country.

FOLSOM, N.J., Feb.1 Advance planning, luck, tough bargaining, scrounging and curtailment of key customers have all been part of how the staff of the South Jersey Gas Company has coped with the natural gas crisis.

FEDERAL Trade Commissioner Paul Dixon apologized to ArabAmericans yesterday for calling Ralph Nader "a dirty Arab," but Representative Edward Koch said that wasn't enough and he intended to ask Congress to impeach Mr. Dixon.

ASPEN, Colo., Feb. 1 (AP) Charles Weedman, Claudine Longet's attorney, said tonight that Miss Longet had decided not to appeal her conviction and to accept her 30-day jail sentence. He said the jail term would probably be next summer.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 1 The snowbound Buffalo Sabres escaped from their winter-scourged city by bus today but than ran into a flurry of Islander goals tonight at Nassau Coliscum, where they lost, 6-3.

TRENTON, Feb. 1 Governor Byrne was interrupted 16 times by applause, none of it thunderous, during his 40minute annual budget address today to a joint session of the Legislature, but it has to be recorded that he asked for it at least six times.

They wear the starched white jackets of their profession, identifying them as hospital physicians. Only their name tags, their faces and their imperfect English indicate that they are different from their American colleagues.

Federal and county grand juries in Brooklyn are reported preparing to indict 11 podiatrists and two organized-crime figures for conspiracy and bribery in an alleged scheme to block a bill in Albany that would have excluded podiatry from Medicaid reimbursement.

The Russian grandmaster Leonid Shamkovich, an emigre now living in New York, and Andy Soltis, a New York international master, shared first place in the Marshall Chess Club International Tournament, each scoring 9 4 . They split the first prize of $1,700.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 A Federal Reserve Board staff stdy suggested today that banks would not be unduly harmed if they paid interest on checking account deposits, but warned that there would be an effect on bank earnings during a transition period.

Outbreaks of relatively mild influenza have been reported in New York State and New Jersey, but there are no confirmed cases in New York City yet. An official said yesterday it was expected there would be soon.

The leaders of the municipal unions, in their capacity as trustees of the city's five retirement systems, have been providing New York City with the only new cash it has been receiving. That process, begun in September 1975, is scheduled for completion on June 30, 1978, at the conclusion of the three-year fiscal plan for recovery.

TRENTON, Feb. 1 Governor Byrne presented to the Legislature today a record $4 billion annual state budget, said it was one of the most frugal in New Jersey's history and complimented himself and the Legislature for "tax reform" and "fiscal restraint."

BANGALORE, India, Feb. 1 (Reuters) After the anguish of three crushing defeats, India appeared on its way to victory in the fourth cricket test following an assault on England's second innings here tonight. In 9.5 overs, India's bowlers reduced England to eight runs for four wickets and though Roger Tolchard and Tony Greig denied them a further breakthrough, it appeared unlikely that the home team would be denied tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 President Carter's effort to install Theodore C. Sorensen as the Director of Central Intelligence was not blocked. It collapsed.

Just as Larry Checco stepped aboard the last car of the shuttle at Grand Central during a recent rush hour, the doors began to close. "I thought I was the last passenger," he writes, "but a man came running full tilt, briefcase in hand, wearing an expression of determination. The result was that he got caught, half in and half out of the closing door."

The city's major banks appear to be softening their demand that the Carter Administration provide an extension of financial guarantees before New York City borrows any more money in the municipal bond market.
WARSAW, Feb. 1 (Reuters) Twentytwo Polish dissidents today issued an open letter expressing solidarity with Czechoslovaks and East Germans demanding human and civil rights.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Dougald D. McMillan, the Justice Department lawyer who was transferred out of Miami after being linked in press accounts to the alleged "sex spying" activities of Federal informants there, has been cleared of the charges after a long investigation, it was learned today.

GABORONE, Botswana, Feb. 1 (Agence France-Press) Four hundred black Rhodesian students allegedly kidnapped and brought into Botswana by nationalist guerrillas on Sunday were fleeing from harassment by Rhodesian security forces, a Government spokesman said here today.
Robert Arthur (Bob) Nash, the first captain of the first New York Giants professional football team in 1925, died yesterday in Winsted, Conn., where he had lived for 15 years. He was 84 years old.

MARIBOR, Yugoslavia, Feb.1(AP) Claudia Giordani, a 21-year-old Italian, won the special slalom today for her first victory in this season's World Cup skiing competition. Monika Kaserer of Austria, 24, finished second and Perrine Pelen, France's 16-year-old sensation, was third.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 The State Legislature passed an emergency bill this evening to bail out thousands of holders of worthless money orders in New York State and to protect future buyers of money orders from loss if the company that issues them fails.

Three years ago two of the venerable Yiddish publications in the city, The Workmen's Circle and The Jewish Daily Forward, migrated northward from the Lower East Side. They moved into the old Harper Row building at 45 East 33d street, forsaking the 12-story Forward building at 175 East Broadway, across the street from Seward Park.

Matt Kallman of Gimbels, Anthony Conrad of RCA, J.C. Walker of Rath Packing, Arthur Taylor of CBS, Gary Childress of Dart Industries and J.W. Richard Goodwin of Johns-Manville all suddenly left top executive posts in major companies last year.

Gale Sayers, who was elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame last month, was among 11 players named yesterday to the College Football Hall. The 33-year-old former running back, now athletic director at Southern Illinois University, became the youngest person to be honored by the National Football Foundation in the last two decades.
Prices of frozen orange juice futures contracts for near delivery continued to gain yesterday, while the distant deliveries declined further in hectic trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.

LITTLE ROCK TEN years ago, Arkansas did not have a symphony orchestra worthy of the name. Now it has five. Whether all are worthy of the name is debatable, but at least two are attracting highly competent musicians and one has begun to play occasionally outside the state.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 The Senate reorganization plan, severely compromised in committee, further unraveled on the Senate floor today with reinstatement of the Committee on Aging by a vote of 90 to 4.

President Carter told the Soviet envoy at their first meeting that the United States would not back down in its commitment for strengthened human rights in the Soviet Union and elsewhere. He called this a commitment on a position, not an attack on the Soviet Union. Plans for next month's resumption of strategic arms negotiations in Moscow took up most of the one-hour White House meeting. [Page A1, Cols. 1-2.]

GENEVA, Feb. 1 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim said today that he would try a touch of shuttle diplomacy during the Middle East peace mission he begins tomorrow by visiting Egypt both before and after he confers with Israel's leaders.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) New orders for durable goods increased 7.7 percent for the biggest December increase in six years, the Commerce Department said today.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, the world's largest investorowned enterprise, yesterday announced earnings of $3.83 billion for 1976, a record for any corporation.

ENGLEWOOD, Feb. 1 By 9:30 A.M., the state's big unemployment office here was wall-to-wall people. The jobless were filed into 10 lines, each about 35 feet long, for the long wait for processing or payment.
Executives of Burlington Northern Inc. and the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway said yesterday that their companies had begun a joint study on the feasibility of combining the two railways.
Young donors and many older ones continue to think of the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund as it continues through its final month.

HONG KONG, Feb. 1 A new wall poster in Canton has charged that over the last 10 years China's economy has been strongly outperformed by Japan's and that, because of China's low standard of living, social order has broken down and crime has risen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) Rejecting a plan to divert some Federal day care funds to emergency utility subsidies for the poor, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare has begun a study to determine what subsidies might be made available later.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 1 From the windows of their Manhattan office, the Vietnamese representatives here have a fine view of New York Harbor and the East River.

TRENTON, Feb. 1 State officials said today that conservation efforts by residential customers to reduce their use of natural gas and other fuels for home heating were inadequate and that drastic steps, such as the cutting off of supplies to some communities, were being contemplated.

Something quite remarkable happened in this country last week. An estimated 130 million Americans shared an experience unlike any in our history as we sat night after night watching the television adaptation of Alex Haley's tale of his family's passage through more than 200 years of African and American history.

SAN DIEGO, Feb. 1 A bankruptcy trial opening here tomorrow will center on allegations that Richard M. Nixon's former law firm induced Government regulatory agencies in 1973 to conceal evidence of massive bank frauds by C. Arnholt Smith, a longtime political benefactor of Mr. Nixon.

RICHMOND, Feb. 1 (AP) Federal District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr., declaring that the Allied Chemical Corporation was contrite and sincere, today reduced its $13.2 million fine for violations of Federal pollution laws to $5 million.

RICHMOND, Feb. 1(AP) Tom Okker beat Onny Parun, 6-3, 6-2, and Tony Roche turned back Wotjek Fibak, 6-1, 4-6, 6-4, in the opening round of the Richmond tennis tournament tonight. The first prize is $30,000 in the World Championship Tennis circuit event.

Rescuing Manhattan Plaza, the unfinished housing that looms like a red brick elephant over West 42d Street, is not just a good idea; for this financially battered and housing-shy city it is also a necessity.
The Soviet Union is continuing the supply of weapons, ammunition and spare parts to Egypt through third countries, according to senior Israeli intelligence sources.
Emile Griffith and two of the world's ranking 147-pound contenders, Wilfredo Benitez and Harold Weston Jr., will display their guile and punching prowess in Madison Square Garden tonight.
RACINE, Wis. For more than two years, teams of American agricultural specialists have visited the manicured Chinese farm fields that have fed a quarter of mankind for thousands of years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) The White House wants to know not only what the news reports are saying, but also if reporters are getting their facts right.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 President Carter's effort to install Theodore C. Sorensen as the Director of Central Intelligence was not blocked. It collapsed.

TRENTON, Feb. 1 Governor Byrne had twice as much fun today as his predecessors in delivering his annual Budget Message to the Legislature. He divided it into parts, and said each part was a gem. More than anything else.

HELSINKI, Feb. 1 (UPI) President Urho Kekkonen, who has been in office since 1956, said today he opposed any plan by Parliament to extend his present term beyond its 1978 expiration date without elections.
The North American Soccer League's coach of the year in 1975 is "fed up" with the league moving his team to a different division for the fourth time in five years.

Donald K. Mackenzie, a former vice president of the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York who had been a financial consultant for the last five years, died Monday in Overlook Hospital, Summit, N.J., after a long illness. He lived in Short Hills, and was 62 years old.

The owner of a pizza parlor at 944 Columbus Avenue was charged with felonious assault and unlawful possession of a loaded gun yesterday after shooting another man who was allegedly robbing him at knifepoint in the pizza parlor Monday night, the police reported.
The cold wave has apparently had one desirable side effect: it has, at least, temporarily, snapped the crime wave.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 1 (Agence France-Presse) Cambodian Communist soldiers killed 30 people and burned four hamlets last weekend because a Thai villager failed to deliver supplies the Cambodians had already paid for.

The credit markets continued to decline yesterday, extending the current pronounced move toward higher interest rates into its fifth consecutive week. As prices dropped and rates rose, the Treasury sold $3 billion of three-year notes

ALBANY, Feb. 1 Although it is only a month old, the state's "sunshine law," which requires governmental bodies to conduct their business in public, is already clouded by agencies that use semantic distinctions to sabotage the law's intent, an official monitoring committee reported to the Legislature today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Vice President Mondale, tired but buoyed after a nineday trip to Europe and Japan, returned to Washington today and said that the cornerstone of United States foreign policy was "close cooperation and consultation" with allies and that the major industrialized nations now had a clear understanding of the Carter Administration's intentions abroad.

DENVER, Feb. 1 Extremely dry weather is endangering next summer's water supplies from the Rocky Mountain states to the Pacific Coast, according to the latest data from the Department of Agriculture. Lack of snow is also threatening crops, especially wheat, in the plains of Kansas, Nebraska, the Dakotas, Oklahoma, Texas, Wyoming and Colorado.
MOSCOW, Feb. 1 (AP) A man set himself on fire in Red Square yesterday and is being treated for burns in a hospital, a Soviet official said today. He described the man as mentally ill.

The New York City Board of Education is planning to impose a record fine of $25,000 upon a $16,510-a-year school lunch employee who was suspended last August, along with two superiors, because of irregularities in the awarding of more than $2 million in purchase orders.

Paul M. Atkins, a retired financial and management consultant, died Monday in Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge, N.J., after a long illness. He lived at 199 Inwood Avenue in Montclair, N.J., and was 84 years old.

The electric blanket is not exactly a staple of life in Miami, so when the temperatures plummeted into the 20's and 30's there recently, stores suddenly found themselves sold out and swamped with requests from newly chilled customers.
Philip A. Thompson, director of marketing research for The New York Times, died yesterday while vacationing in Portau-Prince, Haiti. He was 50 years old.
Edward L. Wright, a former president of the American Bar Association, died yesterday in Little Rock, Ark. He was 73 years old.

GLENDALE, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP) Charles F. Willard the nation's first barnstorming pilot and the fourth American to pilot an airplane, died yesterday in Glendale Community Hospital. He was 93 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Governor Carey, Mayor Beame and Senator Daniel P. Moynihan emerged from an hour-long conference today with the Secretary of Transportation, Brock Adams, confident that the Cabinet member would allow the $1.2 billion Westway highway project in Manhattan to go forward without delay.
Reader's Digest has a nice image. It is always doing nice things to embellish its nice image.
Because Glenn Sullivan is the senior valet at Aqueduct, tending to jockeys' gear for 40 years, he can take his month's vacation whenever he wants. He took off last month.

CHICAGO Recently, a friend's daughter reported that her freshman year at a well-known Midwestern college was "turning out to be a drag" because "the school's going broke." She and her parents had considered academic reputation, size, location, and their own finances in making a final choice, but like most people they had not inquired into the college's finances.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) The House today passed by voice vote a bill to increase the ceiling on total Federal small business loans from $6 billion to $8 billion.
David E. Finley, former director of the National Gallery of Art and past chairman of the United States Commission of Fine Arts, died early yesterday in his home in Georgetown. He was 86 years old.

It took the Denver Broncos only a day to name a replacement for John Ralston, the head coach who resigned Monday. The new man is Robert (Red) Miller, who most recently was the offensive coordinator for the New England Patriots.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1 (UPI) Freddie Prinze, the television star who shot himself last week, left the bulk of his estate to his mother and 10-month-old son but specifically omitted as beneficiaries his father and estranged wife, according to the will filed for probate yesterday.

Lack of snow is also threatening crops, especially wheat, in the plains of Kansas, Nebraska, the Dakotas, Oklahoma, Texas, Wyoming and Colorado.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 1 (Reuters) The Chilean Government tonight came to the defense of Lieut. Col. Jaime Lavin Farina, a Foreign Ministry official who was asked to cut short an official visit to the United States last weekend after allegations that he had tortured political prisoners.

Governor Carey's proposal for reducing the state's Tuition Assistance Program was attacked yesterday by officials of the City University of New York, who charged that the plan would place a "grossly inequitable share" of the reduction on City University students, especially those who are poor, older or selfsupporting.

HOUSTON, Jan. 31 In August 1974, researchers at the Central Intelligence Agency completed a classified 36-page working paper, entitled "A Study of Climatological Research as It Pertains to Intelligence Problems." In it they reported, "Leaders in climatology and economics are in agreement that a climatic change is taking place and that it has already caused major economic problems throughout the world."

New York Democratic and Republican leaders have agreed on a June 7 primary date, but have not resolved their differences over whether there should be a runoff mayoral primary in New York City if no candidate in the first primary receives at least 40 percent of the vote.

COLLEGES have been finding all kinds of ways to attract students to their classrooms who wouldn't ordinarily be there. They've reached up to the middle-aged and the elderly. And at least two of them Bank Street College and the New School for Social Research have reached down for school-age children.

A letter of intent for construction of up to three supertankers that would be the world's largest and the first propelled by nuclear energy has been signed by a Kashmiri-born British shipping magnate and the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

If Denmark ever breaks off diplomatic relations with the United States, it will undoubtedly be due to our use of the term Danish pastry to describe the leaden, oily, artificially yellow and cloyingly sweet cakes we find in luncheonettes, on coffee wagons and on grocery store shelves. Compared to the yeasty, buttery, flaky and delicate pastries that the Danes know as Vienna bread Wienerbrod the importers we produce amount to a national insult.

IF THIS IS WEDNESDAY, you will probably watch ABC no matter what I say. Wednesday, a night nobody wanted for years, is now owned by ABC, which delivers a series of libidinal curves: Lindsay Wagner ("The Bionic Woman"), Robert Blake ("The Bionic Baretta") and Farrah Fawcett-Majors ("The Bionic Angel Cake").

The United Technologies Corporation, of which the Otis Elevator Company became a wholly-owned subsidiary last July, reported a 37 percent jump in fourth-quarter earnings. The major diversified producer of aircraft engines, helicopters and industrial products said net income totaled $39.5 million, or $1.18 a share, in the final 1976 quarter, while sales rose 5 percent to $1.4 billion.

With forecasts of below-freezing February weather threatening continued widespread unemployment in the eastern half of the country, California yesterday imposed restrictions on natural gas including a ban on all luxury uses to let its utilities ship gas supplies to the South and Middle West.
TEL AVIV, Feb. 1 (UPI) Security forces used tear gas today to break up crowds of teen-age demonstrators in Nablus on the Israeli-occupied West Bank of the Jordan River.

John McVay, using his Ohio and Memphis connections, has reached back into the cradle of coaches for an assistant. The Giants named Joe Galat, a former McVay assistant, as defensive line coach yesterday, thus completing their staff for the 1977 National Football League season.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 1. (UPI) The Cleveland Barons were told that they would not receive paychecks today and that a high-level meeting would be held tomorrow on whether the financially ailing National Hockey League team could finish its first season here.
CORTE MADERA, Calif., Feb. 1 Faucets were tightened and baths were postponed here today as Marin County began a tough water-rationing program to reduce normal water consumption by 57 percent.
A key election in the history of American labor will be held next Tuesday among 1.4 million members of the United Steelworkers of America in all parts of the United States and Canada.

Edwin Bolwell, editor of The New York Post, said yesterday that he had had "no disagreements over anything" with Paul Sann, The Post's longtime executive editor, whose resignation was announced Monday.

BUFFALO, Feb. 1 Warmed by the first bright sun they had seen in a week and buoyed by a dropoff in snow flurries and driving winds, citizens of this frozen city yesterday bent to the task of digging out.
MONTREAL, Feb. 1 A police slowdown, begun here yesterday in a contract dispute, has been accompanied by a sharp rise in armed robberies in the Montreal metropolitan area.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 1 (AP) The New York Nets traded their leading scorer, John Williamson, to the Indiana Pacers tonight in exchange for the Pacers' No. 1 pick in the 1977 collegiate draft, plus future considerations.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 The State Legislature passed an emergency bill this evening to bail out thousands of holders of worthless money orders in New York State and to protect future buyers of money orders from loss if the company that issues them fails.
An 84-year-old bedridden man was fatally burned last night despite his wife's efforts to shield him when fire swept through the bedroom of the couple's duplex apartment at 115 East 78th Street.
A large contingent of players from the New York metropolitan area returned home Sunday after a happy week at the Bermuda regional championships, always a popular tournament.

February got off to a promising start in the stock market yesterday as a wide range of issues from the energy stocks to the recently battered drug group participated in a mild rally following January's sharp selloff.

The press secretary of the Palestine Liberation Organization was asphyxiated in his East Side apartment last night after his mattress caught fire, apparently the result of smoking carelessness, fire officials reported.

MARISA BERENSON has come and gone. Margaux Hemingway is here, but she has been here for a whole season, and so she no-longer counts. Besides, she has gotten married. Yasmin Khan doesn't seem much interested, and when she went to the opening of "Pumping Iron," which was the opening that everyone had to go to that week, she slipped in through a side door to avoid the photographers.
Proving that love conquers all, the Cleveland Nets of World Team Tennis will announce the signing of Bjorn Borg and his fiancee, Mariana Simionescu, to multiyear contracts today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Six weeks after she was picked by President Carter to be Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Patricia Roberts Harris still has not selected a single person to serve in her top sub-Cabinet positions.

THERE is no doubt that tastes in food are sometimes cyclical. During the 1930's when I was an apprentice and then a young chef at the Restaurant Drouant in Paris, there were numerous dishes that appeared on Paris menus that contained or centered on cooked oysters. And then for a long time cooked oysters were seldom heard of on French menus.

ROME, Feb. 1 Some months ago Roberto, a 23-year-old mathematics student at the University of Rome, started to experiment with sniffing heroin. A few weeks ago he injected it, became addicted and embarked on a $20-a-day habit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 House and Senate conferees worked out an agreement tonight on pricing of emergency natural gas sales to interstate pipelines, thus appearing to clear the way for final passage tomorrow by Congress of the Carter Administration's emergency gas allocation bill.

This year marks the 10th anniversary of a revolutionary medical procedure for examining the fetus that has helped many thousands of women to give birth to normal, healthy children. Last year alone, about 5,000 pregnant women reaped the benefits of prenatal diagnosis. Yet tens of thousands more who could benefit are not taking advantage of it.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 1 (Reuters) Sixteen missing British guests of President Idi Amin of Uganda, who were stranded for two days when their plane went down in a remote part of East Africa, were rescued and flown to safety today, Kenyan air rescue coordinators said.

It tends to be more enthusiastic about cooking and more innovative at it than some of the female married variety simply because it does it out of choice rather than by obligation.

Ernest Gottscho, who retired in 1969 as a librarian and translator for the Geological Survey of the United States Department of the Interior in Washington, died Monday in the Holly Manor Nursing Home, Mendham N.J. He was 81 years old and lived in Mandham.

When Dick Manoff, chairman of Richard K. Manoff, was asked to comment on the recent announcement by Norman, Craig Kummel that it was renouncing personnel search firms and would henceforth do its own headhunting in-house, he laughed.

TRENTON, Feb. 1 Governor Byrne presented to the Legislature today a record $4 billion annual state budget, said it was one of the most frugal in New Jersey's history and complimented himself and the Legislature for "tax reform" and "fiscal restraint."

ALBANY, Feb. 1 Redistricting of the New York City Council in time for next November's election appears virtually impossible because Democrats and Republicans have failed to agree on an enlarged Council.

RELIEF is on the way for the legions of people who drink modest wine in heavily French Montreal. With the ex ception of beer and cider, alcoholic beverages in the province of Quebec are sold only through government outlets where service tends to be surly and cursory.

The next time you are offered a tray of hors d'oeuvres with chunks of cheddar and slivers of aromatic tilsiter, beware of showing your cheese expertise. For that little tilsiter, genuine as it seems, may be made out of cottonseed, and the small chunk of aged-looking cheddar may have been part of a coconut.
MONTREAL, Feb. 1 A police slowdown, begun here yesterday in a contract dispute, has been accompanied by a sharp rise in armed robberies in the Montreal metropolitan area.

Eighty million Americans the largest television audience in the history of the medium, watched the final episode of "Roots," the dramatization of a black family's life during the American slavry era, the National Nielsen Ratings reported yesterday.
NASHVILLE, Feb. 1 (AP) In what he called "a radical remedy" to end segregation, a Federal District judge has ordered two state universities here to merge within three years.

RALEIGH, N.C. Thirty-five-year-old Arthur Epps, who calls himself King Arthur when he is behind a microphone, has had his ups and downs as an entertainer, singing on street corners in New York, recording his first single when he was 16, composing the sound track for a grade B movie in the early 1960's, playing and singing in barrooms and clubs across the country.

BIVALVE, Md., Feb. 1 The coldest winter for Chesapeake Bay and Potomac River watermen in four decades has crystallized thousands of miles of crab-andoyster filled shoreline, turning one of the world's richest fisheries into a glistening, ice-bound deep freeze.

Prices of home heating oil in the New York metropolitan area have increased by about 12 percent since last winter, according to major dealers, and the rise shows no signs of abating.

In Eric Krebs's "Brothers," two brothers spend a summer building a house and cementing their sibling rivalry. The younger brother, Max, is all thumbs and calluses. The older one, Tom, is a born builder and a bit of a dreamer."Brothers" is about missed opportunities-the two characters are past the point of connection or even of collaboration. The play itself is an exercise in futility.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (Reuters) Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance will begin a visit to the Soviet Union on March 28 to discuss the limitation of strategic arms, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 President Carter announced today that he would nominate Paul C. Warnke as the chief negotiator on arms control matters. The nomination is expected to touch off a debate in the Senate over the former Pentagon official's views on arms reduction.

RICHMOND, Feb. 2 The first upset of the $100,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament came tonight when Corrado Barazzutti of Italy toppled Dick Stockton, 6-4, 6-2, and advanced to the quarterfinal round.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopa (UPI) At a score of dusty and isolated outposts along Ethiopia's wild northern frontier, Africa's longest war is being fought between American-armed troops and Arab-backed guerrillas.

ST.PAUL, Feb. 2 (AP) The Minnesota Agriculture Department says inspectors have found household shelf paper coated with Chlordane, a possible cancer-causing pesticide, in two west-central Minnesota grocery stores.

TRENTON, Feb.2 Ann Klein, Commissioner of Human Services, said today that a thousand or more "disturbed" children, 200 of them severely retarded, were getting virtually no education from the state, and that several thousand others got less than their "constitutional right."

New York City failed yesterday, as expected, to come up with a plan to pay off the holders of nearly $1 billion in its short-term notes, but at the same time officials reported that the principal banks and municipal unions had taken important steps toward resolving their differences over how those short-term notes should be repaid.
Having satisfied his ambitions at the tournament level, with victories at Wimbledon, Paris, Rome, Dallas and Boston, Bjorn Borg said yesterday that he would give World Team Tennis a three-year fling.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 2 The lawyer for Walter Weikers, accused of trying to bribe a juror in the trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel, said today that the juror had solicited the bribe.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (UPI) Marine reservists at Glenview Naval Air Station can avoid haircuts by tucking long hair under short wigs, United States District Court Judge Alfred Y.Kirkland has ruled.

PRINCETON, Feb.2 It is thesiswriting time for 975 seniors at Princeton University. While this has been going on now for undergraduates here for 50 years, old theses may at best be a questionable guide for today's authors.
Ibnu Sutowo, 62 years old, was dismissed early last March as head of Pertamina, the Indonesian state oil company, after it ran up more than $3 billion in debts.

WASHINGTON, Feb.2 (UPI) Samia Megalli, mentor and friend to a generation of foreign correspondents in Egypt, died last night in George Washington University Medical Center after a long illness. She was 47 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 The United States Embassy in Seoul knew of most facets of South Korea's five-year covert effort to influence American policy and lodged strong protests with senior officials of the Korean Government, according to knowledgeable Federal officials here.

The vodka downed neatly in Borough Park with Noik Yankovitch, a Jewish emigrant from the Soviet Union who came here last Thanksgiving, had an ethereal sharpness, like his memories of the homeland winter.
