A Federal grand jury in Chicago yesterday indicted a former senior vice president of the First National Bank of Chicago on charges of mail fraud and embezzling more than $250,000 from First National.

The American Can Company, the nation's second largest can maker, said yesterday it planned to raise the prices on all metal cans by approximately 8 percent on March 14. The credit markets yesterday scored their first big advance of 1977. Prices rose modestly in the morning after President Carter's television talk and Arthur F. Burns's Congressional testimony apparently comforted traders and investors. They then soared late in the afternoon after the Federal Reserve disclosed large declines in the nation's money supply.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 In the first use of the emergency powers signed into law last night by President Carter, Richard L. Dunham, chairman of the Federal Power Commisison, signed an order today that will increase gas flowing from the Southwest to New York City and other eastern markets.

The campaign for a new president of the United Steelworkers of America has acquired some of the characteristics of a public election, complete with tours, outside volunteers, big-name fund-raisers and free-flowing publicity. He also did very well as novelist, cartoonist, autobiographer and pioneer balloonist.

Marking the best rise in 10 days, soybean futures prices closed up 13 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Prices of other commodities futures traded on the exchange were also higher.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 The Senate voted 49 to 44 today to abolish the Committee on Nutrition and Human Needs, after the committee's chairman had sadly noted that the hungry poor could not muster the lobbying efforts that had saved nine other committees marked for extinction.

Well, not much tonight or tomorrow night, as though the networks knew they ware going to be tired after a week of trying to figure out the significance of ABC's amazing ratings sweep. But American history makes a comeback Sunday, as fact and fiction, with some mixed and interesting results.

To a store buyer from Chicago, Helen Boehm is the "movie star of the porcelain business." To Reese Palley, the Atlantic City art dealer who is the largest purveyor of Boehm porcelain in the world, she is a woman of incredible energy. "I'm not a guy of low energy myself," said Mr. Palley, "but in Helen's presence all I can do is gape."
BRUSSELS, Feb. 3 (UPI) The dollar closed generally higher in Europe today while the British pound dropped in the wake of another minimum lending rate cut. The price of gold was mixed.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey postponed at least until midMarch its decision on whether to allow the Concorde supersonic airliner to operate to and from Kennedy International Airport.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 3 From the air the landscape in and around Watertown looks more like a barren polar region than the area of gently rolling dairy and beef farms, winter recreation resorts and the bustling-light industry that it normally is.

TOKYO, Feb. 3 The Japanese Government declared itself satisfied today with Vice President Mondale's assurance that the United States would seek to maintain stability in Korea, while carrying out its intention to withdraw American troops. But at the same time, it indicated the sensitivity with which it views any change in the status quo.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 The upper ceiling that President Carter intends to impose on the number of Federal Government employees will probably become known by March 1 when his Administration offers its amendments to President Ford's last budget, the White House said today.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3 At 180 miles an hour, it is possible to mistake Milt Minter for Paul Newman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 President Carter gave the country the old Dutch Uncle treatment in his first fireside talk all real cozy, quiet and familylike but he has a problem with this gentle folksy approach to the energy crisis.

Tha New York City Ballet is an American company whose artistic director, George Balanchine, was trained in the Russian school of ballet. But tomorrow at 8 P.M., the City Ballet will take on a Danish cast with a new production called "Bournonville Divertissements."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 The Department of Justice has paid private lawyers nearly $800,000 to represent present and former Government officials in civil suits stemming from Government surveillance activities and will ask for an additional $4.8 million to pay such legal fees next year, a Justice Department spokesman confirmed today.
George F. Milliken, a steamship industry executive, died yesterday at his home. He was 76 years old and lived at 12 Beekman Plaza.
MADRID, Feb. 3 Garbagemen are on strike. The February sales are even more enticing than the post-Christmas sales. Skiers throng the slopes of the nearby Sierra Guadarrama.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Transportation Secretary Brock Adams today endorsed the $1.2 billion Westway project to be built in Manhattan to replace the old West Side Highway from the Battery to 42d Street.

COTONOU, Benin, Feb. 2 Shortly before 7 o'clock on the morning of Jan. 16 a plane with a blue tail whose markings were covered in white screeched to a bumpy landing at the drowsy airport here. Out jumped 80 to 100 men in battle gear, firing automatic weapons. Half were whites.

Racal Electronics Ltd. of Britain announced yesterday that it had increased the price it will pay for all shares of the Milgo Electronics Corporation of Miami Florida from $30 a share to $32.50 a share. The offer includes all shares that have already been tendered at $30.

The Atlanta Falcons' search for a head coach has ended with the selection of Leeman Bennett, a Los Angeles Rams assistant. Eddie LeBaron, the Falcon's new general manager, made the announcement at a news conference yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) A Federal grand jury indicted Pan American World Airways, Trans World Airlines and Luft- hansa German Airlines today in the first criminal antitrust action involving airline rate-fixing.

JAMES EARL JONES invests his roles with his own boundless ebullience and explosive enthusiasm. He is a titanic actor whether playing tragedy or comedy?"King Lear," "The Bingo Long Traveling All-Stars and Motor Kings" or his latest Jones-size venture, "Oedipus Rex." Mr. Jones is doing "Oedipus" as an Off Off Broadway workshop, opening tonight and running for three weekends at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration proposed today to ban the country's most widely used food coloring, Yellow Dye No. 5, in certain drugs but not in food. An estimated 47,000 to 94,000 persons are allergic to the coloring, the agency said.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 3 New Jersey's Public Advocate asked Judge Philip A. Gruccio of Superior Court today to require rural Pittsgrove Township to provide relocation housing in the township for its displaced poor rather than move them to a ghetto in nearby Bridgeton.

Before he moved to Hollywood, before he got his first dinner jacket, and his nightclub act, and his Stingray, and his TV show, before he was on a first-name basis with Johnny Carson, and before he got invited to Malibu parties and Inauguration balls, Freddie Prinze lived in Apartment 64 at 550 West 157th Street.

In a calendar year there are some 25 tournaments in the New York metropolitan area, generating perhaps 400 individual winners of major titles and an equal number of runners-up. But the competition is so fierce that it is rela- tively rare for an individual to have two successes in one weekend. A triple success is very rare indeed, although it is sometimes achieved by a player with a national reputation.

Detectives are seeking two men who they say may be able to help them solve the murder of Christine Freund, the 26-year-old Wall Street worker from Ridgewood, Queens, who was shot to death, for no apparent reason, early last Sunday while sitting with her companion in a parked car on a quiet Forest Hills Street.

The Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation announced yesterday that in recognition of the hardships caused for its customers by the cold weather, it would give its natural gas users a $10 discount on their February bills.

IT'S MOSTLY UNKNOWN, undistinguished and unremembered, the short stretch of Manhattan that lies along Broadway and the Ave- nue of the Americas between 23d and 33d Streets, yet it was once at the heart of New York life, its Great White Way and its Tin Pan Alley. It's a noname section that spills over into Chelsea and Madison Square Park on the south and abuts Herald Square on the north.

New York State's Labor Department estimated yesterday that 750,000 workers statewide had been forced from jobs because of recent cold and energy problems. It foresaw a potential new drain of more than $30 million a week from unemployment insurance funds if an expected 350,000 eligibles all put in claims.
John Henry (Pop Lloyd, known to many of his fans as the "Black Honus Wagner," and Martin Dihigo of Cuba were elected to the Hall of Fame yesterday by the Committee on Negro Baseball Leagues.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that on his visit to Moscow next month he would raise the possibility of reductions both in Soviet and American strategic weapons and in conventional arms around the world.

Tenneco Inc., one of the giant diversified industrial enterprises of the nation, whose profits have climbed sharply since 1970, yesterday again reported record results for the fourth quarter and all of 1976.

RINGWOOD, Feb. 3 The first alarm about a water shortage came last Saturday from the Windbeam Water Company. The small, privately owned company beset all winter by frosts that impede replenishment of its underground wells was apprehensive because its two storage tanks were being drained by customers who had kept taps running to keep water pipes from freezing.

ALTHOUGH there has been an extraordinary renaissance in the building of pipe organs and a concomitant flowering of skilled and gifted organists throughout the United States since World War II, American composers have been slow to respond to the opportunities these developments have created. A few minor pieces have been written by nonorganist composers of major stature, but by and large they have neglected the field.

Robert S. Benjamin announced yesterday that he would resign as chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting at the next meeting of the board on March 9. He has held this position since December 1974.

OTTAWA, Feb. 3 (Reuters) Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau tonight held out the possibility that the Federal Government might hold a referendum on independence for the predominantly French-speaking province of Quebec.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 The United States raised today the possibility of faceto-face discussions with Cuba about the imperiled antihijacking agreement and other issues impeding normal relations.

Next Monday, Louise Talma will begin her 50th year as a teacher at Hunter College. To salute her, tomorrow night at 8 in the Hunter College Playhouse there will be "A Celebration for Louise" by friends and colleagues, including Phyllis Curtin, Charles Bressler, Lukas Foss, Herbert Rogers, Peter Basquin and the Gress Smith Singers.
James I. Laufer, a textile industry executive died Tuesday at Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center; Queens. He was 60 years old and a resident of Massapequa, L.I, and Port St. Lucie, Fla.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 3 Ethiopia's chief of state and six other mem bers of the nation's feuding leadership were killed today as a gun battle erupted around headquarters of the governing council, official broadcasts reported.

Allen Ginsberg, a familiar figure at Columbia University in the 1940's, will be reading some new poetry this Sunday at 2:30 P.M. at the West End, the bar on Broadway and 114th Street frequented by generations of students.

CESAR PELLI is a gracious and dignified Argentine who until last month was living in Los Angeles earning a reputation as the creator of some of the West Coast's most refined architecture. As chief of design for the large firm of Gruen Associates, he built in California and elsewhere a series of sleek glass buildings that combined the suaveness of reflective glass with the toughness of industrial materials.

A couple might have no difficulty at all in deciding to have a child; it's the name that gives them the problem. They'll spend days, weeks, even years mulling over names, accepting then rejecting, sometimes right up until a child is born and after.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 President Carter gave a quietly effective campaign speech from the White House fireside, promising action, candor and togetherness. Once in, as in his walk down Pennsylvania Avenue, he managed to symbolize by the apparent informality of the occasion and the sweater he wore his intention to remain in touch with his constituency and aware of its moods.

Interior Chief Is Planning to End Influence of the Special Interests WASHINGTON, Feb.3 Cecil D. Andrus the new Secretary of the Interior, has declared that he will make sweeping institutional and policy changes to end what he sees as the domination of his department by mining, oil and other special interests and to make it responsive to environmental needs.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 4 A Federal Court jury here found Walter Weikers, 67 years old, of Baltimore, guilty today of jury tampering in the aborted trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland. He faces a possible maximum penalty of five years in jail and/or a $5,000 fine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 President Carter's request for the power to reorganize the Government was sent to Capitol Hill today, the first step in what could become a lively contest between the White House and Congress.
Tom Penders, Columbia's basketball coach, said: "We played in spurts. There wasn't much continuity on either the offense or the defense."

PARIS, Feb. 4 Reacting to complaints of the Carter Administration about their plans for nuclear exports, France and West Germany today indicated intentions to continue selling nuclear technology to other countries for peaceful purposes.

NAPLES, Ill., Feb. 3 A cutting wind was lacing snow into their ice-encrusted beards this afternoon as members of the La Salle Expedition II slogged through knee-deep drifts along the frozen waters of the Illinois River.

The Orthodox Church in America yesterday in effect suspended Archbishop Valerian D. Trifa, one of its Bishops, who has been accused of Nazi war crimes, from the governing board of the National Council of Churches.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 The swine flu immunization program has already resulted in 104 damage claims against the Federal Government, totaling nearly $11 million, according to a compilation by the Justice Department.

LONDON, Feb. 4 (Reuters) The Labor Government is under pressure from a small group of ministers to think again about its plan to sell nearly $1.2 billion worth of shares in the British Petroleum Company.

The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra came to Carnegie Hall on Thursday night to give a concert under the direction of Irwin Hoffman, with Daniel Shefran, the Soviet cellist, as soloist. The program began with Ulysses Kay's "Of New Horizons," continued with Schumann's Cello Concerto in A minor and ended with Berlloz's Symphonie Fantastique.

There's a tiny shop on Madison Avenue devoted to the simple 18-karat gold jewelry that Jean Dinh Van designs. His rings, bracelets, earrings and chains are the kind of ornaments that, like a woman's wedding band or a man's signet ring, are almost never taken off.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 An elevated traincrowded with homeward-bound passengers bounced off the back of a train ahead of it late this afternoon at one of the busiest intersections in Chicago's Loop, hurling two of its first four cars to the street about 20 feet below and leaving two others dangling from the tracks.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Feb. 4 The chief delegates of the Soviet Union and Israel have had an unusual private meeting on the Middle East but once again disagreed on the question of participation by the Palestine Liberation Organization in a future Geneva conference.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) Under pressure from the first outbreak of A-Victoria flu this year, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Joseph A. Califano Jr., asked medical and scientific experts today to advise him whether to resume the nationwide influenza vaccination program.

Two gunmen took over a northbound IND train last night and, during the seven-minute express ride between 59th and 125th Streets, held about 40 passengers captive as a third man walked through the cars demanding wallets and jewelry.
DALLAS, Feb. 4 (UPI) World Championship Tennis today sued Bjorn Borg, the Swedish tennis star; his agent, and two prominent tennis sponsors for $5.7 million, alleging breach of contract.
HARTFORD, Feb, 4 Success finally found Charles Tickner tonight at the United States figure skating championships.

SUFFERN, N.Y. It is probably silly to complain that our Government has so little use for men and women of letters and of humane learning. The only such persons I can think of who have held something like high office in my time are Archibald MacLeish, under Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Charles Frankel, under Lyndon B. Johnson: noble emblems for the State Department but hardly makers of high policy.

ROME One important argument for strengthening NATO is rarely used and is also difficult for most people to understand because it is so complex. Simply stated, it is that those Western Communist movements known collectively as "Eurocommunism," which has gained great influence in Italy, has considerable potential in Spain, and is stirring in France, would rapidly lose their independence of Moscow if the equilibrium of strategic power tilted.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 4 (UPI) Tanzania closed at least one border post with Kenya today and began seizing Kenyan aircraft and vehicles.
Racal Electronics of Britain again raised its cash bid yesterday for all shares of the Milgo Electronic Corporation to $35 a share in a bidding duel with Applied Digital Data Systems.
Ibsen's little-known play "The League of Youth" has been revived as Lazarus was revived: altered and grisly.

A group of New York State legislators received conflicting advice yesterday from witnesses at a hearing on how to amend a proposed divorce bill that is intended to be fairer to both husbands and wives.

The state's Insurance Commissioner, James J. Sheeran, urged a Senate committee in Washington to retain the Federal crime-insurance program. The program, which is due to expire April 30, provides a service to city dwellers that cannot be obtained on the open market, Mr. Sheeran said.
A 32-year-old Long Island food-service employee yesterday won what was billed as "the largest lump sum ever given away to one person in United States history" $980,000.
Construction on the final link of Interstate Route 280 in Hudson County from Harrison to the New Jersey Turnpike is to begin this spring, the State Transportation Department said.

It's hard to keep a bad idea down. The proposal for a Broadway Mall keeps popping up with relentless regularity. It is the kind of dated window dressing that boosters embrace, and someone seems to love at City Hall.

MOSCOW, Feb. 4 The Soviet Foreign Ministry today ordered a correspondent of The Associated Press to leave the country within a week. It was the first expulsion of an American journalist in seven years, and it underscored the rising Government pressure directed against the Western press here in recent months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 The nation's unemployment rate in January declined by a substantial amount, half of a percentage point, to 7.3 per cent of the work force but the improvement may be illusory, Government experts said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 The Senate approved today a plan to reorganize its committee structure that was heavily altered by intensive lobbying and defenses of senatorial prerogatives but that nonetheless wrought substantial changes.

PRAGUE, Feb. 4 (Reuters) Human rights activists made their first move tonight in apparent defiance of Czechoslovak authorities since their main spokesmen were warned on Monday that the manifesto Charter 77 on human and civil rights was illegal.

New York City's Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, said yesterday that he planned to employ an outside specialist to assure that the developers of the Manhattan Plaza apartment project did not make "windfall" profits from an unusual renting program approved conditionally by the Board of Estimate.

NOW VOYAGER The world premiere of a work by David Diamond, the distinguished American composer, is an occasion, and tonight's concert at 8 o'clock in Carnegie Hall also features another well-known creative name, that of the late poet and critic, James Agee.

ZANZIBAR, Tanzania, Feb. 4 (Reuters) Andrew Young, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, relaxed and played tennis on this island off the African coast today, his 10-day diplomatic visit to Africa temporarily sidetracked by celebrations here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) Now that it has experienced a rare $36.3 million surplus in a period of less than two months, the Postal Service has decided against raising postal rates this year.

The Observer, the 186-year-old British Sunday newspaper, may introduce "living" or entertainment sections similar to those that have been initiated by American newspapers over the past few years, the new president of the London-based newspaper said yesterday.

Manuel de Falla's "Fantasia Baetica" is the composer's major work for piano, written for Arthur Rubinstein, yet it is rarely played. It turned up Thursday night in the slightly unorthodox program by Zenon Fishbein in Alice Tully Hall. It is a difficult piece, only partly for technical reasons. Its stylization of Spanish rhythms and melodies demands color and flexibility on the part of the pianist to keep the work from sounding lone-winded.

Reversing their position of four years ago, top advisers of Mayor Beame agreed yesterday to the elimination of a runoff mayoral primary, thus making it virtually certain there would be only one primary for the mayoral, City Council President and Comptroller nominations in New York City this year.

The chairman of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said yesterday he understood that a special company review of questionable payments had turned up no evidence of "any improper domestic payments by Lockheed to politicians or any illegal campaign contributions."

New York Metropolitan area homeowners who budgeted for this winter's fuel bills based on what they spent last year will find themselves over budget by about 50 percent, unless they take conservation measures or the winter suddenly and unexpectedly warms up.
Farm commodity futures, after dropping most of the day, closed higher yesterday as a result of new buying in the closing minutes on the Chicago Board of Trade.

HONG KONG, Feb. 4 In the four months since Hua Kuo-feng was elevated to the chairmanship of the Chinese Communist Party, an outpouring of information has begun to fill in his background, providing a portrait of a shrewd, cautious man with a knack for taking the correct political line and attracting powerful friends.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 David Mamet's "A Life in the Theater" is a comedy about the artifice of acting. In a swift 75 minutes, the author spoofs actors' insecurities, pretensions and illusions the ironies and the ignominies of the profession. The author was once an actor and he makes his actors enormously vulnerable people. His attitude is wry and affectionate.
ROME, Feb. 4 The Italian Government announced new steps tonight to curb labor costs in an effort to meet conditions for needed loans from the International Monetary Fund.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb 4. (Reuters) Rhodesia today sought permission from the Botswana Government to take 150 black parents across the border to meet their children, who the Rhodesian Government says, were abducted to Botswana at gunpoint.

CAIRO, Feb 4 (Reuters) Egypt and Syria, the two biggest military powers in the Arab world, today announced formation of a unified political command, setting the seal on accommodation after more than a year of antagonism.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. That new House investigation into assassinations was almost certain to fail, even if the re-established Select Committee on Assassinations had been given the $13 million and the two-year life span it had sought. But this week, a skeptical Congress gave it only until March 31 and $84,000 a month with which to prove that it had a reason to exist.
VIENNA, Feb. 4 The Iranians didn't talk much to the Saudis, but the oil cartel's big bash was nevertheless one of the best parties this city has seen lately.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 American intelligence officials said today that both the Soviet Union and the United States were trying to develop high-energy beams of charged subatomic particles that would destroy incoming nuclear missiles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 The Carter Administration is considering a request to Congress for emergency funds to pay fuel bills of poor families, especially those threatened with a cutoff of electricty, gas or oil for nonpayment.
CAPE TOWN, Feb. 4 (UPI) Groups of blacks stoned schools and chased pupils from their classrooms today in a second day of unrest in black townships outside Cape Town.

The New Jersey Taxation Division, which has been receiving 1,000 calls a day with questions concerning the state's new income tax, conceded yesterday that unclear instructions on its tax forms could lead to payment of a higher tax than necessary by New Jerseyans who work in New York.
VIENNA, Feb. 4 (UPI) The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced today that it had signed 10 new agreements providing interest-free loan totaling $33.8 million to developing nations.

The Treasury Department announced yesterday that the Government's $750 million issue of 30-year bonds auctioned early in the afternoon was sold at an average interest rate of 7.63 percent. This rate was perhaps a quarter-point below the level Government bond dealers had predicted earlier this week.

MOSCOW, Feb. 4 Soviet authorities appear to have mounted a tough new campaign to try to muffle the small but increasingly vociferous dissident movement so that it will cause less embarrassment when the issue of human rights is discussed in the summer at an East-West conference in Belgrade.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Special interest groups representing business, industry and labor provided nearly two-thirds of the money that 15 major House committee-chairmen spent to win re-election last November.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 (AP) Two officers of the Public Service Commission recommended today that the state grant Consolidated Edison an electric rate increase of only about a fourth of the $249.8 million the company had requested.
Australia's first discovery of diamonds in commercial quantities has been made in a remote part of Western Australia by a consortium headed by Conzinc Rio Tinto of Australia Ltd.
TEL AVIV, Feb. 4 Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin flew secretly to Geneva today and held a three-hour meeting with President Felix Houphouet-Boigny of the Ivory Coast.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 4 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency has put a coke producing plant in northeastern Kentucky on a blacklist that prevents the plant from obtaining Federal contracts.

Energy-related issues provided the stock market with its best gains yesterday, while the glamour stocks continued to, flounder. Superior Oil, up 16 points, was a standout as it finished at 254 its highest price of 1976-77. The Dow Jones industrial average, ahead more than 3 points in midsession, eased toward the closing bell, finishing with a token 0.75 point gain at 947.89.

WASHINGTON A Washington patent lawyer was granted a patent this week for a pocket-size, nonlethal, electrical weapon. The invention, which has been named the Cobra, is about the size of a pack of cigarettes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Cuba has notified the United States that it wants to discuss the new American law establishing a 200-mile fishing zone off this country's coast, the State Department said today.

LONDON Feb. 4 (AP) The pound gained fractionally against the dollar today, closing at $1.7145, compared with yesterday's $1.7133. The price of gold was mixed.

HONOLULU, Feb. 4 Among the churning of 144 to 150 names and bodies that is characteristic of a pro golf tournament, an occasional unknown player pops to the surface and wins. Manhattan Plaza is hoping to have its first tenants move in on April 1. Those interested in viewing model apartments are asked to write for an appointment to Manhattan Plaza, Post Office Box 386, Times Square Station, New York, N.Y. 10036. About 3,000 applicants have filled out forms thus far for the 1,700 apartments.
R. Kenyon Kilbon, former staff vice president for editorial services of RCA Corporation, died Wednesday at Hartford Hospital in Hartford. He was 60 years old.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 4 (AP) Faced with a $62,000 repair bill on its electric chair, the State of Oklahoma is considering a measure that would make it the only state in the country to execute condemned criminals by injection of drugs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Despite some misgivings about the effectiveness of President Carter's plan for a one-shot tax rebate to stimulate the economy, many analysts still expect the measure to pass Congress so that checks, amounting to $200 for a family of four, would be in consumers' pockets within the next two to three months.

Manhattan Plaza is hoping to have its first tenants move in on April 1. Those interested in viewing model apartments are asked to write for an appointment to Manhattan Plaza, Post Office Box 386, Times Square Station, New York, N.Y. 10036. About 3,000 applicants have filled out forms thus far for the 1,700 apartments.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (UPI) In 40 years, the Chicago street and elevated railways had had four crashes in which passengers were killed before last night's wreck.

Along with hearts and flowers, cupids and lace, chocolates are among the more important appurtenances of the Valentine's Day celebration. Each year around Feb. 14, tons of chocolate candy are bought for gifts, and the holiday does, in fact, usher in what can be considered the chocolate season, which runs through Easter, with its candy rabbits, chicks and eggs, and ends on Mother's Day, when chocolate is once more the favored gift.

BUFFALO, Feb. 4 President Carter's 26-year-old son, James Earl (Chip), toured this severely winter-struck area today, expressing some amazement at what he saw, but offering no promise of the stepped-up Federal aid for which local officials have been pressing with increasing intensity.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 4 A judge in Superior Court ruled today that adopted persons in New Jersey, upon reaching their 18th birthday, should have easier access to their original birth certificates so as to satisfy a deep psychological need to know their roots.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Americans should not be jailed for growing small amounts of marijuana at home for their own use, Dr. Robert L. DuPont, director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse, suggested today.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 4 Frank H.T. Rhodes, vice president for academic affairs at the University of Michigan, is apparently in line to become the next president of Cornell University.

The Rev. Gilbert L. (Gil) Dodds, a former world indoor record-holder in the one-mile run, considered the best American miler of his time, died Thursday night at Delnor Hospital in St. Charles, Ill. of a brain tumor. He was 58 years old.

DETROIT, Feb. 4 The General Motors Corporation announced today that its Lordstown, Ohio, plant would be closed for the fifth straight week beginning Monday. The 2,450 workers there have been idle since Jan. 7 because of slumping small car sales. The plant makes Chevrolet Vega and Pontiac Astre cars, on which General Motors is offering $200 rebates to spur sales.
